Dr. Collins equably says, "It shouldn't be. Just try to give him a little blood every now and then. I know it's not easy, being who you are, what you are, and all that."
Sammie gulps and nods, "I'll try, doc. I'll try." There are dark circles under her eyes and she looks a lot more paler than the last time the doctor saw her.
Even Wyatt looks quite gaunt and tired. It seems like both these Thin-Blooded siblings are tired, overworked (especially in Sammie's case), and generally drained.
Dr. Collins offers, "How about I take you 3 out for a meal? Something small, just some burgers and shakes, really, just to keep your strength up."
Sammie sighs and shakes her head, "No, it's fine, doc. You don't need to do that, really. I see enough of burgers, shakes, and fucking fries at the diner I work at. No offense."
"None taken. You should really try to get a better job," Dr. Collins suggests.
Wyatt closes the storybook and replies, "Yeah, I keep telling her that, too. But, she insists on working at this stupid diner."
Ralf looks up and repeats, "Stu-pid. Di-ner. Heehehehe!"
Sammie blows a harsh raspberry, "It's the only place that doesn't ask too many questions. You know how hard it is to find a decent job in this fucking city?"
With tired eyes, she glares at the Flesh-Shaper, "Do you? That greasy dump is the only place where I can get some extra cash to put food on the table, make sure our bills are paid, and look after Ralf, you know?"
She rubs her temples and looks away, "Sorry, sorry, sorry. I'm just so tired and stressed out lately. It's been hard, keeping everything together."
Wyatt concurs, "Yep, it sure has."
Dr. Collins inquires, "Any luck getting through to...Ralf's father yet??"
Wyatt groans and his claws come out, "That asshole. Hmph. He won't even pick up when we call him. I've tried so many times, and he never picks up. I recently found out he's away on some kind of a...business trip. How convenient."
Sammie puts her hand on his shoulder and reassures him, "I'm sure you're doing your best, Wyatt."
Wyatt shrugs her hand off and springs up. Little Ralf lets out a tiny gasp. He gets scared seeing his uncle acting this way.
The Thin-Blood clenches his fists and grits his teeth. His face is flushed red with anger and he huffs and puffs, "Why does he get to walk away from all of this?! Huh?!"
Sammie tries to calm him down, "Wyatt, please, relax, you're scaring Ralf!"
Ralf calls out, "Mommy, mommy. I'm scared."
Sammie picks up her son and holds him tight, "It's OK, sweetheart. Your uncle Wyatt is just having a rough time. He didn't mean to scare you."
Wyatt walks over to the window and mutters, "Fucking bastard. Asshole. Coward. Gordon-fucking-Pym."
He looks outside and stares at the ground. He puts his hands on his head and breathes deeply.
Ralf waves to the doctor and grins, showing off his baby fangs.
Dr. Collins smiles and waves back.
Sammie sighs and walks over to Wyatt. She gently puts her hand on his shoulder, "I know it's hard, but...we'll get through this together. We always have."
Wyatt shrugs her hand off and steps away, "No! HOW, Sammie?! We--we're not asking for much, we're just asking that son of a bitch to pay child support, but he--he won't even acknowledge Ralf! Like he doesn't even EXIST!! Like it never happened! And it's fucking frustrating!"
Sammie sighs deeply and holds her son close, "I know. I know. But, we'll find a way. We always do."
Wyatt turns around and shakes his head, "It's just so fucking unfair."
Dr. Collins interjects, "Yeah, it is, isn't it? You...live in Flimont City for so long, you forget what decency even looks like."
Wyatt bitterly scoff-chuckles, "Yeah, I'm starting to see what you mean by that, doc."
Ralf kicks his legs, "Mommy, mommy! Bedtime! Can you tell me a stowy? Please? I like it when you tell me stowies."
Sammie chuckles and kisses his forehead, "Yes, Ralf. I'll tuck you into bed and read you a bedtime story. Just give me 1 minute, OK?"
She looks at Wyatt and asks, "Get him tucked in. I'll be there."
Wyatt puts on a smile, takes his nephew, and goes to the room with him.
Once they're out of sight, Sammie turns to the doctor and tells him, "Wyatt's been going through a rough patch lately. I thought he'd get better, but it's getting worse."
Dr. Collins nods and sighs, "I noticed that. Have you both been feeding regularly?"
The Mercurian scoffs, "Pfft? How? You know the so-called 'real Kindred' are out there, prowling, looking for every last one of us Thin-Bloods, right? It's been hard finding spots and reliable people to feed from, but we manage. Sorta." The uncertainty is all over her face.
"How?" the Tzimisce doctor asks with genuine curiosity.
Sammie answers, "We have our ways. We um...sometimes go to hospitals, especially the rundown ones- there's plenty of those in this godforsaken city."
Dr. Collins tells her, "It seems Sheriff Velma DuPont really has it out for your...kind. She's crazy. I just came here to warn you to be extra careful, OK?"
Sammie crosses her arms and frowns, "What's gonna happen to us, doc? Is there gonna be a time when I can't feed Ralf anymore?"
Dr. Collins reassures her, "It won't come to that, Sammie. It can't, OK? As Primogen for the Tzimisce Clan, I'll try to do my best to dissuade the others from pursuing such draconian policies."
Sammie puts her hands on her head and paces around, "Yeah, go on. Play politics or whatever fancy name they have for it. Single working moms like me don't get that luxury. We're just destined to work jobs that are shittier or more-shittier, heh."
She leans on the wall and heaves a deep sigh, "If--if only I had that little extra cash coming in, then I wouldn't have to worry as much. I just don't know why Gordon refuses to acknowledge Ralf."
The tired single mom looks at the floor and clenches her jaw, deep in contemplation and thought.
Semi-bloody tears well up in her eyes and she wipes them off, "Ugh. Forget it. Listen, I gotta go read bedtime stories to my boy. Thanks for coming by, doc. And thanks for everything you've done for us. Really. I'm sorry if I got a bit snappy back there. Wyatt's sorry, too. Probably."
With sincerity in her eyes, she adds, "It's not who we are as people. It's just that...things are not looking too great for us right now. I don't--I don't want my son to grow up in a world where he's always looking over his shoulders--"
Dr. Collins points out, "And there's the inescapable fact that you'll always remain the same while Ralf ages...it's not easy being in your shoes, Sammie. Now, I understand that."
Sammie puts on a smile and nods, "Hm, yeah. Anyway, th--thank you, doc. Thank you. Now, if you'll excuse me, I should get going. Goodnight."
"Goodnight," Dr. Collins says in kind. He walks over to the door and leaves the house.
He gets in his car and takes another look at the rearview mirror. Nope, no one following him. Good.
The Stoker sighs in relief, starts his car up, and goes back to the clinic to attend to his patients. He does so with his usual precision, non-judgmental attitude, and meticulousness.
The doctor goes about his night and attends to a wide variety of patients. He diagnoses, prescribes, and does everything he can to help the mortals who come through his clinic's doors.
It's certainly a good way to stay in touch with one's Humanity, and in a greedy and callous blightscape like Flimont City, it's almost essential to keep one's Humanity intact.
It is indeed the most important responsibility that any Kindred has. The ability to keep their Humanity intact is a boon that some Kindred squander away in exchange for wealth or power or whatever.
As for Dr. Collins, he's been able to keep his Humanity and compassion intact.
But, is individual kindness and decency enough to keep things going?
Frankly, no. It's absolutely good, yes, but it's not gonna lead to the systemic change desperately needed around these parts. Individual acts of goodness can only take one so far in this world of darkness.
So, Dr. Collins and his fellow Tzimisce will have to do something about this, sooner or later.
The question is, what will they do? What will the good doctor do in the coming nights, and how does the cold body in his storage unit factor into all of this?
Questions, questions, questions.
Chapter 12: The Waitress
Answers will come in due time. For now, the Kindred in this corner of the world prepare for the pull of the day-sleep. The sun begins to rear its hot and fiery head, and the creatures of the night retreat to their Havens and refuges for some rest.
(Some really long-ass rest).
Burt parks his van in an underground parking lot, completely sheltered from the rays of the sun. He pulls the keys out, groans, and heads to the back of his van.
He settles into a sleeping position, pulls a tatty old blanket over himself, and closes his eyes. After a few moments, the Baali goes completely still.
His was a long night of playing gigs at bars and restaurants. The money sucked, but it was better than literally no money at all, so he took whatever was given to him.
The crowd wasn't exactly receptive and he even had a few bottles of beer tossed at him by self-entitled guys in fancy suits who were jeering and booing him at every chance they got.
Was the music not to their liking? Was it Burt's washed-up (one might say subversive and unconventional) appearance that caused those guys to act in such an aggressive and hostile manner?
Oh, well, Burt will never know. He was quick enough to dodge most of the flying booze bottles. He even defiantly took a swig of some of the expensive booze, but he vomited it out later, though.
It's not blood, and it tasted like ash on his dead tongue.
Burt has played before, and audiences have been really welcoming, warm, receptive, and encouraging. But, F-City is different.
Culture is sadly something not held in high regard around these parts; it's always been a city of filthy lucre- petulant stockbrokers, coke-addled day traders, slimy hedge fund managers, nutty VCs, parasitic speculators, and their ilk run this place with an iron fist (in all but name).
The cops in this Midwestern city continue to be a menace, especially against the working masses. The fancy suits remain un-scuffed, but anyone who looks "shady" (you know what that usually means to an American police officer) gets the truncheon.
Or worse.
Anyways, what else happened last night?
A lot. Something quite pivotal, actually- a van got hit by the Brujah, like, literally smacked to scrap by a few of them. Poor sap who got hit had no idea what was going on. They just left a smashed and mangled van, bloodied driver, and a destroyed trailer in the middle of the street.
And then, they buzzed off, leaving all sorts of wreckage and chaos in their wake.
That van was carrying Vessels that "cater" exclusively to Prince Antonio's Rarefied Tastes, the Ventrue Clan Bane. It basically means that Blue Bloods can only feed from "certain" folk.
It could be as wide as the world's oceans or as narrow as a needle, or any freaky-crazy combination thereof, depending on the Ventrue in question.
As for Prince Antonio's Rarefied Taste, he bites down on folk who are of the rarest blood group in the world- the golden blood type or Rh null blood group.
He even has his own "private collection" in some other place that he goes to ONLY WHEN it's an emergency.
And, since the Brujah done fucked up, it do be an emergency. He's not gonna be too happy about it when he reawakens from his day-slumber, that's for sure!
Sheriff Velma DuPont has her own Rarefied Tastes- indie musicians. Yep, that's it. However, since this is Flimont City, those kinds of peeps are harder to come by (one would have greater luck locating teeth on a hen).
So, she drives out real far to get her filling of the thick red. Yummy!!
Prince Antonio has been known to utilize the routes of the Blood Trade to move (smuggle) his Vessels in and out of the state so as not to arouse suspicion or get on any government agencies' radars.
His "meals" are transported in these nondescript trucks (or vans) and trailers that have their plates changed once they cross a certain point.
So, it's easy for folks to look and drive by, not even knowing that they're driving right by the living cargo of the city's vampire ruler.
As for Sheriff Velma DuPont's yum-yums, the local indie music scene is where she finds them. Her experience as a music producer certainly helps her to get close to musicians and singers who fit the bill.
Some even think of her as "a pretty cool, sexy, awesome lady" who just might help launch their careers or whatever. So, they like having her around and they open up to her (sometimes).
But, she is still a Kindred (and a Sheriff, too), and the local music scene is small, so it's hard for her to not feed from the same musicians, so she's careful to make sure that she doesn't cross paths with the same peeps too many times in a row lest they get suspicious.
The question does remain: why did the Punks attack the Prince's shipment? Did they know it was connected to him or was this just another Brujah flare-up due to their Clan's Bane? Was this a way to force and twist the Prince's hand in the current "negotiations"?
Either way, Clive's got a lot to answer for tonight, and he's already on thin ice as it is. Prince Antonio's not exactly going to let him off scot-free for this little punchy-punchy escapade.
The only reason Prince Antonio relies upon the Circulatory System to move his "food" around is because his Rarefied Tastes simply cannot be found within Flimont City.
Despite being a city of a million-plus people, nobody seems to fit the bill for having no Rhesus (Rh) factors or antigens in their red cells, so the big cheese has to rely on the Circulatory System and all the issues that come along with that (like frequently changing routes, for example).
It is what it is.
Brock, meanwhile, goes about his Ghoul-related duties as the sun beams down from high in the sky. He meets with the other Tzimisce Ghouls, checks in with them, asks if there's anything they need, and all that.
They all say everything's fine. Most are either concerned or downright indifferent about Galeb's recent disappearance.
Brock nervously wiggles in his seat when the Elder's name is mentioned. His heart beats like a war-drum in his chest. The Ghouls ask if everything is fine, but he reassures them that yes, everything's fine, just peachy!
He then gets up, says his goodbyes, and leaves. He inhales some of that afternoon air, hails a taxi, and asks to be driven back home so he can study, rest, and keep on going.
Brock has some more errands to run (on behalf of the good doctor) and some other people to see. He'll do that later. Right now, he sits on his beanbag, grabs a book on plastic surgery, and flips through the pages. He settles into his studies and tries to absorb as much as he can. He has to keep up.
This is his future over here!
Still, juggling all this as a quasi-mortal (or quasi-immortal, depending on one's perspective) Ghoul can't be easy. The Bond of Blood is quite strong and it is especially stronger for Ghouls like Brock. The stronger the Bond of Blood, the more connected and dependent a Ghoul is on their Domitor.
Brock does get these weird splitting headaches every now and then, but they mostly go away in a few hours. For now, he spends his afternoon deeply immersed in his studies.
He's done what he can for Dr. Collins. He's checked up on most of the other Tzimisce in this Domain (even if only via their Ghouls), so what else is there to do?
Study! Brock does shoot some suggestive text messages to a few cute guys who might be interested, but in light of recent events, he has to tread cautiously.
The last thing he needs is to get caught up in some Lavender Scare-esque sting operation, get thrown in prison for an unspecified amount of time, or be sentenced to some inhumane "treatment" that involves drugs or shock therapy.
His parents planned to do that shit to him.
Brock sighs uneasily and his lips tremble, "Nope. Nuh-uh. N--never again. I just gotta...not be so fucking horny all the time, heh. Yeah, sh--should be easy, right? I can control my...urges." He gets a little twitchy, but he resists.
He doesn't even bother to reply to the guy he's been texting. He just focuses on his studies. There'll be time for the sexy and fun stuff later.
Hopefully.
At the Lancaster mansion...
Marcus stands at front of the mansion. He looks up, shakes his head, and strides inside. He is immediately greeted by his grandfather.
Clarence looks at him with eyes of disdain. He holds a walking stick and is slightly hunched over. The Lancaster family patriarch's stick-holding hand is trembling and the thin man next to him stands close lest Clarence tumbles down to the floor.
Clarence clicks his tongue and begins, "Well, what do you have to say for yourself?! Huh?! Tell me, boy, what do you want?" there is an intense scowl on the old man's face.
Marcus squares his shoulders and resolutely says, "I'm moving out. I'm here to get my things. After that, I'm out. I'm done with this place, done with this shit, and done with you."
Clarence growls and maintains his scowl, "Why, you ungrateful little mulatto. Do you have any idea of the hell you're bringing upon us?!"
He hobbles forward and shakes his head in disgust, "We shoulda aborted you." He says those 4 words with a quiet rage.
Marcus doesn't even flinch. He simply scoffs and heads for the stairs.
Clarence howls out through gritted teeth, "I ain't done with you, boy. Get your ass back over here."
Marcus stops in his tracks and glowers at his grandpa, "What?!"
The old man grunts, groans, and meanders over to him. His attendant follows closely.
Clarence growls, "Your uncle was just here along with those 2 daughters of his."
"So?"
"Hrmfghgrhgh. So? Despite them both being women, they makin' a whole lot more money than you do, boy. $95,000 a year- you're a failure, Marcus. A disgrace to the Lancaster family name, a disgrace to your daddy's name." The old man's voice breaks near the end and there's some real sadness there.
Marcus puts his hand on his forehead and shakes his head, "For Christ's sake!! I'm done with this shit! I'm OUT!"
He turns around and commands his nearby buddies, "Make sure that they load EVERYTHING from my room into those trucks!"
A man with dreadlocks nods and quickly bolts up the wide stairs with a bunch of other dudes.
Clarence shouts up, "And don't let the door hit your ungrateful asses on the way out! And you better not think of stealin' from my place!"
The guys ignore him, and he turns to face his grandson, "Why? Why do you want to leave your own family, Marcus? Hmm?! Your own house that me and your daddy and his brothers built with our own hands!"
Marcus's face contorts and his cheeks puff up as if he's gonna let out a harsh scream, "You know damn well WHY!!" his fists are clenched and his eyes are filled with rage, resentment, and anger.
"Hmmph. Illuminate me, boy."
Marcus gets all up in his grandpa's bidness and pokes the old man with his finger, "Because you're a toxic, narcissistic, egomaniacal asshole, and I want absolutely nothing to do with that shit! Ever! No matter how many times I come over, it's the same old bullshit."
He pauses for a second and adds, "Nothing EVER fucking changes. I'm not the guy you or daddy want me to be. And that's not gonna change, either." He says that with finality.
Clarence shoves his cane into the ground and snaps, "Boy, you best be on your knees, prayin' for forgiveness. I knew you was nothing but trouble from the day your daddy introduced me to that harlot you call your mother."
Upon hearing that, Marcus screams and violently shoves his grandpa down to the ground. He looks down at the old man who has landed on his side, "Shut the fuck up!! You have NO RIGHT to talk about MY MOMMA like that!"
The old man's attendant looks around in a panic, and some of Clarence's other guys rush to him to help him up.
The old man lets out a groan as he is lifted back to his feet. After being helped up, he shoves all them off and barks, "GET YOUR FUCKING HANDS OFF ME!!"
Clarence fixes his robe and mutters, "Goddamn worthless pieces of shit. I never asked to be helped up by nobody. And I don't need nobody's pity!"
He points an accusatory finger at his grandson, "And you! We didn't raise you to act like a--a--a thug or some hooligan from the 'hood, boy!"
"'We?!' Who the fuck is 'we'?! Dad was always off chasing tail while you were too busy running your businesses with an iron fist!" Marcus's eyes are bloodshot and his face is red.
He shakes his head and bitterly scoffs, "You don't care about anybody, you never have, Clarence. All you care about is...is some stupid legacy that ain't gon' happen."
Clarence huffs and heaves. He clutches his chest and winces in pain.
Marcus puts his hands on his hips and turns his back. He closes his eyes, breathes deeply, and sighs, "You're a mean-spirited old man, Clarence. That's it. A bitter and hateful old man, and it ain't gonna change no matter what happens."
He turns to face the old man and gestures around the fancy mansion, "And all this? All this money, fancy shit, imported fixtures...don't mean shit no more."
Marcus jabs his thumb behind him and continues, "I'm new money. I ain't held down by the constraints or so-called standards of old money no more. Ain't you or anybody else gonna tell us how to behave no more--"
He's rudely interrupted by Clarence shouting out, "Boy! I will whoop the white and black outta your ass. If it ain't for my old and achy joints, you'd be sorry as shit." The old man is clearly fuming on the inside, and he ain't done.
Clarence points his cane at Marcus's face, "You better remember that." He shoves the cane at his grandson, causing him to flinch.
The old man then stabs the ground and takes a few deep breaths, "Now, go on. Get your shit and get outta here. You're lucky I don't press charges. Shoving an old, helpless man to the ground- oughta be ashamed of yourself. Goddamn ghetto behavior. You ain't even worthy of the Lancaster family name." He looks down in disgust, his voice breaking and faltering.
Marcus narrows his eyes, his heart sinking as he watches his grandfather in all his hatefulness.
Marcus faintly chuckles and shakes his head. He smugly says, "You don't know. But everyone at last year's Thanksgiving party had a fitting nickname for you."
Clarence scoffs and dismissively waves his hand, "Nonsense. Now you're just trying to get in my head and throw me off balance." He turns to his attendant, "Go get me some water, boy. Quickly!"
"Y--yes, Mr. Clarence, sir." The thin guy bows his head and runs off to fetch some water.
Marcus snorts, "Uncle Ruckus. Heh, yeah. Everyone was callin' you that behind your back at last year's Thanksgiving gathering. I think it was um...Tasha who came up with that nickname."
He lifts his chin and grins slightly, "It fits. It really does."
Clarence simply glowers at his grandson and snarls. One can almost visualize smoke coming out of his nostrils, like some sort of cartoon bull about to charge or something.
However, Clarence just stands there, glowering at his grandson.
Marcus simply turns around and heads up the stairs to make sure that the rest of his things are packed and ready to be loaded onto the trucks.
He stops near the top of the stairs and turns back around. He sighs and says, "Goodbye, grandfather. I wish I could say that--that it was good knowing ya, but I--I just can't. I just can't."
The thin man returns with a glass of water. Clarence snatches it and gulps it all down, "I don't need nobody's pity! You hear me?! I don't need anybody's pity!!!"
His voice is shaking, but he says no more. He simply turns around and hobbles off into the bowels of the Lancaster family mansion, hoping never to see Marcus again.
Marcus takes a deep breath and goes up to his room to watch other people packing his stuff. He ain't lifting no finger! Nope! He stands in a corner and orders the folk around.
The man with dreadlocks stands next to Marcus and lowers his voice, "So, how'd it go?"
Marcus huffs, "It was...whatever. I mean, it was inevitable." He's clearly down, but he's not going to let it show, "Anyways, all good here, Chris?"
Chris looks to be about Marcus's age. He's got long dreadlocks, droopy brown eyes, dark skin, and he's slightly taller than Marcus (but not by much). He's dressed in some white polyester sports outfit with a red stripe.
"Y--yeah," Chris quietly replies.
"What?" Marcus asks, eye narrowed.
Chris shakes his head and chuckles, "Uh, n--no, yeah! It's um--it's all good here! You got a lotta stuff, man. Holy! You sure it's ALL gon' fit in your new place?"
Marcus shrugs, "Dunno. If it doesn't, I'll buy new shit to keep it in, simple as that. I got money, heh."
"You sure you should be antagonizing your granddaddy like that??"
Marcus dismissively scoffs and replies, "Pfft. The fuck was I supposed to do?! Live under his foot till I turned 50 or till he finally kicked the bucket?! Nah, I'm done with this place, Chris..."
Chris jokes, "But you ain't done with that money, though."
Marcus chuckles and folds his arms, "Haha. Yeah, I ain't. When he and dad finally go bye-bye, imma make sure that I inherit the lion's share."
Chris's eyebrows shoot up and he exclaims, "Whoa! Quincy and Tequan ain't gon' be too pleased by that. They'll drag your ass to court and fight you tooth and nail. Not to mention, all your cousins and shit will be there, too."
"Pfft, what they gon' do? Fuck Quincy and fuck Tequan. They might be my so-called 'half-brothers', but I think it's only fair that I get the lion's share of whatever the old man leaves us. He can't take that shit with him to the grave. Nuh-uh. No. Way."
He turns to Chris, "I ain't letting nobody else have my inheritance, what is rightfully due to ME!"
Chris nervously rubs the base of his neck, "How much is it all, anyway?"
A devious smile forms on Marcus's lips and he calmly replies, "Billions. Billions."
Chris gasps and chokes on his spit. He starts coughing.
Marcus puts his hands in his pocket, "Yup. The Lancaster family fortune. It's in the billions."
He casually shrugs and chuckles, "Haha. And I'm about to claim my rightful share. It's only fair cuz of all the shit I've had to put up with over the years. You think I was being a lil' harsh when I confronted the old man, you shoulda tried growing up in this fuckin' place!"
Chris looks around at all the majestic fixtures, marble tiles, the fine china, paintings on the wall, fancy rugs, etc. etc., and whistles, "Damn, son! Too bad we can't airlift chunks of this dope-ass place and attach it to yours, haha!"
"Yup, exactly," Marcus agrees.
He gestures towards a random table in the hallway. It's exquisite, to put it mildly- gold trimming on the sides and a diamond-encrusted vase sits on top of it.
Marcus then gestures around the opulent hallway, "All of this? I just gotta be patient and it'll all fall on my lap soon enough. And then, I'll be 1 of the richest men in all the Midwest."
He licks his lips and folds his arms. His eyes are filled with determination and a new sense of resolve. He says with confidence, "Yup. It's all gonna work out for the best. It has to. The universe owes me for all the shit it put me through."
(If he says so).
In good time, Marcus's stuff is loaded onto 2 huge trucks (he's got a lotta garish, flashy, and expensive crap) and they take off for Marcus's new place.
The afternoon sun relentlessly beams down on the world below as the packers and movers haul stuff up to the 4th floor of Marcus's place.
The Lancaster mansion is a world away, a distant memory, but not completely forgotten. It will surely nag at the young man, but he won't let it show.
Nah, it's all about the future, not the past, for Marcus Lancaster. And it's gonna be a bright one.
Or so he tells himself. But, the future had other (one might be tempted to say radical) plans for the cocky Marcus and his many delusions of grandeur.
The rest of the afternoon is spent moving shit around. Well, as much as possible.
The dcor is a clash between the regal, high-society flair of Marcus's old place and the modern (at least by Y2K standards) aesthetic of the Prairie Ridge Apartments.
He gets some new, comfy, leather furniture that cost more than some cars (not that that's any surprise), a bunch of cool artwork, and some other stuff that one can expect from the scion of a multi-billion-dollar elite cream-of-the-crop family.
All the noise causes consternation amongst the residents. Some chide the packers and movers for the ruckus (like it's their fault somehow), some try to not be affected by any of the hubbub, and others are just too damn tired to be bothered by all of it.
A polished man in his late-30s with combed-back hair approaches Marcus and firmly says, "Mr. Lancaster. As appreciative as we are of your presence here at the Prairie Ridge, the rules clearly stipulate that there may be no noise from--"
Marcus holds up his finger and declares, "You know who I am? You know who my dad is?" Hey, might as well play the dad card, heh.
The apartment association guy aptly guy replies, "Yes, Mr. Lancaster. I do. As a matter of fact, I am a minority shareholder in your father's company."
Marcus dismissively waves his hand, "I don't got nothing to do with my daddy's business."
The association guy faintly smirks, "Be that as it may, the stock and share prices have gone down lately due to the recent deaths of some employees at Lancaster-SYS. Shame."
Marcus sighs and reiterates himself, "Like I said: I don't got nothing to do with my daddy's company. Now, what do you want?"
Association dude gets to the point, "Your downstairs neighbor has lodged a formal complaint against you last night regarding excessive noise. Miss...erm...Lilac was--"
Marcus grunts, "Man, fuck that shawty! I had 1 shindig and she wants to, what, get me thrown out of--"
The apartment association fella interjects, raising a hand, "We have strict rules and policies here at the Prairie Ridge, Mr. Lancaster. There must be NO noise from the times stipulated in the official apartment handbook."
Marcus faintly mumbles, "I'm so tired of livin' under these bullshit rules all the time."
"Well, haha, be that as it may, we have a certain...reputation to uphold here at the Prairie Ridge."
Marcus gesticulates in a vague direction, "Then, why don't you start by clearing out that fucking homeless encampment nearby, huh? I can get the smells from all the way up in my place! It's disgusting!"
"Yes, yes, we've been meaning to- for a while, actually. It's bad for property values and our image here at the Ridge, isn't it? Either way, we've been working on coordinating a removal operation with the FCPD."
"Fuckin' of course it is! And about this so-called 'noise complaint'...if there's a fine, I ain't paying it."
Association fella chuckles, "Haha, oh please, nothing like that, I assure how. However...if you get 3 complaints in a row, you're out. Our rules and policies are VERY strict on these matters."
Marcus's face scrunches in confusion, "What is this?! Some kinda video game?!"
Mr. Association shrugs, "It's the 3-strike system. 'Gamey' in a certain way, I suppose. Like I said: we have a certain reputation and image to uphold here at the Ridge. We can't have the wrong kinds of people taking up space in our luxurious apartments, wouldn't you concur, Mr. Lancaster?"
Marcus shoves his hands in his pockets, "Hmphhrf. Imma go down and talk to that...what's her name again?"
"It's Mauve Lilac, I believe. Strange name and definitely not our usual type here at the Ridge, but the payments from her end are always on time. I would personally recommend NOT going down and speaking to her."
"Why?"
"Well, for starters, she doesn't answer the door in the morning- don't ask why. We value our privacy here at the Ridge. Secondly, she barely takes part in...anything going on here. I hosted a rooftop BBQ a few weeks ago. Everyone was invited, but the occupant of 303 saw fit to...not show up."
Marcus remarks, "She looked kinda crazy when I saw her. I guess it's better chicks like that keep to themselves."
"Hm. Well, as long as she has the money, she can be as 'crazy' or 'kept-to-herself' as she wants. That's usually how it goes around here, Mr. Lancaster."
Marcus gets annoyed, "Tch, please. Don't 'Mr. Lancaster' me. My name's Marcus."
The Association dude plainly smiles, "Well, Marcus, I'll let you off with a warning...this time. I'm not saying don't have parties in the future, no, no, no, by all means, knock yourself out! Just color within the lines is all we ask of you."
Marcus shrugs a shoulder, "I guess I can do that."
They chat for a short while about little things of no great importance, exchange quick pleasantries, and go on their merry ways.
It's not long before afternoon gives way to evening. The sun begins to set, and the city is slowly being shrouded in darkness. It's almost serene. Almost. It's a beautiful moment of transition in a city clogged up with cars and honking horns.
The sun sets and a new night is born. It's still quite hot outside and the air is stale. Traffic congestion begins to build up as mortals begin to rush home from work, the usual.
A few stop to get their dinner from fast food joints and restaurants, which are open for very long hours. It's all part of the rhythm of the (still-young) night.
Prince Antonio Black awakens from his day-sleep. He slowly rises from his double bed, throws the thick blanket off, and begins to walk around his bedroom.
The Ventrue Prince's face is still as hard as it ever was, but it does soften up a bit when he sees the pictures of his kids and his late wife.
He looks up at the framed painting and remarks, "We've come a long way from Sicily. A long time, too...and I'm still here, in charge of this place."
He stares off into the distance, remembering the old times. He remembers the time (in the very distant past) when he and a 100 (or so) other Ventrue (and their Ghouls) were on that boat bound for the so-called "New World".
The Sicilian Ventrue had sent about a 100 of their own, along with plenty of mortals (as food, mostly). They all sailed over the sea to a new land, where they were supposed to have a new beginning.
Prince Antonio was just a mortal back then, his pregnant wife and kids coming along with him on this voyage. The ship ride was hell. Many Frenzied, a lot more perished, and some were just REALLY seasick.
By the time the ill-fated ship got to America, there were only about 50 souls remaining. There were a LOTTA exsanguinated corpses and piles of ashes beneath the deck.
They were given land and told to work the land and prosper. And so, they did, albeit in a very limited capacity. It wasn't long before Antonio got Embraced into the Clan of Kings; his mortal family continued on, having kids and grandkids of their own as time flew by.
Due to the Masquerade, Antonio had to distance himself from his family (and their eventual descendants). He got so busy and involved with the Ventrue politicking in America that he sort of forgot about his family as time rolled on.
The Prince's Haven is a luxurious and spacious mansion with marble flooring, fancy chandeliers, and other lavish trappings. The walls are lined with various portraits and art pieces, and the decor is clearly high-class to the max.
It's all about the Old-World flair to him, with a bit of the "Old Country" thrown in. Still, he does have the latest-model appliances, but they're mostly there for show or for the mortals who serve on the Prince's staff.
They're not really used that much. What's the Blue Blood gonna do with a toaster?
It's pretty quiet here, the distant sounds of the city not reaching this far out. The air is warm, the night is calm, and the lights come on automatically at sunset.
The Prince's brow furrows and his eyes dart around. He has a lot to think about, a lot to reflect on.
He steps into a bathtub, disrobes, and lies there for a good few minutes. The warm and bubbly water comforts his dead nerves and soothes his soul. He lets out a deep sigh.
A while later, Prince Antonio emerges from the tub and dons a bathrobe. He puts on some cologne and steps out of the room, his bare feet lightly tapping the marble floor.
He saunters over to his walk-in closet and picks a beige suit, black shirt, and a brown tie. He begins to dress himself. It's always nice to look sharp, after all.
It's all about the image to the Patricians.
He sits down and begins to run a comb through his hair. After that, he approvingly nods at his reflection in the long mirror. From there, he heads downstairs to the larger-than-Unlife living room.
The lights are dimmed, and the windows are all closed. The living room is very tasteful, decorated, and practically spotless. The Prince rubs 2 fingers across a leather couch and nods.
He steps over to a fancy mahogany table, puts a phone to his ear, and dials a number on his rotary phone. It rings for a few seconds before the other line is picked up.
Sheriff Velma answers, "It's bad. Real bad. Something happened and it requires our immediate attention. I'll be there shortly." She hangs up without saying goodbye.
Prince Antonio's eyes narrow and he mutters, "Ach, great. What now, huh?" he paces around and bites on his thumb. He feels his Hunger. It's almost overwhelming, but he tries to ignore and suppress it for now.
His face softens and he looks off into the distance. He can hear the faint sounds of the vehicles in the distance, and the noises of people within his mansion shuffling about, cleaning, polishing, dusting tables, and so on.
He closes his eyes and listens, focusing his senses. There are the sounds of water running in the kitchen and the faint noises of the fridge humming.
He walks over to another table and picks up a letter he had recently received. It's from some teenage girl named Molly Black (!). She claims to be a distant relative of the Prince and that this letter she's writing to him is part of her school assignment.
Molly went on about how she went about finding her roots using the computers at her school in this little town called Greenridge, and how her family had roots in Sicily or some such.
She also went on about how she was very interested in finding out more about her distant relative, provided he is the right guy. She goes on and on about other things relating to her upbringing, her town, and what have you.
The Prince indifferently tosses the letter aside and shrugs, "Ah, she's not getting a reply."
A wise choice, perhaps. Then again, if some small-town kid with a public-school computer can track down a fairly elusive guy like Prince Antonio, who knows who else might be able to do the same?
The many forces of the Second Inquisition monitor a lot on these nights. Various Orgs and factions are undoubtedly lurking in the shadows, preying (or waiting to be preyed upon).
It's the price of being in a position of power. The Ventrue Prince looks at his fancy Rolex watch and his eyes narrow, "Hrmf. Where the fuck is she?!"
The exterior of the Ventrue's Haven is all brick and stone, with a large, iron gate that is kept locked. The grounds are manicured and lush, with bushes and trees dotted around the lawn.
There are no signs of any obvious security cameras, but one can never be too careful. The place looks quite grandiose even from the outside!
Sheriff Velma DuPont rolls up to the front gate in her sleek red Mustang convertible. She honks and looks up at the CCTV camera above her. She impatiently taps her fingers on the steering wheel.
Her hair is done in her usual up-do, and she's wearing a long black trench coat. She's got a shiny pearl necklace, cherry-red lipstick, diamond earrings, and red-tinted sunglasses.
A buzzing noise is followed by the iron gate opening up. Sheriff Velma puts on her sunglasses and speeds through the gate, stopping right in front of the giant, ornate front door.
She gets out of her car and approaches the front door. Prince Antonio is already standing outside, his arms on either side of his body and a look of mild annoyance on his face.
He's the first to speak, "Talk to me, Velma."
Sheriff Velma pushes her shades up and gets straight to the point, "Your Brujah buddies had a bit of a flare up and wrecked your latest shipment. I don't know the full details yet, but it's a problem, a big one. Bad news."
Prince Antonio's face contorts and his jaw twitches. He swears under his breath and faintly growls, "Fuckin' Anarchs. I knew trusting them was a bad idea. They're gonna pay for this, oh they will. Nobody crosses me and gets away with it. Nobody!"
Sheriff Velma frowns and says, "Either way, we'll need to address this soon. From what I've heard, that crazy British brick shithouse Clive was somehow involved. I don't know exactly how he's involved in this just yet, but it can't be good."
Prince Antonio snarls, "Goddamn, what the hell has gotten into these fuckin' Punks, huh?"
He paces around and muses, "Is it because of the entrance fee? Are these clowns trying to force my hand in these negotiations, huh?! Well, I tell ya what, I might increase the asking price now! 2 million dollars!"
Sheriff Velma stifles a sigh, "I--uh...I don't think that's wise. In all fairness, 1 million dollars itself is quite a big ask. Adding another million to the demand is only going to make things worse for us, and you know how Brujah act when they're backed into a corner."
Prince Antonio shakes his head and grumbles, "This is unacceptable, Velma! T--Tell me you at least found out where my Vessels went?" there's desperation in his dead eyes.
Sheriff Velma shrugs and shakes her head, "Honestly, I'm not sure. The vehicle was all smashed-up."
She takes off her sunglasses and holds them up against the moonlight, "I'm still trying to figure out the next move. Maybe you could hire somebody to track the cargo down? I'll do what I can from my end, but if those guys are hiding, I'm not sure what else we can do."
With some resignation in her tone, she adds, "I mean, it was a shitshow, as you can probably imagine. We're dealing with the aftermath right now. That's why I came here so quickly- to brief you, so that you can make a decision."
Prince Antonio sighs in frustration and mumbles, "At least I have my emergency stashes around this city. I hate having to hit 'em, but..."
He sighs again, his hands clasping his neck, "I'll...I'll work on something."
Sheriff Velma points out, "With all due respect, Flimont City is a city of a million plus people. Finding your runaway Vessels won't be an easy task, and with the cops out in full force--"
The Prince rudely interrupts her with a raised hand, "Yeah, yeah, I get it, Velma, I get it. I'll think of something. But we can't just sit here and let these goddamn Rebels do as they fuckin' please. If they want a seat at my table, then I want my money. Capeesh?"
"Hm. Either way, you can't just let this slide. You want me to bring Clive in with a piece of wood sticking out of his chest? Just say the word and I'll do it. Gladly."
Prince Antonio shakes his head and snickers a little, "No, no. Bring him in, but without the wood sticking outta his chest, heh. I need to have words with him."
He goes on to command her, "Bring him back here if you have to. If he won't come quietly, then just talk to him at whatever dump he's at. Get to the bottom of this. Capeesh?"
"Hm. Yeah."
The Blue Blood then calls his Sheriff over and hands her this letter from Molly. He hands it to her and asks for her "professional opinion" on the matter.
She reads through it, eyes darting around the paper, and remarks, "Well, this definitely spells trouble for you. You want me to go over to Greenridge and take care of it? Personally?" Every syllable uttered is nothing short of ominous.
Prince Antonio is taken aback, and he raises both eyebrows in surprise, "What?! NO! She's just a fucking kid, Velma! Not some Thin-Blood! I wanted to know what you thought about it, not whether or not you were gonna go over there and kill her! For Christ's sake, she's...family."
Sheriff Velma's eyes narrow, "Family that managed to find you. As Sheriff, it is my duty to uphold the Masquerade--"
"Don't educate me on the Traditions, OK? I know 'em already. Either way, I have no interest in replying to the kid."
Sheriff Velma cracks a small smile, "That's a wise choice."
The Prince glares at her, "Yeah, yeah, I have my reasons."
(Some of those reasons are more apparent than others).
Sheriff Velma blandly asks, "Do you...still keep in touch with any of your mortal relatives or descendants?"
Prince Antonio scoffs, "Pfft. No. This letter was out of the blue for me. I mean, I might know a few people who are...related to me. We have no connection whatsoever. They have no ties to me and don't owe me anything. Best part is, I don't owe 'em, too!"
Sheriff Velma looks around her fellow Ventrue's Haven, "Hmm. Same here. I keep away from my sisters and their many grandchildren. DuPont women were always too...laid-back for me."
Prince Antonio asks, "DuPont, huh? I never did ask, but any relation to that chemical company of the same last name as yours?"
The Sheriff emphatically answers, "NO. We're the DuPonts, as in the family composed of musicians, music producers, and so on. We're French on my mother's side, I think. Not that I would even care about something like that, anyways."
The Prince grins, "Haha. Sure, sure. Now, go on. Scram. Find me that Brujah and make sure he comes quietly or talks. Either way, I don't want a mess on my streets."
Sheriff Velma bows her head slightly, "As you wish. It'll take a while, though. Traffic's out in full force again and this city turns into a fucking maze for snails when that happens. It's awful!"
Prince Antonio replies, "Well, I ain't payin' you by the hour, Velma."
She gets the hint, turns on her heel, and strides back over to her car. She doesn't drive off right away, instead checking her hair and makeup in her rearview mirror.
The Prince is still in the doorway and he's watching her intently, "Hmmph. I give her a wide berth to do her thing. She's been good for these past 5 decades. Here's to another 5...or 10...or more, heh heh!"
Sheriff Velma starts up her car, the engine roaring to life, and she begins her journey through the mean and congested streets of F-City! She's gonna go out and about, looking for a muscular British Brujah, and hopefully get to the bottom of last night's events.
Elsewhere, in an abode far humbler...
Diego steps out from the shower, a towel wrapped around his waist. The Gangrel proceeds to dry himself and gets dressed.
He's clad in a button-down shirt, slacks, and some fancy scuffed work boots.
Marisol does the top buttons of her silk shirt and adjusts her collar. She then puts on some light makeup, a look of uncertainty on her sallow face.
Diego asks his girlfriend, "Hey, what's up? You look down. Work again? Any word on those layoffs?"
Marisol applies some mascara and weakly replies, "Yeah. Oscar and a few others got let go last night."
Diego gasps, "Oh, no. Not Oscar! Damn! He was a good homie, y'know. Who else?"
Marisol pauses for a second, her eyes fixated on the lipstick tube in front of her, "Uh...Marty, Zach, Ellie, and Scott."
"Shit! And how are they doing? They need any help from us?"
Marisol sighs and quickly applies her lipstick. She smacks her lips a few times, "Not good. They're not taking it too well, D. I wish that we could help, but we're not exactly doing too great ourselves."
Diego's shoulders slump and he sighs deeply, "Yeah. Maybe we can buy 'em dinner when things start to settle down? Or something. I just wanna help them."
"Hmm. Well, it's worth a try. I feel sorry for them, D. Some of them were living hand-to-mouth. I know Scott was homeless and living out of his sister's car. Ellie recently lost custody of her kid after her DUI charge. I don't how any of them are going to cope now. This job was--was all they had."
Diego puts his cold hand on her shoulder, "We'll try our best to support them in whatever way we can."
Marisol puts her cold hand on his and forces a smile, "We will. But--never mind. Sorry. I have to go to work now. This job, I need it more than anything, D."
Diego nods in understanding and gives her a quick peck on the cheek, "Yeah. Remember: if things get bad, I have no issues looking for more stable work. I don't care what it is, I'll do anything. Anything for us, mi corazon."
Marisol sniffs and holds back tears of blood, "Thank you, Diego. Really. In these 4...short years we've been together, you've been nothing but supportive and understanding. I--I love you, D."
Diego smiles at her, "And I love you a lot more, chica. Don't you worry, we'll be fine. We're both survivors. We're Gangrel. We're tough as they come and we've been through a lot of bad shit. You're all that matters to me, Marisol."
Marisol looks around her Haven and wistfully adds, "And you're all that matters to me, D. And this Haven, too. At least we have mi abuela's house, so we don't have to worry about paying rent or any of that shit."
Diego's eyes glimmer a bit and he smiles, "Yeah! It's gonna be our home for a really long time to come. Maybe even forever!"
Marisol faintly chuckles at that, "I hope so, D. The housing situation in this city...it's not that great. We should be grateful--"
Tears of blood begin to flow down her cheeks and her voice cracks, "We should be grateful that mi abuela let us have a roof over our heads, D. I love you. I--I miss her so much, Diego. I--"
Diego pulls his girlfriend into a tight embrace, "Shh, shh, shh. Easy, easy. I love you, too. We'll be OK."
He kisses the top of her head and she leans in, sniffing.
She softly asks, "Will we survive this?" the sanguine tears continue to flow down her face.
Diego firmly replies, "Yeah. We will. I promise."
The 2 Ferals hold each other, and they say no more.
After a few minutes, Marisol redoes her makeup, checks her clothes, grabs her things, and gets on her scooter. She starts it up and drives off to work.
Diego stands in the doorway and watches her leave. He's worried, and the same can be said for Marisol. She'll grab a warm body on the way.
The night is dark, and Markham stands next to the Feral, watching the scooter get further and further away. The Feral's eyes are transfixed on his girlfriend.
The 2 Kindred are silent for a moment.
The Feral turns to the Baali and asks, "So, how are things going, d-man?"
Markham plainly replies, "All good, Diego. I don't intend to stay long. Once I'm done, I'll be out of here."
Diego chuckles at that, "Yeah. I'm gonna miss you, hermano. When you go back to Seattle, promise to keep in touch with your ol' pal?" he has a somewhat expectant look on his face.
Markham nods and answers, "Sure."
"Cool," Diego says. He's still not convinced. He knows that Markham is still withdrawn and cold, but he's been warming up over these past few nights.
He turns to Markham, "You sure everything's OK, homes? You got that...look on your face. Only Gringos like you could pull it off. That 'I'm-thinking-about-a-lotta-shit' kinda look, hahaha!"
Markham turns his gaze heavenwards, his gray eyes piercing the night. His mind is elsewhere; his thoughts are racing to and fro.
He says nothing for a moment, before saying, "Yes. Everything's fine. I've decided on something. I just need to approach it the right way and not rush into it."
Diego looks up at the night sky and shrugs, "Hmm. As Gangrel, we do like rushing into shit every now and then, hahaha! So, what is it that you've decided upon...if you don't mind me asking?"
Markham's jaw tightens, "I've decided to set up a meeting between myself and Luciano Donovan Junior...and Paul Cho, too. Hm."
Diego's eyebrows shoot up, "Whoa! The same busters who tried to 'off' you? You sure that's wise, ese? I mean, you are gonna have 2 mortals who put out a hit on your head! And we already know those assassinos don't play around."
The Baali responds, "I'll set the meeting in a public place. That way, those 2 won't try anything funny."
"You want me as backup?"
Markham firmly, but not rudely, replies, "No, Diego. This is my investigation, my case. I don't want you getting caught up in this mess and getting hurt or worse. You're a good man, and I don't want you to get in any trouble. It's best that you don't get involved, even if you are a...friend."
Diego's eyes do light up at that last part, "Friend, huh? Well, I'll take it, man. But are you sure you'll be OK handling them? If you're not comfortable, I'll go with you."
Markham's eyes narrow, "Yes. Once I set the meeting spot, I'll just need you to drop me off. I can handle the rest from there."
Burt's van comes screeching down the road and he parks it near the driveway. The driver's door flies open, and the rock star jumps out of the van, some blood on near his chin and mouth.
Markham's Sire is dressed in a button-down, leopard-patterned shirt, worn chinos, and sandals. He's also got some eyeliner on and is wearing a lot of cheap and tacky roadside jewelry.
He slings his guitar case over his shoulder and nods over at Diego and Markham, "Hey, rock stars! Crazy night, huh? Traffic in this place is something else."
Markham is slightly taken aback by his Sire's sudden appearance, but he hides his surprise well. He points out, "You got blood on your face, Burt."
Burt chuckles and licks his lips, "Oh, this? Yeah, it got messy. I didn't kill her- thankfully- but I'm pretty sure she knew what I was and wanted me to keep sucking her dry."
He rubs his fingers across the blood on his chin, "Ah, crazy. So, what's going on with you 2? Any plans for tonight? I thought we could hang out, play us some tunes, and have a good talk. I really did enjoy our last chat, y'know?"
Markham excludes himself from this, "I got some work to take care of. You and Diego could chill out together, though."
Burt playfully punches his Childe's arm, "Ah, c'mon, rock star. Spend a little time with your Sire. Besides, tonight's my last night. After this, I'm back on the road again. I'm done with this city. I...wouldn't rate it too highly."
Diego's expression falls, "What?! So soon? Already? Aww, c'mon, homes, we was just getting to know each other! You can't leave already!"
Burt winces a bit and explains himself, "I got something, someone, I gotta track down. I got a few solid leads. This is important to me, Diego. Why don't we go inside, and I can tell you and rock star here all about it, huh, what do you say?"
Markham sighs softly and concedes to spending some time with his Sire, "OK, fine. I can only spare a few minutes, Burt."
The 3 vampires head back into the house and talk about a whole bunch of things. Burt pulls out his guitar and begins to gently strum the strings, while Markham and Diego sit next to him and listen.
Diego clasps his hands together and inquires, "So, what is this 'important' thing you're gonna do, Burt? Are you gonna, what, hit the road and hit more of the clubs or something? Maybe restart your career?"
Burt shakes his head, "No, not exactly. Restart my career? Well, I was thinking of something, y'know, fashioning my legacy as a sort of comeback kid by coming back onto the rock 'n' roll scene in the year 2010. Maybe even re-releasing a few old albums of mine."
Markham dryly remarks, "2010's a...long way off, Burt. And with how ubiquitous technology is, doing a comeback after all these decades is kinda risky."
Burt presses his lips into a thin line and nods, "Well, you make good points there, kiddo. Still, I think it's kinda possible. Anyway, that's not even something I'm remotely worried about now, no..."
He pauses and plucks a few strings on his guitar, before saying, "No, it's the other thing. Remember, Markham?"
Markham's eyes narrow, "No? Not exactly? Remember what?"
Diego leans forward, curious to know what Burt's ambitions really are.
Burt playfully smirks and chuckles, "Ah, you really don't, huh? Remember when you were just a Fledgling sitting out on my porch, sipping bags of watered-down o-negative and we were talking about your new existence? Remember any of that, kiddo?"
Markham nods, "I do. I remember. Bits and pieces. Most of it...was buried under all that--that other stuff."
Burt smiles at his Childe sympathetically, "Well, remember what we talked about back then?"
Markham answers, "A lot. You gave me an Unlife 101. The Beast, our Bloodline, the other Clans, the Sects, the Masquerade, the whole shebang. Yeah, I remember. I hope you're not planning on a pop quiz here, Burt."
Burt leans back in his seat, laughs, and strums his guitar, "Hahahahahahah! Oh, no, nothing like that. As long as you still remembered the basics, then I did my job as your Sire. Nah, do you remember the...other thing that I spoke to you about?"
Markham looks away from his Sire, and his fingers tap against the side table, "Uh--I...I'm not sure. Even now, it's all still so foggy, Burt. I don't know why it's like that."
Diego clicks his tongue and winces, "Damn! That was truly some traumatizing shit you went through, huh, hermano?"
Burt says, "Ah, yeah, it was. Let's--let's not talk about it. Anyways, here's the gist of it..."
So, Burt has ambitions to join this Sect known as the Inconnu. They are an extremely secretive Sect of Kindred, and virtually nothing is known about them other than the fact that they renounce the Eternal Struggle and are said to be manipulating the other major Sects from behind the scenes.
Others claim they're tied to the Antediluvians, whilst others say their main goal is the pursuing of Golconda (sorta like vampire Nirvana, basically).
Burt explains, "There's no Inconnu office that I can just walk into and ask to join, haha! Over the many decades, I've clearly expressed my interests, but I got frustrated of waiting around for an invite."
As a result, he took (very) drastic and daring measures. He managed to stake a very high-level Agent of the Inconnu and abduct the body.
Down in Burt's basement, there's a staked body of that Agent. Burt showed the still body to his Childe and laid out his plans.
"Generation is a big deciding factor in joining the ranks of the Inconnu. I'm 7th Generation, just 1 Generation off from the set limit of 6th Gen or older. That guy's body is my ticket in."
Burt strums his guitar, and there's a sadness in his eyes.
Diego takes some time to piece what Burt has told him together. He gasps loudly, eyes widened in shock and horror, "You--you're gonna Diablerize that buster????"
Burt smirks and blandly says, "Yes. What of it? Is there a problem, Diego?"
Diego's voice cracks as he says, "Y--yes! I mean, n--no? I mean, that's so crazy, man!"
Burt elaborates, "Yeah, that clown down in my basement is a 6th Gen Setite. I would've Diablerized him years ago, but he'd just take over and that'd be the end of me. We can't have that now, can we?"
Markham has his cheek on his knuckles, and he's staring off into space, "Hmm."
Burt goes on, "But, no, I've got word of a special and magical dagger that's said to make Diablerie a whole lot easier. That's what I've been tracking these past few nights. Last I heard, a bunch of fucking no-good Sabbat cultists have that dagger box in their possession."
Diego leans forward, "Oh. Well, that's bad, man, but you've got something figured out, right?"
Burt nods confidently, "Yep! I lost their trail sometime back, but I know where they're heading. All I need is gas in my tank and enough money to take me around."
He goes on, "So, tonight's gonna be my last night in this city. After a few gigs tonight, I'm outta here. I might stop by and visit that Farooq guy that Markham here told me about- always good to see a fan out in the wild."
There's a longing look on Burt's pale face and he misses a few notes, "I'm not nostalgic by any means, but I do miss all the times I had with my groupies. Y'know, it was really wild back then."
He strums the strings on his guitar, and the sadness on his face intensifies, "I'll just be happy knowing I have a chance at joining the Order of the Inconnu. I know I have what it takes to be 1 of them."
Markham is still looking off into the distance while Diego is listening to the Baali rock star with rapt attention.
The rock star sighs and mutters, "Ah, well. Hey, Diego? Any song requests? Anything at all. You name it and I likely knew the songwriter in person, haha!"
The Gangrel states, "You should really think about that comeback kid thing, man! Plenty of busters would be lining up to see you work your magic again!"
Burt softly chuckles and waves a dismissive hand, "Ah, well, there's nothing I wanna do about it right now. Like Markham said: 2010's a long way off. All this new technology shows some kinda potential. I could try working with someone to get my music released digitally and stuff like that."
Diego thinks for a moment and then nods, "Yeah, that sounds like it could work. It might attract some attention from the bad guys, but eh...a little 'living-on-the-edge' is good every now and then."
Burt concurs, "Absolutely, just a little bit, however. And if you ever wanna get into this line, remember 1 thing."
Diego looks on with expectation. Even Markham sits up and pays attention.
Burt lifts his finger and warns the 2, "Nothing in this country destroys an artist faster than success. I know that firsthand. I let it get to my head, and it all came crashing down when those Sabbat maniacs unleashed hell upon me back in Greenridge."
He turns his head aside and gulps deeply. The Demon blinks a few times, "Anyways, uh...the point is, try not to let things get to your head, OK? The best and safest path is to keep doing what you're doing and live in the moment. Always try to aspire to speak to the broader concerns of the world. Remember that."
Diego nods, "Yeah, I get you. I'll remember that, homes. If I ever do get into it, I'll always keep that up in here," he taps the side of his head and smiles. "And always down here too," he points at his still heart.
Burt smiles from ear to ear, "I'm glad to hear that, Diego. A rock star's only as good as their next gig; that's also something you gotta keep in mind."
Markham gets up and excuses himself, "OK, I'll leave you 2 to it, then. Burt, goodbye. I guess. And thanks for putting my mind at ease. It was...eating away at me- not being able to remember wh--what happened that night."
Burt gets up and pulls his Childe in for a hug, "Hey, hey, hey, no worries, rock star. I'm glad I could help. If we don't ever see each other again for a long time, just know that I'm proud of you, alright? And never forget that."
Markham looks into his Sire's wild amber eyes, and the 2 embrace for a long time.
Burt breaks off and advises Markham, "You're doing good work at the SEC, right? I hope you can keep up that good work for many, many years to come."
Markham responds, "Thanks. I'm not planning on quitting, not until the job's done, anyway. After that, I'm not so sure. I've already been there for a long time and I'm starting to think that some of my coworkers might be getting suspicious of me not exactly aging."
Burt looks around, "Hmm. You're a smart guy, you'll figure something out, won't you? For now, enjoy the night and enjoy the company of your friend. He's been a good host to you, never forget that, OK?"
Markham looks at Diego and acknowledges all that the Feral has done for him over these past few nights. There's a hint of genuine gratitude on the Baali's pale face.
Diego does a thumbs-up and grins, "Anytime, homes! And thank you, Burt, for all the kindness and advice."
Markham says goodbye to his Sire and departs to the kitchen. He pulls out his laptop, plugs the charger in, locates the dusty ethernet cable and plugs that into his device, and then boots it up.
He spends the next few minutes sending an email to some coworkers and higher-ups, updating them on the progress of the investigation into LDJ and P-Money and saying how he's doing great (so far, it's not much, but it's a start).
While this is going on, Diego and Burt continue to talk with each other. They get along really well, and the Feral is eager to hear more about this Baali rock star's many adventures and the wild tales he has to share.
Raucous laughter, cheering, and guitar-strumming is heard throughout the evening. It's a short night before Burt has to go, but it's a good and memorable one.
An hour or so later...
Diego exhales and lets out a sharp whistle, "Wow, what a guy. What. A. Guy. Too bad we can't stay in touch. Man, I hope he does OK and gets all that he wants. He's a true rock star in my book. Even the way he talks and dresses...is--is so cool!"
Markham wraps up with his work and shuts his laptop, "Mm-hmm. He's got that effect on people, that's for sure. So, what's the plan now?"
The Outlander shrugs, "You got a place you need to be at, homes? You set up that meeting spot with those 2 pendejos yet?"
The Baali shakes his head, "Nope. Why don't we head out now? Neither of us have fed and I'm feeling a bit...hungry. Might as well find ourselves a warm body and you know all the good spots around here."
Diego is up for it, and the 2 Kindred leave the house and step out into the warm night breeze. They get in the pickup truck and Diego starts it up. It roars to life and the 2 are rolling down the streets in no time!
The Gangrel decides to take Markham to a nearby diner. There are a lot of alleyways and dark corners for the 2 bloodsuckers to hunt around. A lotta nooks and crannies to be found around this city, it would seem.
The 2 Kindred drive down the congested roads, and they see a few cars and trucks on the road. Diego turns on the radio, and some Spanish rap music starts to play.
Markham's eyes are transfixed on the outside world. He remains silent and deep in contemplation. His Hunger gnaws at him, but he has many other things on his mind right now.
Sating the eternal needs of the Beast within, however, is a must if he hopes to get anything done.
The duo soon pull up near a diner that has a large neon sign outside. There are some people sitting outside on scratched benches, and a couple of old men are smoking while having a heated discussion.
The pickup truck comes to a stop and Markham gets out. Diego points to the diner, "Not inside. Outside is where it's at. Lemme find a better parking spot, and I'll show you what I mean, aight?"
Markham plainly nods and shoves his hands deep in the pockets of his long trench coat. He stares out at the road ahead and waits patiently. Diego drives off to park his vehicle.
The surroundings are...quite deprived judging by the look of things. The diner's neon sign is flickering and the place inside appears quite empty, save for a few patrons sitting at their tables and talking amongst themselves.
It's not a place frequented by people from the upper echelon, then. Markham gazes at the old men outside and a few other passers-by. The area around is badly lit, the streetlamps either broken or falling apart.
The pavement is cracked and there are a few tents (for unhoused folk with nowhere else to go) scattered about, here and there. A few needles and generic-looking pill bottles are found near the overflowing trash cans.
Urban decay.
The scent of dog piss and other less-than-pleasant odors permeate the air. It's not exactly the most salubrious of neighborhoods. Deprived and willfully forgotten by the powers-that-be, it would seem.
There's a heavy cop presence on the periphery, and Markham spots them from the corner of his eye. The swine are holding their assault rifles, a very stiff look on their faces. A few even have bulletproof vests on.
He knows they're watching everyone closely, and the thought that they might catch him in the act of feeding is ever present in the back of his mind.
Moments later, Diego comes walking over, spinning his keys around his finger. He sees the Baali, "Welcome to the REAL Flimont City, homes! If the news ever talks about it, it's either to moralize or scare those suburban Gringos shitless. Hmph."
"Hmm, yeah. Sensationalism seems to be winning over facts these nights, Diego," the Baali replies. He has a stern look on his face.
He turns to the Gangrel and gives him a look, "So, you know a spot around here?"
The Feral grins and beckons to a tight alleyway, "Follow me. Take your pick and remember: no killing nobody. We don't need that shit on our consciences, right?"
"Absolutely."
The alleyway in question is rather narrow. Flies buzz about and hazy smoke permeates the air. The asphalt is cracked and worn away. A dumpster is at the end of the alley, and there's graffiti scribbled onto the brick walls.
There are a few folks, milling about and hanging around in the alleyway. They're huddled together, their eyes barely open, some about to stick needles in their arms. A few of them are talking, but they're all too tired to make coherent sentences.
Markham feels pity for these people, but his Beast impels him to just lunge forward at the nearest unfortunate sucker and sink his fangs into their neck. The warm blood coursing through their body would be a stimulant for his eternal thirst and fill him with delicious pleasure unlike any other.
It's an...alluring idea, but Markham remains composed and uses his Obfuscate Discipline to blend in with the darkness and lurk in the shadows of the alleyway. He's so close, so close, the blood beckons him, but he holds back.
Diego makes a strange whistling sound and beckons someone to approach him. His fangs pop out, and he bites down into the neck of a middle-aged woman, who's wearing a flimsy shirt, shorts, and cheap high-heeled sandals.
She yelps in surprise and fear, but her eyes gloss over and her voice goes husky, "Mmm..." she accepts the Kiss, a faint smile dancing on her rugged face, and her legs buckle.
Markham spots an older man rubbing his hands and muttering incoherently, his eyes wide open and darting about in the darkness. His mouth is agape. Markham silently moves close, puts a hand over the old guy's mouth, and bites him on the neck.
The Demon immediately feels a rush of life flood through him. The Beast be eatin' good tonight!
The old man tries to struggle, but Markham's grip is too strong, and the mortal is too weak to resist. After a short moment, the old man slumps over in Markham's arms. He's unconscious, and he won't wake up for at least a few minutes.
Before gently dropping the fella to the ground, Markham licks the wound shut and checks to make sure that the mortal is still alive. He's still breathing, so that's...acceptable.
The Baali then checks himself. He dusts some dirt off his clothing and goes over to Diego, who has just finished licking the fang-puncture wound on his victim's neck. She's still breathing, although a faint moaning sound escapes her mouth.
She's humming in a haze, and it looks as if she's just snapped out of a very pleasant dream.
Diego sucks some air through his teeth and silently leaves her be. The 2 Kindred emerge from the alleyway, revitalized and full of energy, ready to face the (many) challenges of the night ahead.
Markham takes a good look around, "So, what's next?"
Diego shrugs, "I believe you have a meeting to set with 2 spoilt rich brats?"
"Hm. Yeah. You wouldn't...happen to know where either Luciano Donovan Junior or Paul Cho live at, by any chance?"
The Gangrel shakes his head and mirthlessly chuckles, "Nah, man, sorry. Maybe it's 1 of them areas where you'll find all those rich Gringos. Plenty of places like that in this crazy city."
The Baali exhales and turns his attention to a nearby payphone. There's a massive phonebook next to the rusty box. He'll just need to browse through it to find LDJ's phone number and address.
The Baali goes towards the payphone and browses through the phonebook, while Diego paces around and whistles a tune. The Feral spots a woman in her early-20s.
She's got long, flowing red hair and chocolate-brown eyes. She's profusely sweating and holding what appears to be a map, but upside down. She looks so flustered and out of place.
Diego, being the helpful buster that he is, approaches her, "You lost, err--"
The redhead gasps at him and almost drops her map, "Oh! No, no, no, it's OK, I--I'm fine."
She sighs deeply and shakes her head, "Nope, no, I'm lost, I'm sooooo lost."
Diego warmly smiles and puts her at ease, "Hey, it happens. You're not from around here, huh? Name's Diego, by the way. You uh...got nice red hair, if you don't mind me saying that. That's rare around these parts. So, where you headed to?"
The redhead scratches the back of her head and introduces herself, "Hi, Diego. I'm M--Maya. I'm just sorta here in this big city, um...never mind. I'm trying to find the nearest B&B around here. You have that here, right?"
Firstly, Diego slowly takes her map and sets it right, much to the flustered embarrassment of the redhead. She's now seeing a map that has the right-side facing up.
He then directs her to a corner of the map, "Hm, yeah, no, you're near here. Just keep walking a few blocks, take this turn, and you'll be at the closest we do have to a B&B in this city. This city's confusing, and always, ALWAYS, look 4 times before crossing, alright?"
Maya nervously chuckles, "Um...s--sure thing. And thanks. This city is so...huge and--and confusing. I'm uh...more of a small-town gal myself, y'know?"
"I'm a big-city boy, haha!"
Maya laughs and mutters, "Well, anyway, I'm really, really grateful for your help. Um, Diego, right? If I ever meet do get lost in this city, what's the best place to offer a little direction and guidance?"
"In my opinion? Find a buster in a lowrider. They'll always help a chica in distress out. No questions asked, heh."
"Um...OK. I think I might hang around this diner first. My legs are kinda sore from all that directionless walking for hours on end, y'know?"
The Feral waves the mortal redhead goodbye and she trudges into the diner.
Markham is busy thumbing through the massive phonebook until he comes across LDJ's phone number. He pulls out some coins from his pocket and inserts them into the coin slot.
He dials the number, waits for a ring, and an irritated, entitled-sounding voice answers, "HEY! Where the fuck is my pizza, huh? You better not be holding back on the salami, ya hear?"
Markham groans a little and shakes his head, "Mr. Luciano Donovan Junior? I'm not your pizza guy. My name is Markham Reed, I'm with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission- the SEC- I'm reaching out to--"
Luciano gasps and almost chokes on the air, "I--I don't owe anyone any taxes! I'm licensed! What's that shit about? H--How do I know this ain't a scam or a crank caller, huh?" his tone is awfully defensive.
Markham sighs and explains, "No, no, it's nothing like that, Mr. Donovan. I would like to know if you're free anytime tonight or tomorrow evening. There are some...discrepancies that I need to clear up with you and your associate, a Paul Cho."
There's silence at the other end for a second, and then LDJ snorts, "Y--you're breakin' up over here..." he goes on to make some very obviously fake static and beeping sounds over the line.
Markham cringes at this weaponization of sheer incompetence. He's been in this line of work long enough to know when some squirming idiot is clearly stonewalling him.
He tries to keep the conversation going, "Are--are you serious, Mr. Donovan? The line's fine on my end."
The arrogant and entitled-sounding voice of LDJ cuts through, "Psssssh. Wiiizzzzzz. STTTTTSSSGGGHHHHH. I--I can't hear you--shhhhhgggsshsshsh. Fwwwwwwwshssshshhh."
Markham shuts his eyes and slowly breathes out, "Mr. Donovan, please stop this childish nonsense. I just wish to meet with you and clarify a few thi--"
"Bzzzzzzzt. Wsssssssshrrrrhghggh."
The Baali has had it. He furiously slams the payphone receiver and the whole thing wobbles and almost falls off. He glares at the phone and snarls, "Fucking idiot."
Luciano, meanwhile, smugly smirks to himself, "Ah, works every time, heh heh." He throws his head back and goes back to flipping through various TV channels.
Still, he does have an uneasy look on his face as he continues to flip through the channels until he lands on MTV. He picks up the phone again and dials the number of none other than his attorney/fixer, Gordon Pym.
The Pym Reaper answers, his voice strained and taut, "Luciano, I was just about to call you. We need to talk."
"Yeah. Listen, Gordo, I--I think I got a problem here."
The fixer grunts, "What now?"
"That...that...that fuckin' bozo called me! I did the thing where I faked static over the line and hung up on him, but I think he fucking knew! Wh--what do I do now, tell me, c'mon!"
"What you did was...childish and stupid, but it buys us time. I just landed a couple of minutes ago. Gimme some time to think this through, but we HAVE TO deal with Markham Reed."
"Yeah, y'know what, I don't mind spending another 60 large--"
Gordon firmly interjects, "Stop. Don't. Just...don't. We'll talk more about this in-person, but not tonight. I'm tired. I've been to the town where this Markham Reed was born and raised."
Luciano hisses, "I don't care about any of that, I just want this fucking cazzone (ITA: idiot) outta my fucking hair!"
"Hmm, you and me both, kid. Either way, I--I'm even more confused now than when I first heard of this Markham Reed. He's got some really deep and inscrutable secrets of his own, that's for sure."
Gordon sighs and adds, "But that's...for tomorrow. I'm tired now."
Luciano inquires, "So, how was your vacation?"
The Pym Reaper sternly retorts, "It was NOT a vacation, Luciano. It was business- it always is with a man like me. I met some...intriguing people, rubbed a few shoulders up in DC, the usual."
Luciano stupidly asks, "Did you meet the President?"
Gordo stifles a sigh, "No. Now, if there's anything else? No? Good. Stall as much as you can. We'll talk more about this tomorrow morning."
"Early morning?"
Gordon yawns loudly into the phone and counters, "Make it at noontime. Don't worry, kid, I'll come up with something by then...but it's gonna cost you. You understand that, right?"
Luciano nods, "Mm-hmm. I got money- lots of it."
"Hmm," Gordon tiredly grunts and hangs up the phone.
Luciano slouches back in his chair and scowls, "Fucking Gordon. Man, I don't know what I'd do without his shady and shrewd advice, but man..."
He shakes his head and checks the clock on the wall, "Mm, where the fuck is my pizza? I'm fuckin' starvin' here!"
Back to the diner...
The 2 Kindred have gotten themselves a booth in a corner. Maya the redhead is sitting on the far side of this establishment, hunched over and twiddling her thumbs. Her map is lying in front of her and she's gazing off into the distance.
She's still profusely sweating.
The diner itself looks fairly average. Bright white lights, shiny checkerboard flooring, walls that are either pale blue or lacking in color, and some very old, yellowed pictures of Flimont City through the decades.
It's rather empty save for a few people cutting about here and there. There's a jukebox by the wall, a few menu cards by the counter, and the kitchen doors swing open as servers in uniform come and go with plates of food.
The aroma of grilled cheese wafts through the air, but neither Diego nor Markham can really smell anything. The servers are all dressed in similar uniforms consisting of a blue candy-striped, buttoned shirt and a white apron with the diner's logo on it.
