The logo is a smiling beaver, buck teeth visible, holding a spatula, and the text above it reads: "TIA'S DINER"
Markham's looking out the window at the outside world. His Motorola phone is in his pocket, and he's sitting with his hands folded on the table.
Diego sits across from him and breaks the silence, "Seeing that you almost assaulted that poor payphone back there, I take it that you have not been able to set up a meeting with those 2?"
Markham has a faraway look in his gray eyes, "Mm-hmm, I...that fucking guy actually did what--what kids do, Diego. He made these obviously fake static sounds and hung up on me. The nerve of these people. The fucking nerve."
"Wow. Immature and loaded? Hm, yeah, sounds about right. Busters like that, they don't ever to worry about nothing, y'know what I'm saying? They just take and take and take, and break shit up and expect someone else to pick up the pieces and clean up after them."
The Baali growls, "I see what you mean, Diego. Either way, I just want people like that to play fair and by the same set of rules as everybody else."
Diego sympathetically pats the Baali on the shoulder and shakes his head, "Ehhh, good luck with that, ese. I've been here long enough to know that there are different rules for different people, y'know?"
Markham stares off into space for a moment, before continuing, "That's what I'm trying to do, Diego. I'm just trying to ensure fair play, even if it might seem like a losing game, an uphill battle, at times. Someone's gotta do it."
The Outlander pointedly queries, "Even after seeing all the nasty shit here in Flimont City, you still trust and believe in the system?" his tone is questioning, but there's no hostility.
The Baali sighs softly, "Of course I do, Diego. I admit, it's not perfect, not by a long shot, but at its best, it works. Or--or it could work if we try hard enough."
Diego muses, "I suppose so, maybe, yeah, but me personally? I stopped believing in this shit a long time ago, hermano. Busters like me won't fare well in the system, y'know what I mean?"
The Gangrel exhales sharply, "The whole system is designed to keep people like us down. Hmph." He shakes his head and watches a few cars zoom down the street.
He frowns and adds, "I've been in and around this system long enough to know that it's pretty much designed to keep us down and...take away our will to do anything, really."
Markham sympathetically offers, "I'm sorry, Diego. Really, I am. We just have to...make do with what we have. It's flawed, cumbersome, and seems to be breaking down and falling apart with each passing night, but I really don't know an alternative. This is just the way it's been set up."
Diego slumps in his seat and sighs, "Mm-hmm. I guess you're kinda right, homes..." he trails off and a forlorn look crosses his face.
Markham observes, "I'm guessing that you're not really that...attached to the city itself?"
The Outlander quietly replies, "Not by a longshot, homes. If it wasn't for me and Marisol having our own place, we'd have skipped town a long time ago. Maybe try our luck in Santa Fe or New Jersey or something."
"Hm. Understandable."
Just then, a whole ruckus group of people (football players, judging by their attire) walk into the diner and take over any unoccupied tables and booths.
They're loudly chatting amongst themselves, clearly pumped up from a victory or whatever. There's a burly guy in a jersey with gold letters on the back. Another guy has a massive #1 foam glove on his hand.
The rest of these people seem to be the typical sports fans you'd find in any large city. They're all loudly laughing and joking about something.
Diego notes, "Looks like they won a game, huh, Markham?"
Markham looks over his shoulder, "Hm. It certainly does seem that way. My football days are behind me, anyway."
Diego smiles and his curiosity is piqued, "Whoa, hold on! YOU used to play football?"
The Demon slowly nods, "Mm-hmm. Small-town, high-school football mostly. Nothing beyond that."
And with that, Markham divulges more about that part of his mortal past. He was clearly quite good at tossing the ol' pigskin around, it would seem.
Maya is overwhelmed by the crowd. She promptly gets up, smiles awkwardly, and brisky walks out. Her map flutters to the floor, but she's too flustered to pick it up.
One wishes her the best of luck and hopes that she finds her way through this crushing hellscape of a city. It's mean to people like her and Diego. And it's absolutely cruel to people who are far worse off than that.
At the back of the diner, the waitstaff shuffle around to bring food and beverages to the crowded tables. Burgers, fries, sandwiches, shakes, the usual yummies.
Chefs wipe sweat off their foreheads and go back to flipping patties, the sizzling sound of which can be heard from where the cashiers are being overwhelmed by orders and whatnot.
The pressure is clearly mounting owing to the influx of hungry customers!
A waitress approaches the 2 vampires, "Sorry for the wait, guys. We're kinda swamped here tonight. What'll it be?" She's got a pen and a notepad ready.
Oh, right. It's a diner these 2 immortal blood-drinkers are sitting in! And one is expected to order something to eat or drink in a place like this! Yikes! Not doing so would be hella suspicious, or eyebrow-raising at the very least!
Diego shuffles out of his seat and says he's got some work to take care of, leaving Mr. Reed alone with this waitress chick.
She looks to be in her 30s and is of average weight, and she is fairly tall. She's got a sort of victory rolls hairstyle going on and her makeup is fairly on-point. Her skin is fair and there are some light bags under her eyes.
Her golden nametag reads: "Rhonda".
Markham stares at her, jaw slightly agape, as Diego drives by in his pickup truck.
Markham waves her off, "Oh, no, it's fine."
Rhonda smiles awkwardly, "You gotta order something, or else, I gotta throw you out. And I don't like throwing potential customers out." She chuckles a little and scratches the back of her head.
Markham blinks and scans the menu card, "Uhhhh...I'll have a...glass of water. Room temperature." Even that's not gonna agree with him, but he's gotta do something to blend in.
Rhonda's eyebrows shoot up, and she bites her lower lip, "Alright. A glass of water it is. You from around here, mister--"
Markham, for whatever reason, gives her his real full name in lieu of his fake name, "Reed. Markham Reed. N--No, I'm here for work. I uh...work for the SEC. I've been living in Seattle."
He's not sure why he's telling her all this. Maybe it's because she reminds him of someone from his past? Right now, he's not sure who. But she certainly does!
Rhonda smiles, "Oh, Seattle, huh? Yeah, I'm from New Jersey." She says it like "Nooh Joisey" as she scribbles down something in her notepad.
Markham nods, "I can tell. Your accent." He looks around and asks, "So, how long have you been working here?"
"Mm, a couple of years now. How long you planning on staying in this city for?"
"Not long. Once I'm done, I'm going back to Seattle. This city...it's just not for me."
The waitress chuckles along, shrill and high-pitched, "Yeah, I hear ya, pal. I know what you mean. I've got my own reasons for sticking around."
"Ah, I see. And what would that be, if you don't mind me asking?"
Rhonda grins at him, "Lemme get your water first." She shoots him a smile and walks off.
Markham gazes out the window and sees the lights of the city. Why was he just so open and easy with some random waitress? Something about her reminds him of someone.
Amidst the boisterous chaos in the diner (loud sports types, what do you expect?), the Baali mulls some things over in his troubled and tired mind. He's exhausted from that short phone call with that mortal twerp, Luciano. He's just...exhausted.
He thinks about the person that Rhonda reminds him of. It takes some time, but it clicks just as the waitress comes to his table with a tall glass of H2O.
Markham nervously looks at it and then looks up at Rhonda. He smiles a little, "Ah. Um...thanks, Rhonda."
She pulls out her notepad and readies her pen, "So, Markham? Make up your mind yet? Between me and you, I'd avoid the egg sandwiches. Trust me."
Markham slowly nods, "Right. I'll be sure to keep that in mind. Um...you know, you remind me of someone--"
Rhonda holds up her hand and shakes her head, "Oh, great, just when I was starting to like ya. There's a reason I don't wear pigtails to work anymore."
Markham assures her, "Oh, no, no, it's nothing like that. Nothing at all. You remind me of--of someone from my past- my older sister, Daniella."
Rhonda is surprised, "Oh, OK. Now, that's new. You keep in touch with her?"
Markham softly sighs and a look of sadness forms on his face, "She died a long time ago." He pauses and looks at Rhonda, "I'm sorry, I shouldn't have brought this up."
Rhonda dismissively waves her hand, "Eh, it's alright. We all need a shoulder to cry on. So, should I put ya down for a grill cheese?"
Ah, right, that. Yikes.
Markham declines, "I'm not hungry. I...just ate, actually. I came in here with my friend to sit down for a while, but he had to leave."
"Ah, OK. No problem. As long you're ordering something, anything, you're welcome here. If you DO change your mind, lemme know, alright?" she smiles and walks off to another table, ready to take their order or collect a tip.
Markham sits there, staring at the glass of water. It's not blood. It's clear and smells of nothing. He doesn't want to drink it, but he knows he has to. Just for appearances' sake. And to blend in.
He sighs and brings the glass to his lips. It tastes ashy as he gulps it down and he grimaces and winces as he swallows. It feels like sand going down his throat. He sets the glass down and wipes his mouth.
He groans softly, "Oh, god. That's awful."
Markham feels weird in his undead stomach. The Beast within sharply disagrees with this pathetic non-sanguine liquid. It wants nothing but blood! It demands blood. It needs blood. And it's not getting any!
Markham shuts his eyes and breathes out, "Ugh." He looks around and sees that Rhonda is busy with another table. She nods to the customers, forces a smile, and pockets the measly tip they left her.
Damn. Chicks like her practically live on the tips because the pay isn't so great. Markham's seen this sort of thing before, but it never fails to make him feel kinda bad.
Service workers deserve so much better.
The mortal waitress goes back to the kitchen to pick up more orders and comes back to the dining area to deliver them to their respective tables. The food smells pretty good, but Markham knows that it'll taste like ash and sand in his mouth.
He forces a few whiffs of the food passing by, but no strong feelings come over him. He's just...numb to it all. He doesn't even miss mortal food and drink that much. His Beast is too angry to be hungry. It's demanding blood. Blood. BLOOD. And it's not getting any.
All it got was water. Markham is starting to feel uneasy in whatever counts as his digestive system. He feels a sharp pain in his abdomen and he groans softly. He looks around and sees that Rhonda is going back and forth, deftly balancing plates of food on her arms.
She's clearly an experienced server, and she's quite good at her job. She's quick on her feet, and she's got a good memory. She knows which table ordered what, and she's able to remember what each customer ordered.
The notepad and pen are mostly for show, it would seem.
A few minutes later...
Rhonda has gotten out of her uniform and joins Markham at his table. The loud sports types have either filed out or reduced their volume to more reasonable levels. The diner is still pretty packed, though.
Rhonda smiles at Markham, "So, Markham? What do you think of the city so far?" she's got a cup of coffee in front of her.
"It sucks."
Rhonda laughs out loud, "Hahahahahahaha! Oh, yeah. You're a real one, alright! Hahahahahahahaha! I like you, Markham. I really do."
Markham awkwardly chuckles along, "Heh, um, thanks. I guess." He pauses and asks, "So, uh, what about you? What's someone from all the way in Hoboken, New Jersey doing out here in the Midwest?"
Rhonda is off her shift now, so she's more relaxed. She sips her bitter coffee and shrugs, "Eh, it's a long story, but the short version is that I'm here because I got nowhere else to go."
"I'm sorry to hear that."
"Hmm, yeah. It wasn't my fault that--that the college I was going to was a fuckin' fraud, a scam. And there I was, a 2nd year accounting student, and then they pull the rug out from under us. Bastards."
Markham nods, "I see. That's awful. I'm sorry to hear that. What exactly happened?"
Rhonda has a sour look on her face and she explains, "The whole college was a fucking scam, Markham. They were taking large sums of money from us and giving us nothing in return. It was a fucking joke."
"Oh. I'm sorry to hear that."
"Yeah, well, I ain't the only one. By the time I found out those degrees they were giving out were as worthless as used toilet paper at a nursing home, it was too late for a lotta us."
Markham offers, "I'm truly sorry to hear that, Rhonda. It sounds like you've been through a lot since then."
Rhonda sighs, "Yeah, well, it's all in the past now. I lost so much money, including my life savings, on that goddamn place. At this rate, it'd take me 10-15 years to break even and clear out most of my...outstanding debts."
"Jesus. That bad, huh?"
Rhonda's New Jersey accent gets more prominent and she clicks her tongue, "Oh, you bet, Markham. That place really screwed a lotta good people over, y'know?"
The Demon nods, "Yeah, I hear you. But what drew you to this city in particular?"
Rhonda mirthlessly chuckles, "Oh, that's the kicker. That 'college' I was talking about? It was right here in this godforsaken hellhole of a city."
Markham responds, "Knowing what I know about this city and its upper echelons, I can't say I'm too surprised by that. So, what exactly happened with this fake university?"
Rhonda drinks her coffee, "Ah, that. I'm not a super-smart gal by any means. And the papers barely touched on it, y'know? It was uh...embezzlement, fraud, something called insider trading, I dunno. There were all these complicated terms being tossed about."
"Uh-huh."
Rhonda sets her coffee down and sighs, "All I know is that those assholes knew about what they were doing. We tried, y'know, protesting, writing to our elected representatives, but they didn't give a flying damn, Markham."
She exhales sharply, "It was--it was as if they just didn't give a fuck, y'know? They just let it happen and let us keep paying. I--I kinda had a feeling that they were in on it, too, y'know? A little um...piece of the pie, a little cream so they look the other way."
"Yeah. It would certainly seem that way. Anything's possible."
Rhonda clicks her tongue and looks off into space for a bit. She then asks, "Y'know what it's like, Markham? To sacrifice everything you've got saved up for a better and more decent future only for it to get swallowed up by a bunch of greedy, slimy assholes who don't care about anyone but themselves?"
Markham sighs, "Mm. It's an all too familiar story these nights." He looks around and he can sense that something is wrong, but he can't tell what.
Rhonda perches an eyebrow, "'Nights'? Lemme guess, you're 1 of those freaks who work really odd hours and have all sorts of crazy schedules, huh?" she laughs a little, but the laughter soon peters out and is replaced by a faint smile.
Markham nervously nods, "Heh, yeah, something like that. I'm sorry about what happened. I guess that experience left a sour taste in your mouth and completely put you off from pursuing higher education?"
Rhonda nods her head, "Mmm-hmm. I figured why even bother. I'd just be digging a bigger hole of debt for myself. Besides, even if I did get my degree, there'd be no guarantee of me getting a job after that."
She inhales and exhales sharply, "Yeah, the whole job market in this city kinda sucks; you gotta know somebody who knows someone who knows a guy if you even want a foot in the door."
Markham agrees, "From what I've seen and heard, I can't argue with that. This city is a mess in so many different ways."
Rhonda scoffs and adds, "Hfff. Yeah. There was a name that kept popping up, y'know, when we found out about all the monkey business and crap going on under our very noses. There was this guy who kept showing up. This name, it kept popping up, y'know? Repeatedly."
Markham leans closer, his hands clasped together, "Oh. Who?"
"Luciano Donovan Senior. Real piece of work. Shady guy. We uh...protested in front of his house, demanding answers. You know, a whole angry mob of college students who lost a lot of their hard-earned cash to a fucking sham."
"Hmm. What did you want to do?"
"Plenty! 1 of us was thinking of firebombing his fancy digs with some molotovs. You know how Maoists are, haha. Anyway, the others said that he probably had a lotta guns stashed around his house and that he probably knew how to use 'em. So that didn't work out too well for us."
"What happened then?"
Rhonda rolls a shoulder, "Eh, we protested, wrote letters, some of us chained ourselves to the railings while others held up 'tasteful' signs at a bridge for a while. But nothing changed."
She ruefully continues, "I guess this is just how things are. It's like nothing can be done to change them, y'know? We tried and tried and fuckin' tried everything in our power to hold someone accountable, but they all got away with it in the end."
She holds up her coffee cup and sarcastically remarks, "Cheers to all those fat cats. I hope they're enjoying our fucking money!"
Markham sighs softly. The pain in his abdomen has abated, but there's still some lingering discomfort in the area. The Beast has been quieted (for now), but that water's gonna come out as scarlet vomit before he knows it.
Rhonda sighs, "Sorry if I got a little heated there, Markham. But...y'know...it's a lot. And I dunno why I just felt so comfortable talking about it all to a literal stranger who I met."
Markham smiles sadly, "Yeah. You've definitely been through a lot, that's for sure. How exactly did you come to work in a...diner of all places?"
Rhonda groans, "I was done with books, debit, credit, exams, calculators, what goes in what column, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. It was too much, and I guess I sorta wanted a change of scene. Maybe."
Markham lifts his chin, "And how's the service industry treating you so far? Is it the change of scene you wanted or...?"
The question lingers in the air for a moment or 2.
Rhonda sees a coworker walking past her. She warmly smiles at them and waves goodbye. She looks around to make sure that her superiors aren't nearby.
Then, she turns to Markham and says, "Yeah, well...the grass ain't exactly greener on the other side. That's what they say, right?"
Markham softly laughs and looks at the glass of water before him.
Rhonda nods over to it and smirks, "Drink up. I was thinking of giving it to you from the tap, but I cracked open a fresh bottle just for you."
Oh, dear. Well, it was awfully considerate of her, but that was a wasted effort.
Markham exhales through his nostrils and lifts his eyes up from the table to meet Rhonda's gaze. He's smiling, but his smile doesn't reach his eyes.
To be nice to this fine lady, he holds up the glass of water, "Cheers." He gulps down some more of the clear liquid and sets the glass down.
Rhonda is grinning.
Markham swallows it, and then his face contorts.
Rhonda's expression changes, "Oh, you uh...allergic to water, Markham? It's mineral water."
The Baali shakes his head, "No, no. I'm more used to it straight from the um...tap. Mineral water just tastes different. I'm not a big fan."
Rhonda shrugs and takes a quick sip of her coffee, "So, tell me more about you? You're an interesting guy, Markham from Seattle. I don't know why I felt comfortable sharing details of my past with you, but I just did. Funny, huh?"
Markham acknowledges her with a nod, "Mmm. It certainly is something. I feel the same way around you, Rhonda. You really do remind me of her, y'know. Daniella. She--"
Crying tears of blood would be a SEVERE breach of the Masquerade, so Markham really has to keep his emotions in check around this mortal woman.
Rhonda sees Markham struggling, "I--I'm sorry. I didn't mean to make you--"
The Demon softly assures her, "No, no, it's OK, Rhonda. Something about...you reminds me of her. She was so full of life and a real social butterfly. You've got that same energy."
Rhonda smiles at this and blushes, "Aw, you're sweet, Markham."
Markham is not sure if he should disclose how his older sister died. Instead, he vaguely says, "She died in a hit-and-run. And--and that's all I feel comfortable talking about regarding that. Sorry."
"It's fine. It's totally fine, Markham."
Markham rubs his eyes. It's not just his Beast that's stirring inside him, but his human emotions, too. A guy like him, so cold and withdrawn, is always searching for anchors. Add to that the trauma surrounding his Embrace (and eventual Re-Embrace), and he's...not that well of a guy.
He takes a deep breath and exhales through his nostrils. He smiles sadly, "Well, um--I...I'm originally from this little town a few miles east of DC called Greenridge. Moving to Seattle was more of a career choice for me."
"And...how's your job so far, huh? The one with the SEC?"
Markham winces, "Mm, it's...it's fine. Yeah, it's going great." It's really not. Or it's about to get a whole lot worse in the coming nights.
Rhonda grins, "Hey, I know when a guy is lying, y'know? And that right there? Total BS. What is it? You hate your job? The boss being a dick? You got turned down for a promotion and a raise? C'mon, talk to me."
Markham shuffles in his seat a little, "It's this case I'm working on, actually. I--I'm not--I can't exactly give you details of an ongoing investigation, Rhonda."
She laughs a little, "Right, of course. Classified. I get it. I know how crazy everyone's acting these days. All that 'national security' talk. Everyone's a terrorist, blah blah blah, yeah."
Markham lifts his chin and turns his head aside, "Yes, there's...a lot of tension in the air recently. Especially here." He thinks about his current investigation and winces again.
Rhonda sighs and her smile withers, "Yeah. This is a messed-up country in a messed-up world, you know?"
"Mm-hmm. I do what little I can to make sure that everybody plays fair and by the same rules."
Rhonda grins at this. She then sighs and bites her lower lip, "You know, Markham from Greenridge. It's been real interesting chatting with ya. You got any places to be at this time of the night?"
"Nope. Not really. You?"
Rhonda shakes her head from side to side, "Me neither. I'd just go back to my crappy place, flop down on the couch like a sack of potatoes, and watch some cheesy soap operas that usually don't make sense, but it's the only thing on my TV. You?"
Markham smiles at her sense of humor, "Eh, not much, I guess. I'd usually just go back home after work, throw back and think about my life choices. After that, I'd fall asleep till I wake up to do it all over again."
Rhonda pouts, "Aww, ain't that sad. So, no girlfriend or wife or something?"
"Nope."
"Ah, I get it. You're gay, right? Hey, nothing wrong with that. Some of my dearest friends like their eggs scrambled, some like it hard-boiled, y'know? Not a big deal to me. No problem with it at all. In fact, I even got this really good friend who's into--"
Markham quickly corrects her, "No, no. Not at all. I'm just not interested in or looking for that kinda thing right now. It's simply not a priority."
Rhonda playfully shoves him, "Yeah, I bet you were a real looker back in high school, huh? Lemme guess, you got crowned Prom King once upon a time?"
Markham shakes his head and lets out a tiny chuckle, "I did play a lot of football in high school. Small town girls, oh, they ate that up with a spoon, heh. But I never did get crowned Prom King. That was my friend, Jack. He's dead now, though."
"Oh, I'm sorry to hear that."
"Hmm. It was a long time ago, Rhonda."
In his case, it was a VERY long time ago!
The mortal waitress hums some more, "You know, you're an interesting guy. Not like the usual greaseballs who come in here and start acting all funny with me. Maybe that's why we can get along? I'm curious, what else is there to know about you? What's your hobbies? What are you into?"
"Not much, really. It's just work, home, sleep, rinse and repeat. I keep my head down most of the time and try not to draw any unwanted attention."
"Yeah, sounds like a real blast. How are you so--so good at keeping it together?"
"Keeping what together?"
Rhonda laughs, "Your job, your life, everything."
Even Markham does wonder that same thing every now and then. HOW the hell has he managed to keep it together after all these years?
He looks back at the mortal woman and simply says, "I dunno. I guess it's just who I am as a...person."
Rhonda leans closer, her chin propped up by her hands, "I think there's more to you than what meets the eye, Markham Reed. A lot more."
No arguing with that!
Markham admits, "I guess you could uh...say I'm always searching."
Rhonda lifts an eyebrow, "Oh, for what? Or who?"
The Demon Worshipper shrugs, "Just...searching for anchors, y'know, trying to find a way to stay human in increasingly inhuman times a--and surroundings. Or...at least, what passes for human in these crazy times."
Rhonda gives him a sympathetic look, "Hey, it's alright. I understand. I listened to that song by David Bowie. 'I'm Afraid of Americans'. Yeah, I'm kinda afraid of us sometimes, y'know?"
"Ah, yeah, that one. It's a great song. You see the music video, too?"
"Yeah, Trent Reznor's a hottie in that. Those eyes of his, oh, gosh." She's blushing and she bites her lip just thinking about him.
Rhonda exhales sharply, "Yeah. You know, it's like...there's this sense of desperation that's gripping this country right now, you know? Wars, school shootings, cops being violent, people not having enough, and so on."
She takes a moment to pause and recollect herself, "There's just so many ways that we CAN die o--or get hurt out here, y'know? We're supposed to be living in the greatest nation in the world, but I don't feel so great and mighty, Markham."
The lady lets out a sharp and tired sigh, "Hell, I can barely make ends meet these days, y'know..." she trails off and emptily stares at her coffee cup.
Markham nods his head and reaches out to hold her hand.
Rhonda twitches at how unusually cold his hand is, but she appreciates the friendly gesture all the same.
Markham clears his throat, "Well, Rhonda. I'm sorry for all you've been through." He knows that she has lost a lot in her short life on this planet.
Rhonda smiles sadly at him, "Thanks. And I'm sorry about your losses, too. Losing your big sister must've been tough on you. That hit-and-run. What was her name again?"
"Daniella. Her name was Daniella. We used to call her Dani most of the time, though."
Rhonda squeezes his cold hand tighter and says, "I bet she was a wonderful sister to you."
"Oh, yeah, absolutely. She was someone I could confide in a--and--and even look up to when I had my own doubts and didn't know where else to turn."
Rhonda softly smiles at him and then she looks around.
She turns back to Markham and observes, "You've got cold hands, Mr. Reed. Did ya just step out of the freezer in the back or something, haha!"
Markham evasively answers, "It's a...genetic thing, I suppose."
Kinda veering into Masquerade breach territory here.
Rhonda perches an eyebrow, "Ahh, sounds interesting. But, seriously, you're cold. Get a heater or try taking a walk when the sun's up. It'll do ya wonders. Just make sure to lather up in sunscreen first, hahahahaha!"
Yeah, not gonna happen. Like, ever. Nuh-uh, sister.
Regardless, Markham warmly smiles and chuckles at this, "Haha, I'll be sure to do that."
Rhonda lets go of his hand.
She then says, "So, uh, I--I dunno if this is too forward of me, Markham, but uh...thank you. Y'know, I just expected tonight to be another shitty 'day at the office' but you're coming here kinda brightened up gloomy ol' Rhonda's night, y'know?" she shyly chuckles a bit.
Markham smiles widely (very rare!), "There's no need to thank me, Rhonda. Truth is, I've had a really nice time chatting with you."
The Baali is strongly considering having Rhonda as his Touchstone. He already has his co-worker, Jamie, back in Seattle, but it wouldn't hurt to have 1 here, too.
Besides, Rhonda is a really compelling mortal. Maybe it's those eyes of hers- that sparkle in them is similar to the sparkle in Daniella's eyes, and Markham is just desperately seeking for a way to hold on to her memory.
Perhaps it's Rhonda's vibes? Is that what the kids call it these days?
Anyway, Markham's smile fades away and he turns his head aside to see the city slowly moving (crumbling apart) before him, "I just popped in here to--"
He feels the undead hairs on his Unliving body stand on end. It feels like he's being watched, like there are eyes (with ill intent) watching him, burrowing deep into his skull. He winces, groans, and a sharp pain forms in his head.
Could it be the water he drank earlier? No. This feels more like his bestial senses (6th, maybe even 7th) kicking into maximum overdrive. He can't explain how or why, but he knows that he's being watched.
He knows this like he knows the sun will rise in a few hours. And for whatever reason, he feels an almost primal urge to lose his tail(s).
Rhonda looks at him, side-eyed, "Markham? You alright? You blanked out there. You look like you saw a ghost or somethin'." She laughs. It sounds forced.
The Demon looks around the diner and notices nobody out of the ordinary, "Actually--never mind. Call it a job hazard. You uh...never know who's watching, heh."
In truth, a few tables over, there sat none other than 1 of Mr. Strickland's soliders. And they are staring at Markham from afar, face concealed by the menu card they're pretending to look through.
They're dressed fairly blandly, so as not to attract attention to themselves.
This is exactly why Markham is uncomfortable around Rhonda right now. He's afraid that she might get caught up in this mess.
The assassin in question has a tall glass of strawberry milkshake on their table and they watch the whole scene unfold. They're not able to hear what the vampire and the mortal are conversing about, but their orders are STRICTLY reconnaissance only.
Mr. Reed shrugs and shakes his head, "Nah, never mind. Maybe it's just my frayed nerves, hmm?"
Rhonda opines, "If that's the case, then some malt whiskey will really help you chill out, Markham!" she laughs and leans back into her seat. It squeaks under her weight.
The Baali chuckles, "Yeah, maybe."
He sniffs and leans forward, "I'm sorry about what happened with your whole college thing, Rhonda. I--I can't make promises, but I'll try to look into it a bit more if I get the time."
Rhonda's eyes light up a bit, "Oh? R--Really? They wrote some articles about it recently, but I gave up on--on there being any resemblance of justice after the whole thing happened. You know, justice for us, justice for those who got scammed by being promised the world. We tried, Markham. But--"
She inhales and exhales, "--But we failed in the end. They promised us the world but all we got now are--are crushing debts, shattered dreams, broken lives."
Her eyes water a bit and she shudders, "We were just young kids lookin' to make something better, y'know?"
The Baali equably responds, "I can talk with some of my superiors at the SEC. Maybe we did investigate the financial malfeasance at your college years ago, but I'll look more into it, Rhonda. Maybe something's still...waiting to be discovered. Turned over, even."
Rhonda's eyes sparkle, "Really, Markham? You mean it?"
"I can't make promises. All I can say is that I'll try. I shouldn't be saying this, but we've been struggling a lot at the SEC over the years. The usual: funding cuts, staff issues, and political and bureaucratic bullshit. I can't make any promises, but I'll try. Maybe there's something that hasn't been looked into. It's all I can offer you, Rhonda."
"Anything helps, Markham. Anything! I don't want you to get into trouble with your bosses."
"You let me worry about that."
Rhonda blows her nose with a tissue and tosses it inside her empty coffee cup, "You know, uh...some people were so broken after the whole thing that they uh--they uh--killed themselves."
Markham winces and his face tics, "That's awful!"
"Mm-hmm. Yeah. They really promised us the world, and they didn't even give us a fucking grain of sand. I fought with my uncle and aunt to go to that place. They wanted me to go to something more well-established, but I was as stubborn as a mule. And look where it got me in the end."
She lets out a sharp breath and gestures around to reinforce her point, "Yeah, my aunt wasn't too trusting of some place that just popped up almost overnight, y'know? The recruiters who came to Jersey were all so sleek and slick with their fancy clothes, fancy cars, fancy watches, all of that."
She clears her throat and sighs, "They were like sharks, Markham. And we were swayed by the promises, y'know? My uncle said he knew someone at Harvard, but I kicked and screamed for the Clearwater Institute."
Rhonda stares deeply into the last dregs of her coffee. The bitter flavor lingers in her mouth. She mutters, "Ugh. By the time we got there, it wasn't long before things started to unravel: shitty dorm rooms leaking water, crazy rules, bad food, out-of-date textbooks, blah blah blah."
Markham clicks his tongue, "That's--that's terrible. Nobody should ever have to be scammed like that."
"Hmph. Tell me about it. By the end of it all, my aunt and uncle disowned me and cut off ALL contact. Can't blame 'em, y'know. So, I had to fend for myself and clear out any outstanding debts, too. So, here I am, slogging away in this place..."
Markham dryly remarks, "Slinging hash in a hash house."
Rhonda snickers at that.
Markham feels a surge of thick something rising from his gut and into his throat. Oops! That water is about to come out! The vamp quickly excuses himself and briskly walks to the washrooms.
A moment or so later...
He looks at himself in the grimy mirror, as if staring into what remains of his very "soul". Unhealthily pale as a sheet and, he can't say that he doesn't look like someone out of a Victorian horror story these nights.
His reflection looks haunted and fraught with pain. He looks tired, too.
Markham takes a deep breath and shakes his head. He splashes some warm water all over his face and tries the nearby automatic hand-dryer, but it's busted. The tissue dispenser is empty as well.
Thankfully, he never leaves home without a large handkerchief! He dabs that on his face and goes back.
When he steps out, Rhonda's still sitting there, dreamily staring out the window. Cars pass by and the occasional police or ambulance siren can be heard in the not-so-far distance.
Rhonda turns to Markham and smiles as he slides back into his seat, looking no different than he did a minute ago. She's been waiting for him.
She leans over and asks, "So, uh...how long are you planning on being in this city, anyway?"
"Not for long. Once I'm done with my investigation, I'm out."
"Yeah, I wish I could do that, too."
"If you could start over, where would you like to be?"
Rhonda sucks some air through her teeth and takes time to answer that open-ended query, "Eh. Maybe Magnolia City o--or maybe Las Estrellas. They got a lotta casinos down there in Las Estrellas. Not that I'd ever gamble, but it'd be fun to see them, y'know?"
The waitress is feeling good around this nocturnal predator part of a Bloodline of (alleged) devil worshippers, so she continues, "What about you, huh? Seattle the place or are you thinking of somewhere else?"
"I like Seattle. It's not infested with traffic like this place, for starters."
"Hah! Yeah, traffic in this place is fucking nuts, Markham! It's a good thing I live close by, but getting back to my place is like doing 1 of those mazes on those kiddy magazines. The amount of times I've almost been run over is--is NOT funny! Haha!"
Markham stiffens up when that last part is said. It's a little too close to what happened to poor Dani. His lips quiver a little bit. His throat constricts slightly.
He doesn't feel the pangs in his "stomach", but he doesn't feel too great, either. Rhonda notices his change in demeanor.
Her expression softens, "Oh. I--I'm sorry."
From there, the conversation between these 2 drifts hither and yon. They talk about their respective pasts, but Markham has to be sure to at least sound his mortal age (43) and not his actual cumulative age (pushing 70).
Rhonda's laughter is shrill and pretty. She's very expressive and quite animated. A bit rough around the edges, but not too much. She's authentic and isn't afraid to share her experiences with anyone caring to listen.
Markham appreciates that kind of authenticity. Too many fakes out there these nights.
After some time, Rhonda looks at her wristwatch and exclaims, "WOW! Haha, this is the time I usually snooze off with the TV shopping network."
She pauses, then she grins at Markham, "You know, I'd uh--I'd like to thank you for tonight."
"It was a pleasure talking with you as well, Rhonda," Markham slightly bows his head and walks with her to the exit of the diner.
Rhonda heads to the back and returns with a box containing a single hamburger.
She smiles warmly at the bloodsucker and says, "I'll uh...hope to see you around, then? This burger's for a...friend of mine. Homeless guy. Sweet guy who just fell on a bit of a rough patch, y'know?"
Markham nods slowly, "Yeah. Anyway, my investigation has run into a hurdle, so I guess I'm stuck here until it's resolved. It shouldn't take too long. Hopefully."
Rhonda bites her lip and playfully smacks his shoulder, "Aw, c'mon. There's a silver lining to every cloud. That's what my tarot-reading neighbor told me. I don't buy that woo-woo stuff, but it's kinda funny to dip your toes in the woo-woo water every now and again, y'know?"
Markham laughs a little and shakes his head, "Yeah, I guess so. Take care, Rhonda. I'll be seeing you around."
She smiles at him and bids farewell before exiting the diner. The heavy door closes behind her and that's the last thing Markham sees of her for the rest of the night.
The assassin slinks into their seat but keeps their eyes steadily trained on the vampire's back as he also leaves the diner.
Mr. Reed exits the diner and looks around. A van pulls up next to him and a woman steps out.
It's Diana! Her stuffed animal dangles from her rearview mirror. She rubs her hands together and her attention is immediately drawn to the Baali, his hands deep in his trenchcoat pockets.
The professional cleaner narrows her eyes and slowly approaches him, "Ma--Markham? Markham Reed?"
Markham's back stiffens up when his real full name is mentioned. He looks at this woman, eyes narrowed. Who is she? How does she know him?
He turns to Diana, "Yes. Can I um...help you?"
Diana points to herself, "It's me!"
"I'm sorry, I don't--"
"You--you really don't? Does the last name Moskowitz ring a bell by...by any chance?"
When he was still a fraud investigator, Markham had a co-worker with that last name. They worked on some cases together, if memory serves correctly.
Diana rubs her baggy eyes, and she looks absolutely tired and worn the hell out.
Markham slowly nods, but remains on-guard VERY much, "Yeah. I do. You are...?"
Diana spreads her arms out wide and smiles, "It's me! Diana Moskowitz! You really don't--oh wait."
She stops and explains who she really is, "OK, this is kinda complicated. You remember a--a little b--boy by the name of Dino? You watched me for some time while my dad went out to um...run some errands, I think?"
She pauses for a moment, then she laughs, "Wow. You really don't remember, do you? That's OK! That's OK! Uh, yeah, I was Dino and well, now, I'm Diana!"
(Diana is transgender. She was Assigned Male At Birth (AMAB), but she now identifies as female and has undergone all the necessary gender-affirming procedures and surgeries over the years. Her family has disowned her as a result of this.)
Interestingly enough, her family all vote Democrat. Make of that what you will.
Markham side-eyes her, "I...don't get it. I remember a Dino, yes, but not a Diana."
Diana explains her circumstances, "I uh...underwent some procedures and well uh--"
It clicks for Markham, "Oh. I see. A sex change? Uh, well, congratulations, I guess?"
Diana chuckles at that, "Haha. Yeah. Thanks. You know, Markham, you look...well, I was expecting you to be a lot older. Maybe it's the lights playing tricks on my eyes."
"Hm. Maybe. How are you keeping, Diana? How's your family?"
Diana scoffs, "My family? They turned their backs on me and cut me off from their lives because of who I am. I was so uncomfortable in my own skin, y'know? I had to start over from the ground up and it's hard out there."
"I'm sorry to hear that, Diana. Um...what are you doing now?"
"I work as a professional cleaner for 'Worbo's Professional Cleaning Services'. Not my 1st choice, lemme tell ya that much, heh. But I got rent to pay and uh...what else is new?"
She half-heartedly gestures to her van. Her black hair is short and stringy. She's thin and somewhat short, but her eyes are a clear shade of green.
Markham looks over and says, "Ah. I see. So, what are you doing here, Diana?"
"Apart from being worked like a fucking horse for pitiful pay? I'm here to grab some chow. Truth is, I could ACTUALLY eat a horse right now. I'm famished and Tia's Diner is 1 of my joints."
Markham tries to keep his distance from her, so as not to arouse any suspicion, but Diana sluggishly trudges forward and looks up at him with eyes that reflect tiredness and curiosity in equal measures.
It was the same look she had when she was a kid being watched over by Markham for but a few hours while her dad went off to do something or the other.
Diana gazes into his eyes and asks, "You know, I'm not so good with people anymore. I lost touch with a lot of my old friends since, uh--since what happened with my family. At least I got Jerry."
Markham is not sure who that is, "Oh, Jerry is your--"
Diana points to the stuffed lion, "My inanimate stuffed lion and professional listener. No BS from him. Ever."
Her eyes water up and she's still looking at Markham, "I--I'm glad that he's there for me, y'know?"
The Baali looks at her with some sympathy in his dead gray eyes. She must have been through a lot since they last met.
Diana mirthlessly smiles, "Anyway, how have you been? What have you been up to?"
"Not much, really. I'm just here in Flimont City on a work-related assignment. After that, I'm getting the hell out and going back to Seattle."
The mortal woman whistles, "Seattle, huh? Lucky you. You got a family back home?"
The eternal predator of the sundown hours shakes his head, "No. No, not really. It's just me, Diana."
Diana somberly responds, "I'm sorry. I heard about what happened to Daniella, by the way. Shame."
Markham gulps, "Hm. Yes. Please, don't--don't make me talk about it."
"OK, OK."
She can sense how cold and withdrawn the vampire is, so she waves goodbye and gingerly asks, "Can we stay in touch? Pretty please? A familiar face is--"
"Yes, Diana. Of course."
"You sure? You sound like you'd rather I was a stranger. I won't be offended if--"
"Diana. I have no issue with who you are. It's your life, your body, and ultimately your choice. As long as you're not hurting anyone else, then it's fine."
Diana is not sure if she heard that right, but she thinks she heard it right, "Wow! That's um...really nice of you, Markham. A kind word to a--a gal like me is rare around these parts. Especially when, y'know, I tell 'em that I'm..." she trails off and clears her throat.
She makes a motion with her hands and awkwardly adds, "That I'm uh--I'm--well, you know..."
Markham smiles at this and nods, "It's nothing to be ashamed of. You yourself said that you were uncomfortable in your own skin. I can't even begin to imagine what that must feel like but--"
Diana humbly mumbles, "I can't thank you enough, Markham. Seeing you has brightened up my shitty day by...this much." She makes a pinching gesture to show how much her day has improved.
Markham winces uncomfortably at how low her mood must be if he's "brightening it" this much.
Diana then hands her a card for Worbo's Professional Cleaning Services. Her number is hastily scrawled on the back. She mouths, "Call me!" and hurries inside the diner to satiate her hunger.
The Baali's expression shifts, "Hmm. You never know when you might need a professional cleaner, do you?"
He thinks about how she has come far since he last saw her. He cracks a tiny smile and pockets the card.
Interesting night, all things considered. A woman who might be a Touchstone for the troubled Baali and someone from his not-so-distant past, huh?
But the night is still young, as they are oft wont to say. There's still work to be done here. Mr. Reed decides to hit the nearest cybercaf and do some more digging into Rhonda's scam college- Clearwater Institute.
Ah, yeah. Cybercaf. Before everyone and their grandpa had the power of knowledge and information shoved into their pockets in the form of touchscreen phones, a cybercaf was a place where people could usually access the Internet on bulky PCs.
Markham's not too "up" on the Y2K tech, but he does what he can so as not to stand out and unwittingly cause a Masquerade breach.
He asks around and a few locals point him in the direction of the aforementioned establishment. He walks a few blocks, constantly looking over his shoulder to see if he's being followed.
He is, but the killer knows how to tail someone without getting made.
How long until the Baali is forced into a confrontation with these killers? Either way, he hopes that his friends (be they immortal or mortal) don't get caught up in the crossfire.
Mr. Strickland already tried once (and failed). With Gordon back in town, the 2 will indubitably make plans to have another go at that which cannot be so easily killed.
Recall, for that which is already dead cannot be so easily killed. And Mr. Strickland's people, trained as they are, do not have the right tools for the job.
How will the Demon be able to protect those he cares for from this looming and lurking danger? This is the question which nags him in the back of his mind, but it's not the only one.
There's the whole Luciano and Paul thing. He's not too keen on meeting either of them or asking them the questions he knows he has to ask so his investigation can...progress somewhere.
Another issue is him essentially staying in Diego's and Marisol's Haven. Those 2 Gangrel have been welcoming to him thus far, but he knows that arrangement can't go on forever.
Mr. Reed has the cash for a hotel room, but Diego, being the helpful buster that he is, insists on him staying at their place. Regardless, Markham doesn't want to impose on his hosts any longer than is absolutely necessary.
In good time, Markham's at the cybercaf. It's musty in here. The floors are a shade of chocolate brown and grimy in some spots. The walls are peeling off in some areas, and the place is full of warm and sweaty bodies. Add to that all the heating PCs and it's quite arid in here.
There's some kind of a LAN party going on in here, it seems. Loud cheering and whistling pierces the air. Skinny, shirtless guys are whooping loudly and sipping on Mountain Dews.
There are a few chicks in the corners, but they look so bored out of their minds. Can't blame 'em, honestly.
There are pizza boxes and sticky wrappers carelessly strewn about. It's a good thing that nocturnal predators of the dark night no longer have functioning respiratory systems.
The stench alone would make any self-respecting breath-drawer flee the scene in a matter of moments!
Markham opts for a corner booth for maximum privacy. He starts looking into Clearwater Institute, specifically the financial side of things. It isn't long before he comes upon a series of articles on the threadbare website for the Flimont Times.
The vampire's typing speed is abysmally slow, but he gets the gist of the articles. This is how he comes to know that the whole thing was a fucking pyramid scheme from start to finish.
The articles in question were all written by none other than the late Nicky Schroeder a few years back. By then, it was too late for anything to be done about the CWI.
Nicky, may the poor guy rest in peace, had quite an ol' timey muckraker quality to his writings. Either way, he did his due diligence and was able to uncover some really shady goings-on around the college.
And while there is some clear hyperbole thrown into the mix, it does shed some light on this whole sordid situation. There are a few names that Markham recognizes from the article.
Namely, Luciano Donovan Senior- LDJ's dad. Clearwater Institute had this weird and unusual thing where every student, faculty member, and employee was made a shareholder. In the article, Nicky mentions how unusual this move is for an institute dedicated to higher learning.
In essence, the college that Rhonda attended was a scam from start to finish. Money kept being sucked up to the top echelons who have all either ran away to countries with no extradition treaties with the USA or are lawyered up and ready to sic those hungry lawyers on anyone trying to poke the bear, as it were.
The article does mention the disappearance of a few staff members (how very convenient). A few deaths were quickly written off as accidents by the FCPD (!) and the story was essentially forgotten as the new century was ushered in.
It does mention a few other employees, though. But, when reached out for comment, they either clammed up or claimed they knew nothing of the massive ponzi scheme.
The article that Markham's reading ends on a rather ominous note, as if more were planned to be revealed: "It would seem, dear readers, that all roads lead back to 1 man- Luciano Donovan Senior. Stay tuned for more about that and be sure subscribe to our emailing list so you don't miss out!"
All roads lead back to LDJ's daddy, huh? Well, if that's the case, then taking down LDJ is, at best, a distraction. Someone really needs to look into LD Senior.
Markham is certainly getting those feelings right now, but his hands are tied. His orders are LDJ and P-Money.
The real problem is clearly LDJ's father, whose name has popped up in connection to all sorts of unpleasant things- from right-wing death squads in Latin America, connections to Jeffrey Epstein, and a possible role in the funding of some pretty nasty domestic terror orgs right here in the land of the free.
There's a lot of smoke there, that's f'sure!
Regardless, Markham Reed is determined to focus his investigative energies on Luciano Junior. He'll just need to hope that someone at the SEC or the IRS (or wherever) has the stones to look more into Luciano Senior.
Good luck with that. Luciano Sr. himself sat on the advisory board for the SEC a few years ago. He's got shadowy connections to all the ominous alphabet national security agencies in the country, and he is obscenely wealthy.
Not to mention, he has tons of kids (mainly daughters) on literally every continent. The guy's a fucking behemoth who'd leverage all his power and connections to crush the Baali into bits and pieces.
Mr. Reed takes a moment to pause and reflect on his current situation.
He has been around the block a few times. He's seen a lot of scumbags in his own time, and he knows that the Donovan patriarch is certainly a force to be reckoned with.
Either way, he's here to look into LDJ's (alleged) misdeeds and that's exactly what he's going to do.
For now.
Bigger fish need bigger pans and more heat if they're ever gon' get fried!
Ah, well...let's check in on Sheriff Velma DuPont...
The Ventrue Sheriff finds herself in a rather seedy part of the city. It's empty save for a few shipping containers dotted about here and there. There's not a lot of light here, and the place stinks of garbage and piss.
Sheriff Velma's eyesight is as sharp as a hawk's, though. She adjusts her up-do and confidently walks forward, gracefully gliding over the uneven ground.
The Ventrue Sheriff hears some loud arguing coming from a nearby shipping container. A gruff British accent is most prominent amongst the sea of generic Midwestern American accents.
Sheriff Velma stops for a second and listens in. There's a bit of a heated discussion going on inside the shipping container. She can't make out what these Brujah are talking about, but it sounds...spirited and intense.
Yeah, definitely Brujah having a chat amongst themselves.
The Blue Blood amusingly remarks, "I'm surprised they haven't started trading blows yet."
She circles around and approaches the container's entrance with quiet footsteps. She stands there, at the front, like a Cheshire cat, and observes 3 vampires having a heated discussion.
Clive is in the middle and 2 of his fellow Punks flank his sides. Clive's hair is a bit messy, and his hands are balled into fists. His nostrils flare and his teeth grind together.
He sharply tells the goth-looking dude to his left, "I'm telling you; you're reading it wrong! You fucking muppet! It's not a metaphor for whatever the bleedin' hell you're taking it as."
The goth vamp rolls his eyes and sighs, "Oh, come on. It's pretty clear what you're getting at, Clive."
The chick on Clive's right is a demure, academic-looking dame. She wears glasses, and she has her long black hair tied up in a tight bun.
She speaks with a soft, gentle voice, "You know, Clive, I think we can take a moment to step back and reflect on the broader themes of--" she stops and gasps when she sees the Ventrue Sheriff.

Clive glares at her and his expression sours. He puts down his book and snarls, "What are you doing here? Here to shake me down for a million dollars, love? I don't fucking 'ave that kind of dosh lying around. Now, bugger off."
Academic chick lowers her head and avoids eye contact with the Sheriff. Goth dude tries to appear all tough and intimidating but is shut down when the Sheriff icily glowers at him.
Clive scoffs, "Well, what do you want, love? Can't you see that we're busy?"
Sheriff Velma leans against the shipping container, "You have been busy, haven't you? Lemme jog your memory. You and your fellow Rabble hit something, something very important, last night."
Clive throws his muscular arms up in the air, "I don't know what you're talking about, love. We hit a lot of things. We're Brujah. Maybe whoever or whatever it is we hit had it coming."
Sheriff Velma rolls her eyes, "Don't make this any harder on yourself, Clive. I only found out where you were tonight because your Gangrel buddy Pedro told me where to look. The Feral gave me a 100 different spots on where you MIGHT be."
She sounds tired and a tad bit irritated.
Clive smirks, "Not me problem, love. We want in to the big posh Ivory Tower, but I AM NOT giving that fucking twat you call your Prince a million dollars! Even if I had that kind of dosh, I wouldn't waste it on him."
Sheriff Velma growls and reminds the Punk, "He's not just MY Prince. He's OUR Prince. He's been the Prince of this whole city for the past 100 years."
She takes a few menacing steps forward and stares down these 3 Rebels, "Show some fucking respect. You think that you're hot shit, but a bum would sooner scrape what's left of you off their feet. Don't think that I won't make sure that happens."
The goth dude raises his hands up in mock-surrender and snarks, "Oh, madam Sheriff officer. I've been a bad, bad boy. You gonna bend me over and spank me?"
The academic chick giggles at this.
Clive snarls at her, "You don't scare us. We know what you really are. You destroy Thin-Bloods for fucking sport. What you and Antonio are running is nothing short of an extortion racket."
Sheriff Velma is getting a bit ticked off and is just about to grab the Punk by the shirt collar, but Clive quickly rises up from the barrel he's seated on.
He smiles, "What do you want, eh? Let's go for a walk and we can talk about it...like the civilized parasites and leeches that we are, yeah?"
Sheriff Velma blandly says, "Lead the way. Tell nerd and emo to stay put." She shoots a glance at the 2 other Brujah.
Clive smiles, "Oh, you can count on it, love. They'll stay put. Come on." He walks over to the edge of the shipping container and beckons, "Ladies first."
Sheriff Velma faintly scoffs and starts walking, making sure to not let this massive British dude out of her sight. A few other Brujah in this area emerge from the shadows or watch her with a certain fiery intensity in their dead eyes.
She remains unfazed and composed while walking slowly. Clive matches her pace and begins, "So, what's the story, love? Do you even have any proof of whatever it is you think we did?"
"Don't call me love. I'm your Sheriff. Which means I'm owed a certain degree of respect around these parts. I'm not some 'crumpet' or some 'floozy'. I'm the Sheriff of Flimont City. You will refer to me as Sheriff Velma."

Sheriff Velma groans, "Oh, just that you and your buddies smashed up a van and destroyed a trailer in the middle of the goddamn street. Ring any bells in that empty head of yours?"
Clive's expression shifts into one of curiosity, "Van? Trailer?"
"Mm-hmm. It was carrying something really important- that's all I'm gonna say. You left quite a mess back there. It's a Masquerade breach, if ever there was one. Your little ex-Anarch posse isn't doing the best job of keeping a low profile in this city."

Nah. She reassures herself that they've got a good thing going on here.
"Only a fool would try to upset the apple cart, and there are no fools in the Prince's Court."
Oh, the apple cart was gonna be upset, alright. But those who would soon do it are gonna be anything but fools!

It isn't long before that great ball of fiery fire roars into view. Flimont City is now bathed in an intense orange glow. Day is now in full swing. The streets are mostly empty save for a few cars here and there.
The Kindred in this Midwestern blightscape succumb to the lulling and sluggish pull of the day-sleep. Their bodies "shutdown" for a whole day of rest and rejuvenation.
As the day rolls on, the traffic begins to build up. School buses (the functioning ones, anyway) ferry their little charges to their crumbling destinations.
The homeless begin their days of begging for spare change and searching for the nearest dumpster to find scraps of food, good but thrown away for whatever absurd reason.

The day is a busy one, bright and sunny. What nobody knew was just how messy things were gonna get from here on out.
In fact, it was already beginning.
Chapter 13: Why so SAD?
"I'm afraid of Americans / God is an American / God is an American" -David Bowie, Im Afraid of Americans (1995)
Miles and miles away, in a building of glass and steel...
A man in his 40s is seated in his comfortable air-conditioned office. He's got a wiry build and is a bit on the short side. His dark hair is thinning, and he's clean-shaven.
He wears a dark suit with a blue tie. His black shoes are shined and polished to perfection. He has a faint scent of cologne about him.
His face is locked in a stern and serious expression. He's reading through a thick stack of documents (mostly redacted), making sure that everything is in order.
He checks his watch and mutters, "It's almost time."
His office is sparsely furnished. The carpet is gray, and the walls are painted a neutral cream white. There's a large desk made of oak. A few photos are placed on top of it. The windows are covered by thick curtains.
A ceiling fan is lazily spinning above the man's head. He picks up his phone and dials a number.
The other person on the end of the line answers, their voice professionally neutral and monotone.
"This is Special Agent Harold Cuomo speaking," the man says, "Yes, I have reports of potential blank body activity in Flimont City."
The person on the other end replies, "Understood, Special Agent Cuomo. We've just received the reports as well."
Special Agent Cuomo sits back in his chair and stifles a sigh, "How should we proceed?"
"The Special Affairs Division leaves that in your hands, Special Agent Cuomo. You'll have FBI assets at your disposal, but tread cautiously when utilizing them. We don't want or need a repeat of 1993."
Special Agent Cuomo faintly chuckles, "Understood. This could very well be a big break or a whole load of nothing. I'm looking at a file detailing our last op in Flimont City- 1995. It's not pretty and it's heavily redacted."
The person on the other end of the line is silent for a moment, then they say, "That, Special Agent Cuomo, is not your concern. We made...small errors in our handling of that situation. It's been cleaned up since then."
Special Agent Cuomo nods, "Understood. So, we're starting with a fresh slate, then?"
"I believe we are, yes. You will be provided with all that you and your people require- specialized equipment, transport, personnel, access, and weapons. However, we must stress that this is a delicate matter. We don't want another incident like 1995."
Special Agent Cuomo grimly states, "I understand. If there are blank bodies in Flimont City, then we'll smoke 'em out."
"Hm. Yes. Your...track record speaks for itself. You have approximately 3 confirmed blank body kills on your record. That's not bad, considering the circumstances and what you were up against in...Tulsa, yes?"
Special Agent Cuomo sniffs, "Yes. Tulsa, Oklahoma, 1998. It's not enough, though. I know that there are more of these slimy immortals out there. They're everywhere. And they're dangerous."
The person on the other end of the line agrees, "Indeed. Well, you've got the green light, Special Agent Cuomo. Although, your methods..."
They pause and some shuffling and mouse-clicking can be heard, "Ah. OK, yes. You've been utilizing...unorthodox methods to acquire information from suspected blank body sympathizers. Methods that are...not exactly approved by the Bureau."
The Special Agent scoffs lightly, "So what if I did? It's a new world and the rules of engagement have changed drastically as a result. If we want to fight the blank bodies, then we need to play by a different set of rules. There are no other options or alternatives when dealing with 'em. I speak from firsthand experience."
"Well, we appreciate that, Special Agent Cuomo. Still, pouring kerosene on an incapacitated blank body, who appeared as a teenager, and lighting them and their surroundings on fire...that's not exactly something certain folk would approve of."
Special Agent Cuomo coldly remarks, "Fuck them. We're at war with these monsters. Besides, that so-called 'teenager' was almost 200-years-old! That bloodsucking 'kid' had it coming."
"We'll keep that in mind, Special Agent Cuomo. Regardless, you have to be cautious with how we handle these matters. If the public or a wrong Senate Subcommittee found out, a black site in Thailand would be the least of our worries."
Special Agent Cuomo sighs, "Yeah, yeah. I know. But these blank bodies are parasites, plain and simple. They live off our blood and don't age. They stalk the nights looking for some unfortunate sap to feed on. And they're smart. They blend in well with society despite being old as hell."
"We fully understand, Special Agent Cuomo. That being said, you have full authorization to deal with and neutralize any and all blank body-related threats in Flimont City. Just do it quietly and don't leave too much of a paper trail."
Special Agent Cuomo grins, "Ah, music to my ears. We'll make sure that none of these monsters survive. We'll get 'em before they get us. They won't even know what hit 'em."
"Very well. Do you have any other concerns?"
"Yes. Am I...authorized to utilize enhanced interrogation techniques?"
"Harold, if it's good enough for the CIA, then it's good enough for the Special Affairs Division. All we want are results. Maybe a few graphs and bar charts to show to some members of Congress. Pictures, too. Where applicable, of course."
Special Agent Cuomo laughs, "You got it! Any other orders from your end?"
"You've been on the Division Director's radar since your last op in 1998. He's interested in how result-oriented and driven you are, and he wants to see you succeed."
Special Agent Cuomo smiles widely, "Oh, that's great!"
"He's also thinking of promoting you, should you succeed in this operation in Flimont City. You're 1 of the best agents we have, Harold. Don't screw it up."
Special Agent Cuomo nods, "I won't. I promise."
"Good luck, Special Agent Cuomo. Keep us in the loop at ALL times and exercise caution when dealing with the blank bodies. They're not to be underestimated."
"Roger that. Over and out."
Special Agent Cuomo hangs up and leans back in his chair. He closes his eyes and takes a deep breath. He lets it out shakily and spins around in his chair a few times. He stares out the window and watches the world below him.
From where he's looking, it's a beautiful day outside. The sun is shining, the birds are singing, and the sky is clear. He makes a call and a woman shows up a few minutes later.
She's in her 40s as well. She has dark brown hair, a round face, and a somewhat athletic build. She's wearing a dark suit with a blue tie. Her shoes are black and shiny. She has a faint scent of perfume about her.
That would be Agent Heather Heartley, Special Agent Harold Cuomo's second-in-command. She takes a seat opposite her superior and crosses her legs.
"What's up, boss?" she asks.
Special Agent Cuomo turns to face her, "We've got the green light, Heather. We're heading to Flimont City. If there's vampires there, then we're fucking killing them. All."
Agent Heartley's face lights up, "That's great news! I've been itching to get back into the field ever since our last op in Tulsa. So, what's the plan?"
"Here's how it's gonna go. We have full access to the Bureau's resources. Fresh faces and bushy tails from Quantico, weapons, vehicles, intel, and all that good shit. We'll be using the Bureau's connections to get us whatever we need."
Agent Heartley nods, "Got it. So, we're basically running an off-the-books operation here?"
"Mm-hmm. We'll be working with a mix of standard FBI agents who don't know squat about the blank bodies and SAD specialists who do. So, we'll have to figure out a way to keep the lower ranks in the dark while keeping the rest in the loop."
Agent Heartley ponders this for a moment, "Well, we could always use the old 'need-to-know' excuse."
Special Agent Cuomo dismissively waves his hand, "That won't work. Last century's tricks just won't cut it anymore. We'll need something...contemporary and plausible, too."
Agent Heather strokes her chin and thinks for a minute, "What about...using a different kind of excuse? Something that won't raise too many eyebrows while giving us the freedom to do what we need to do?"
Special Agent Cuomo looks at her curiously, "Go on."
"We could say that we're conducting an op against a plausible bioterrorist threat in the area. Blank bodies technically are, well sort of, biologically different and whatnot. That should give us deniability in case things go south, right?"
Special Agent Harold smiles, "That's a great idea, Heather! We'll use that as our cover story. The bioterrorist threat. The lower ranks will have to keep their mouths shut and do as they're told, but our inner circle will know what's REALLY going on."
Agent Heather nods, "Right. We'll have to tread cautiously, though. The blank bodies are smart and they're good at blending in with the rest of society. We'll also have to keep a close eye out for their daylight hangers-on."
"Yeah. Sneaky sons of bitches. Tch. This new century means it's a whole new world out there, Heather. 1998's rules don't cut it anymore..." Special Agent Cuomo gets up from his chair and walks over to the window.
He puts his hands behind his back and lifts his chin, "We'll have to do whatever it takes to keep America safe from these...things. They stopped being people a long time ago."
Agent Heartley stands up and joins her superior at the window, "I know, Harold. We'll get them. We'll make sure that every last one of them is dead."
Special Agent Harold snickers, "Or in a black site. The intel that these fuckers are sitting on could save a lot of lives."
Agent Heather's gaze follows a bird flying by, "True. The blank bodies have powerful friends, though. They can't all be hobos and junkies stalking alleyways and biting into hookers infested with god knows how many STIs. Ech."
She shudders, her face contorting into a tight grimace.
Special Agent Harold shakes his head, "No, they can't. It would be easier if they were all losers, though. But they're not. They're smart and they're everywhere. All around us. And they're extremely dangerous."
"I know. So, what's our next move, sir?"
Special Agent Harold takes a deep breath, "We'll need to assemble a team of specialists. The right kinds of people. I'll look into putting together people for our lower ranks, you focus on our in-house SAD operatives."
Agent Heather nods, "Understood. We'll need a good number of people for this op. How many do you think we'll need?"
"Enough to keep the purse strings happy, but not enough to attract too much attention from the blank bodies. They're everywhere- even we're a bit compromised. Hmph."
Agent Heather chuckles, "I'll get right on it, sir."
Special Agent Harold pats her back, "You've done well by me...and the SAD, Heather. Once we're done cleaning Sunshine City of its immortal problem, we'll have a long and serious talk about promoting you to Special Agent."
Agent Heather bows her head a bit and cracks a small smile, "Thank you, sir. I won't let you down. Promise."
"I know you won't. Now, get to work. We've got a lot to do before we can head out to Flimont City. I want a good and competent team put together. Money's no object, but discretion is key."
Agent Heather firmly nods, "Yes, sir! I'll get right on it!"
Special Agent Harold smiles, "That's what I like to hear. I look forward to some...fires being started." He's got that psychotic look in his eyes again.
The very same psychotic look he had when destroying those vampires in Tulsa back in 1998. He just had to go for the option that caused maximum damage and destruction.
That was (and still is) his modus operandi back then.
And in the opening years of the 21st century, it's going to be a hell of a lot more destructive in Flimont City!
Special Agent Harold Cuomo is an establishment thug through and through. His trigger-happy violence and eagerness to use extreme force against the Kindred (and those around them) have earned him quite the reputation amongst the ranks of the SAD.
He's the kind of buster who will burn down an entire apartment building in the 'hood if it means getting rid of a single vampire. He's ruthless, he's brutal, and he's determined to get the job done no matter what.
As Agent Heather leaves, a call comes in for the man himself. He picks it up and it's the same person from earlier.
"Yes?" he answers.
The person on the other end of the line replies, "We have an asset in Flimont City. We've sent his file over. You are to liaise with him as soon as possible. He has extensive knowledge of the area."
Special Agent Cuomo raises an eyebrow, "If it's another 600-pound drug dealer called 'Skinny Tim', I'm not interested. I have my limits."
"No, no. This one's different. He's one of us, actually. He's intelligence and he's protected from on high, so don't touch him."
Special Agent Harold's face scrunches in confusion, "What's that supposed to mean? Who--who is this guy? What's so special about him?"
A dry response comes through, "It's all in his file, Harold. You might see things that you don't approve of, but you are NOT, under any circumstances, to interfere with his operations. Understood?"
Special Agent Harold stifles a groan, "Yeah, yeah. Yes. U--Understood."
"Good. We'll keep you posted if anything else comes up. And we expect timely status updates from you."
"Yeah, sure thing," Special Agent Cuomo hangs up and immediately checks his emails for this mysterious asset's file.
He finds it and opens it up. The first thing he sees is the man's name: Mr. Strickland. That's it. It's not mentioned whether it's his first, last, or middle name.
Special Agent Harold perches an eyebrow skeptically and scrolls further down. Yeah, it's the very same Mr. Strickland, the crazy asshole running the organization of contract killers in Flimont City.
He's an asset to the vast military-intelligence apparatus of the almighty dollar empire. And judging by how long his file is (and how HEAVILY redacted it is), he's a VERY valuable asset.
Special Agent Harold groans and rubs his temples, "Fuck me sideways...who--who the hell is this guy?"
He's going to have to deal with this lunatic. Almost 90% of Mr. Strickland's file is redacted. There's a hell lotta black redaction pens being mistaken for highlighters up in Washington DC or Langley or Quantico or wherever.
Special Agent Cuomo's expression sours as he reads through the unredacted portions of the man's file. He's a contract killer, yes, but he's also a highly skilled and experienced operative.
And he's got the connections to back it up. Before entering the "bidness" of murder-for-hire, Mr. Strickland was with the Military Assistance Command, Vietnam- Studies and Observations Group (or MACV-SOG).
He and his fellow imperialist goons did what could only be described as war crimes in Vietnam. They were the American empire's most ferocious attack dogs, and they did a whole lotta dirty and unpleasant work.
Mr. Strickland was said to be 1 of their best and most loyal operators. Even then, his past "escapades" are heavily redacted in the interest of "national security" or some such bullshit.
After 'Nam, Mr. Strickland moved to Flimont City and has essentially been living off a very generous retirement fund. Nothing much about his past and no mention of any family, immediate or extended.
Son of a bitch has shrouds that are shrouded in secrecy!
Special Agent Harold, for his part, wonders why the file is so redacted, "It's blacker than a fucking oil spill. Who the hell is this guy that we've got working...for us? With us? Jesus."
He makes a few calls and is immediately shut down when Mr. Strickland's name is brought up. People clam up, hang up, or sternly chide Special Agent Harold and tell him not to go digging where he shouldn't be.
So, he does what any establishment thug would do in his position: he follows orders. But the more "curious" part of him (as far as he has one) is wondering WHY this particular "asset" is so highly protected.
Either way, Special Agent Cuomo puts that aside and gets to work on assembling a team of competent and trained SAD agents to accompany him to Flimont City. These assholes are coming, and they know what they're doing.
The operation begins in earnest!
Back to Flimont City...
It's now noontime. Luciano Donovan Junior has already woken up, said his daily morning affirmations, and is eating a dry bowl of cereal while watching the news.
