P-Money grimaces uncomfortably, "Is it gonna be those some contract killers again?"
LDJ claps back, "So what if it is, huh? We got a good deal going on here, Paul! Are we really gonna let 1 fucking nobody screw it up?!"
Paul hesitates and scratches his head, "I--I don't know, Luciano. I mean, if the SEC gets involved any further, we could be in deeper shit. Like, REALLY deeper shit!" he has that really manic look in his eyes.
It's kinda scary.
LDJ sneers, "Yeah, but they don't have any proof..."
He turns to his best friend and smirks in a smug manner, "...they don't know about our golden goose, laying those fat golden eggs for us."
Paul clicks his tongue, "Hmph. I just, dunno, man. Mauve is a good source of income, yeah, sure. But she's also a huge liability. She's practically retarded and..."
LDJ hisses and gets closer to Paul, "Aw, shut up, Paul! I don't care about any of that! Yeah, I know she was, and will always be, a fucking retarded homeless bum. But she's OUR retarded homeless bum, and she makes us a whole lotta fuckin' money with her crazy numbers thing!"
Paul sighs, "I know, I know. I just think that maybe we should..."
Luciano cuts him off, face red with anger, "What? Maybe we should what, Paul!? Hmm?! Maybe we should stop using her?! Is that what you were gonna say?!"
Paul flinches and backs away from his buddy, "N--No, Luciano. I'm just saying that we should keep our idiot savant on a tight leash, y'know? Make sure that she doesn't go and--and start running her crazy mouth off to the wrong kinds of people."
LDJ huffs, "Yeah, yeah. I know. We'll keep her in line. I'll make sure of it. Besides, I pay her fucking rent up at that fancy-ass place. That alone should make her grateful enough to shut up and do whatever the fuck I tell her to do."
Paul nods, "Good. Good. OK. Just making sure. So, what's the plan?"
LDJ puffs his chest out and proudly declares, "We keep making ourselves rich. And soon enough, every-fucking-body is gonna line up to kiss my ring. Even my fucking dad's gonna be on his knees."
Paul raises an eyebrow, "You sure about that, Luciano? Your old man doesn't bow for anybody."
LDJ scoffs, "Pfft! Oh, marone, when he sees how much money I'm drowning in, he'll be begging to learn the recipe to that secret sauce. He'll be kissing my ass and asking ME for a job!"
Paul chuckles, "That would be something, alright."
Luciano sets his bowl aside and brings up something from his past, "Y'know, Paul, the only time my dad ever...smiled at me?"
"Uh...?"
Luciano Jr. sucks some air through his teeth and shakes his head, "When I was 12 and I made my first ever trade at the Flimont City Stock Exchange. That...that was the only time the old man ever smiled at me and he meant it."
Paul nods, "Oh, yeah. I remember that. It was a big deal, back then, wasn't it? You made like, 3 grand or something like that?"
Luciano fondly recalls, "$3461.16. It was late in the evening, and I had just come back from school." Damn! He even remembers the cents!
LDJ goes on, "Traffic was light and dad said we should take our Rolls-Royce. Damn, I fucking loved the high I got from making that trade and watching those numbers go up! The feeling of having all that money, being able to do whatever the fuck you wanted. It was great."
Paul smiles, "Yeah, it was. I remember how happy you were. Practically ecstatic and uh...over the moon. You even got yourself a new pair of sneakers, right?"
LDJ grins, "Yeah, I did. Man, that was the best goddamn day of my life! Even better than the time I lost my virginity or kissed a girl. That trade I made a--and seeing my dad smile at me...it was THE best feeling in the world."
Paul pats his buddy's shoulder, "You're gonna get there again, Luciano. Soon enough, we'll both be swimming in so much money that we'll both forget about all the bullshit from our pasts."
"Heh. Yeah. Remember that pact we made?"
Paul smiles from ear to ear, "How could I forget? Never get married, never get cooties, and never share any of our cash with another girl. Oh, yeah, abso-fucking-lutely. We promised each other that we'd make it big and be the kings of Flimont City. No matter what."
LDJ proudly chuckles, "And now we're getting there. Soon enough, they'll be kissing my ring and bowing before me. And they'll all be asking for my secret sauce. It'll be a line of losers all the goddamn way from here to Peppy's!"
Luciano does a waving gesture in front of himself, "But I'll tell 'em ALL to fuck off, cuz LDJ doesn't share his cream with nobody!"
Paul laughs along with his buddy. They've been friends since they was in diapers, and they've been through thick and thin together.
The 2 of them have shared many experiences together, but there is a certain...superficial quality to their "friendship". If anything, it's more like a business partnership than anything else.
Paul knows this, and he's fine with it, for his part. He's never been one to get too attached to people. Luciano, on the other hand, is a bit different.
LDJ clearly lives in the long and overarching shadow of his ruthless father. Everything Junior is doing (or intends to do) is for the sole purpose of impressing the old man. He can tell himself otherwise, but that's the truth.
Luciano Donovan Sr. has always been a tough act to follow. He's been a successful (and brutal) stockbroker for decades and he's built up quite the (nastily unpleasant) reputation in Flimont City.
So far, like daddy like son. But Junior wants to be more than just a carbon copy of his father. He wants to be the go above and beyond and be the BEST. And he's willing to do whatever it takes to achieve that insanely deluded goal.
Even if it means resorting to illegal and immoral means. However, in LDJ's case, the means are more...supernatural in nature. Preternatural, perhaps. Of course, there's a fair degree of illegality involved.
Not to mention, coercion.
Anyhoo...
Gordon Pym arrives a few minutes later than when he said he would. He's carrying a briefcase with him and is dressed as sharply as ever. His cravat is orange, and his light-gray suit looks like it came straight from the drycleaners.
He's wearing his usual silver-framed eyeglasses and has his hair neatly parted. Gordon greets the 2 wunderkinds with a curt nod and a firm handshake.
Paul looks like a mess. Gordon grimaces at this but he refrains from opining on the matter. Instead, he focuses on Luciano.
LDJ claps Gordon's back and says, "Good to see you, Gordo! You got everything ready? C'mon, talk to me. Let's deal with this Reed bozo."

The usually stoic and unmoved Pym Reaper has a very troubled expression on his face. Even his voice sounds different.

Gordon snorts and gives Paul a dirty look, "Oh, believe me, Mr. Cho, it's worse than I could ever imagine. Or maybe I'm just making mountains out of molehills over here. Hmph."
LDJ furrows his brow, "What do you mean? What's going on? It's just 1 fucking Federal Government clown; how bad can it be?!"
Gordon's face twitches, "I--I don't know, Luciano. Part of me wishes I never ever heard the name Markham Reed. Hell, part of me wishes I didn't get in touch with Strickland's people to get rid of him. Maybe paying him off was a...better idea. Maybe."

He mirthlessly lets out a strained chuckle, "Still, it does have some great property values if either of you are ever interested in buying something there."
P-Money starts playing with his nose. He sniffles and makes all sorts of weird noises. LDJ glares at his friend and motions for him to stop.
Paul does so, and he looks away, embarrassed.
Gordon shakes his head and continues, "I looked around the place, did some snooping on my own. I asked a few questions here and there. It was hard to find anybody who knew Markham Reed."
LDJ growls impatiently, "OK, OK. So, what'd you find out?"
Mr. Pym vaguely states, "I found A Markham Reed. There was a small 'fraud investigation' firm in Greenridge. Employee records were hard to come by, but I have my ways."
Paul sniffs loudly, "And?"
Gordon takes some air into his lungs and exhales slowly, "I spoke with some of Mr. Reed's old co-workers. There was some guy named...uh, something Moskowitz. He and Reed used to work together, apparently."
LDJ grunts, "What'd he say, huh? C'mon, spill the beans! This isn't story time! It's almost lunchtime and I'm hungry!"
The Pym Reaper responds, "Well, nothing much. Or nothing useful to us, at least. Just a lot of talk about how Markham Reed was a pretty quote-unquote 'closed off' kinda guy. Didn't talk much about himself, and he kept to himself...very much so."
Paul nods, "Yeah, OK, what's up with that? Not exactly news, is it?"
Gordon shakes his head, "No, no, it isn't. But...the more I looked into Markham Reed, the more I got the feeling that there was more to it than that. Something...something else was going on."

A look of clueless confusion crosses Paul's face, "Uh...so what? What the hell? How the...? How is that even possible? He--he should either be 70-something or dead by now."
Gordon's face is now ashen white, "There's more to him than meets the eye. I did further digging and found out about his 'older' sister, too. She died in a hit-and-run."

What a repulsive asshole.

LDJ sits back down and angrily kicks the coffee table, "FUCK! FUCK! FUCK! FUCK! FUCK!"

He states, "It was just a mishap of some kind. It happens. Even professionals get sloppy every now and again."
Paul lightly smacks Gordon's arm, "Heh, you're talking from experience, huh? I thought YOU were always on your A-game, Mr. Pym Reaper."
Gordon frowns, "I am. But even I have a few mistakes in my closet." His head is turned aside, and his mind is seemingly elsewhere. He's got a fairly blank look on his face.
In his case, it's a whole lot more than a few whoopsie-doopsies!
Luciano announces, "OK, so it's been decided! C'mon, lunchtime! Gordon, you're coming with!"
Paul rubs his hands together and bites his lower lip, "Oh, yeah! I'm starving! Let's go, guys! Let's eat!"
Gordon lazily stands up and trudges along with the 2 wonder boys. He's still feeling very uneasy about the whole situation. There's something about Markham Reed that doesn't quite add up.
He's not sure what it is yet, but he's determined to find out.
Of course, he could never know (or be allowed to know) that Markham Reed is a Kindred, hence the inconsistent records.
This only begs the question: how did Mr. Reed manage to successfully apply for a job at the SEC in Seattle? Well, that thanks to some good ol' fashioned forgery.
Thanks to Darla, the blue Nosferatu lady, and her prowess in regard to such matters, Markham Reed was able to pass the background check and everything else with flying colors.
Even then, the SEC's background checks weren't exactly the most thorough and rigorous in the world. Sure, they're pretty good, but they're not perfect and Darla's excellent forgeries held up pretty darn well under the scrutiny, all things considered.
Of course, it's a different story when it comes to someone like Gordon Pym. He seemed to be a lot more stringent and thorough in his background checking and what have you.
Markham Reed is not the average (mortal) Joe. The next hitter sent after the Baali would soon learn that the hard (and fatal) way.
The trio arrive at none other than The Heartland Grill And Bar. Traffic was rather dense on the way here and it's sunnier than usual, not to mention the cops swarming the streets.
LDJ flashes his golden membership card and is ushered to a table for 3. On the way up, he spots Marcus Lancaster sitting at a table, all alone and reading a finance magazine of some sort. He's got a briefcase right next to him.
Luciano calls out, "Hey, Marcus!"
Marcus looks up from his mag and blinks, "Huh? Wha...? Who?"
Luciano briskly walks towards him and shakes him, "Hey! It's me! What are you doin' here, huh?"
Marcus gulps and awkwardly states, "Um, I--I was hungry and..."
Paul guffaws and elbows his buddy, "C'mon, Luciano! I'm hungry!"
Luciano looks at Marcus from head to toe and suggests, "Join us...ya fucking party animal! C'mon, it'll be fun! Hey, Gordon! Get over here, I wanna introduce you to someone!"
The Pym Reaper does his usual sigh-groan and complies. He waddles over to Marcus Lancaster's table.
LDJ puts his hand around Gordo's shoulders and makes the necessary introduction, "This here is Gordon Pym."
Marcus's jaw almost drops, "Y...you're THE Gordon Pym? The Pym Reaper? Man, you got a helluva rep, dog."
Gordon raises his chin and sternly regards Mr. Lancaster, "Hmph. My reputation precedes me, yes. And you are...?"
Marcus's eyes twinkle, "Marcus Lancaster. Stockbroker extraordinaire." He extends his hand.
Gordon shakes it firmly, "Ah, yes. Lancaster. Clarence Lancaster is your grandfather, right?"
When that's mentioned, Marcus's expression sours, "Yeah, grrrfgh. Don't ever try to mention him in the same sentence as my name again. Ugh."
LDJ laughs, "Yeah, yeah. So, why the long face, huh?"
Marcus shakes his head and lazily waves his hand, "Let's just go and eat. C'mon."
Lunch is pricey (of course it is, in a place like this). The boys verbally circle jerk each other and make big and grandiose plans for the future, meanwhile Gordon eats his food quietly and observes the 3 of them.
The blah blah blah is about their financials being in the green, shit like that. Fairly banal and utterly meaningless stuff.
Gordo's a very private man. There's not much to be said about him, and he doesn't say much, either. He sips his drink, goes through his chicken parm in minutes, throws his part of the bill down on the table, and takes his leave.
Luciano groans and calls out, "Dammit, Gordo! We're not done talking yet! We have shit to discuss! Sit your ass back down!"
Paul lightly scoffs, "Just let him go. He knows what he's doing, man."
Gordon concurs with Mr. Cho and saunters off to go and meet with Mr. Strickland. Time for "Contract Out On Markham Reed: Part Deux"
Part Une went so well, didn't it?
It isn't long before Mr. Pym finds himself in the back of a van, smelly burlap sack on his head. The van ride is bumpy and long. Gordon is practically dripping from every pore in his body, and he's worried that he's about to suffer some kind of a heatstroke.
After 60+ minutes of the most miserable ride in his life, the van stops, and Gordon is escorted out of the vehicle. The sack is ripped off and Mr. White gestures to where Mr. Strickland is standing.
Gordo's vision is blurred, so he takes a few seconds to readjust to the sudden change in light. He almost tumbles over, but Mr. White steadies him.
Gordon glares at the assassin, "It's fine. It's fine. Now, where is he?"
Mr. White grins and licks his lips, "Right over there."
Gordon looks around and sees that he's under some kind of overpass near the city's outskirts. Mr. Strickland's back is ramrod straight and there's a leashed poodle beside him. The poodle has a collar, and the tag is very noticeable.
Mr. Strickland has a smug look on his face as Gordon tiredly walks up to him.
"So, here we are, Mr. Pym."
Gordon pops his neck and groans as he feels a stiffness in his joints. "Yeah, yeah. I'm here. So are you. Is all the driving around and sack-on-the-head thing really necessary?"
Mr. Strickland raises his chin as a few vehicles zoom by overhead, "Oh, yes, absolutely. You have to be careful about these things, you know? I take Operational Security very seriously, Mr. Pym. It's 1 of the many reasons why my organization has been able to thrive for so long."
"Hmph. Even then, I'm not a nobody--"
Mr. Strickland lifts a finger, "Ah, ah, ah. Yes, your reputation does precede you, but I have had to take certain measures...in light of recent events. I'm sure you can appreciate that, hmm?"
Gordon grumpily states, "Yeah, yeah. Just get on with it."
Mr. Strickland's lips curl in an ugly and unsettling grin, "Very well. You're here about our shared enigma, aren't you? Markham Reed."
The small, white-furred poodle starts to wag its tail and even goes to lick Gordon's shoes. Gordo grimaces and lightly shoves the mutt off with his shoe.
Mr. Strickland gently commands, "Darlene, arrt (FR: stop). Talon (FR: heel)!"
The poodle immediately stops, sits on its haunches, and stares up at Mr. Strickland, tongue wagging like crazy.
He tells Gordon, "See? She knows her place."
Gordon sighs and remarks, "Didn't take you for much of a dog guy."
Mr. Strickland shrugs and cracks a slightly wan smile, "Oh, I am quite the animal lover, Mr. Pym. I have 3 cats at home and this dog used to belong to a target."
Gordon looks down at the poodle and wonders out loud, "'Used to'?"
Mr. Strickland's eyes reflect something menacing, "Indeed. The target was taken care of by 1 of my soldiers. Such a fine thing ought not to be put down in some godforsaken shelter, so I...adopted her, seeing that her previous owner had expired. I couldn't bear the thought of a lovely creature like this being whacked."
Mr. Strickland crouches down and lovingly pets the poodle's head, "I like to feed this city's pigeons every now and then, and I am a bit of an avid birdwatcher. They're such...fascinating creatures."
Gordon is unimpressed and dryly states, "So much for your operational security. If you're telling me all this, then that means you're not as discreet as you think you are."
Mr. Strickland chuckles, "What can I say? I am something of a misanthrope. I much prefer the company of animals over bipedal creatures. Humans, especially, are so...lacking in any kind of a sense of refinement and loyalty."
He strokes the dog's head some more and adds, "Regardless, I shepherd the brave men and women under my command. And my soldiers do need their general as of late."
"Hmm. Fun. So, about Markham Reed. $60,000 like last time. And please make sure he stays dead, this time."
Mr. Strickland raises an eyebrow, "Don't tell me how to do my job, Mr. Pym. What happened last time was...unfortunate, yes. But slip-ups and bumps are to be expected in this line of work; even I can't prepare for ALL eventualities and worst-case scenarios."
Gordon stares out into the vastness, "So, you're telling me that even the best hitters in the world can't always guarantee a certain outcome? Hmm."
Mr. Strickland faintly grunts, "I don't need your snide comments, Mr. Pym. It shan't happen again. I've had my people trail this Reed fellow for the past few days."
"Anything interesting?"
"Only that he's ever seen at nights and manages to shake off and lose my people every single time."
Gordon mucks around with his cravat and blandly muses, "That's something, at least. How many hitters are we talking about? A squad?"
Mr. Strickland shakes his head from side to side, "You let me and my people decide how to best go about this, Mr. Pym. You're paying for a dead body, not the details."
"Hmph. Whatever. And if any of you screw up again--"
Mr. Strickland takes on a more ominous tone, "You'll what, hmm? Like me, you're a professional; these kinds of threats are beneath you. Just have the cash ready. And keep an eye out for day-after-tomorrow's news." There's a smug and self-assured look on his face.
He goes on, "This Markham Reed is our enigma. I did some digging into him. Needless to say, 1 bottle of Aspirin wasn't quite enough to drive away the headache I had got when going through this man's records. The guy's a bit of an odd duck."
"Is that so? What do you know? Who are your sources?"
"I seem to know about as much as you do- judging by the desperation in your voice. As for my sources, I still have a few contacts in intelligence. They're quite forthcoming with me."
"Hmph. I see. I'll keep an eye out for day-after-tomorrow's news, I guess."
Gordon turns around and begins to walk off. Mr. Strickland doesn't say anything, but his dog, Darlene, follows Gordon with her beady poodle eyes.
Mr. White is leaning against the van, arms folded and looking as menacing as ever. He silently presents the same burlap sack to Gordo and holds the back door open for him.
Mr. Pym's brow furrows as he looks up at the overpass, "Oh, great. You know, just bonk me over the head. I feel nauseous with that fucking thing over my head."

Gordon grabs it and holds it close, "What's up with this piece of cloth?! It smells disgusting!"
"I dunno. I think someone jerked off in there once! Hahahahaha!" Mr. White chortles and cackles.
Gordon rolls his eyes and puts the burlap sack on his head as Mr. White gets him all settled in the back.
The Pym Reaper mumbles, "Professionals my ass."
The drive is mercifully short this time, and Gordon is somewhat grateful for that.
Mr. Strickland spots a few pigeons nearby. He reaches into his coat's pockets, for some bits of bread, and tosses them over to the hungry birdies.
As he's feeding the birds, a woman approaches him. She's quite stocky and her platinum blonde hair is tied into a tight ponytail. She's got a few faded scars here and there.
She firmly salutes her general and maintains a stiff upper lip.
Mr. Strickland salutes her back and gives her a warm smile, "Ah, hello, Ms. Blue. Keeping well?"
"Yes, sir!"
"Good. I have a job for you. Ms. Green and Mr. White have further details for you. Everything else is in the dossier."
Ms. Blue asks, "This the asshole who took out Daniel Percy, sir?"
Mr. Strickland nods, "That would appear to be the case, yes. I don't know how Reed did it and Daniel's body still hasn't been found. This is a...unique case. Ms. Green and Mr. White are the ones that you need to talk to. This one requires a certain finesse. A certain...subtlety."
Ms. Blue's expression hardens, "Understood, sir! S--Should I go at it alone or take backup along?"
Mr. Strickland replies, "If you're fine with splitting the fee with someone else. Otherwise, go at it solo. I leave that to your discretion, Miss Blue. Ms. Green and Mr. White have some additional intel for you. Dismissed, soldier."
Ms. Blue salutes her boss and trots over to her car. It's a shiny sedan with darkened windows. She gets in her car and starts prepping herself for the hit that's gonna go down tomorrow night.
She starts making plans. She hits a few gun stores, studies a few maps, and checks her weaponry. She's decided to go at it solo, so she doesn't have to share the 60K (minus Mr. Strickland's very small cut) with anybody else.
Her mind is sharp, and her training is very thorough. She's a seasoned veteran of this grim line of work and is very good at what she does.
Mr. Strickland looks up at the overpass once more. He checks his watch and tells his poodle, "I have another meeting in a few hours' time, Darlene. People are exhausting, but alas. They do pay well."
Darlene barks a few times as way of response.
Mr. Strickland continues, "The job will be done soon enough. We're not leaving anything to chance this time. Markham Reed will meet his maker, and this can finally be put to rest. It's never too good to dwell on the past."
The poodle wags her tail and licks her master's shoes. He doesn't seem to mind the dog's affection.
The FBI's Special Affairs Division was already nearing the city limits. The afternoon heat is vicious. It's now 5 PM. The sun will soon set, and that means the Kindred in this part of the globe will awaken from their daylight rest.
Time drags on, with the sun gradually moving across the sky. Gordon is back home, fast asleep in the comforting familiarity of his own bed.
On the road, an SUV is driving down the highway, almost passing the speed limit. The radio is playing a catchy song, and the passengers in the car are focused as can be.
Special Agent Cuomo and Agent Heartley are in the back, discussing and going over some things. The driver is in the front, eyes glued to the road ahead.
The city is bathed in an almost ethereal orange-pink hue. The SUV is speeding down the highway, on the way to what'll act as a temporary field office for the SAD.
Special Agent Cuomo sniffs and wipes some sauce from off the corner of his mouth, "Ugh. This is why I never go for double cheeseburgers."
Agent Heartley shrugs, "Eh, sometimes the flavor is worth it, boss."
"Hmm. So, you read that file on that so-called 'asset' we're supposed to be meeting up with soon?"
"Hff. What file? 90% of it was redacted! Who the hell is this guy?"

Agent Heartley throws her head back and clicks her tongue, "Oh, if he's ours, then maybe we play ball with him, y'know?"
"Sure. I just don't like walking into shit blind. You know that."
Agent Heartley's face hardens, "I know that, Harold."
She pauses for a moment and stares at the scenery whizzing by.
Special Agent Harold puts his hand on her tense shoulder and asks, "So, what's the deal? How's your family doing? Kids still raising hell back home, huh?"
Agent Heather wistfully watches the blue skies above, "Yeah, they're doing good, sir. Youngest just lost his 1st tooth, so he's making a big thing out of it. The oldest one's having a bit of a rough patch, but she'll bounce back."

Agent Heartley pulls out a photo of her 2 children. It was taken a few years back and is a bit worn around the edges. She looks at it, smiles, and looks at her boss, "They're why I'm doing what I do."
Special Agent Cuomo is lost in "deep" thought and snaps out of it when he hears his subordinate.

Whoa.

The FBI's Special Affairs Division is now in the city proper. Agent Heather gently tucks the photograph of her kids away.
After a few more minutes of silently wading through the traffic build-up, the SAD vehicle pulls up to a large building. It's gonna be the temporary base of operations for the SAD.
It's a nondescript, 3-story building with no windows and reinforced steel. On paper, it belongs to this and that shell corporation, and the name on the deed changes every few months or so.
It's not like it's the first time the SAD has had to use a place like this. But it's a very good thing that it's so nondescript and doesn't really stick out amongst the sea of similar looking buildings in this area.
Special Agent Harold Cuomo and Agent Heather Heartley step out of the SUV and look around. They're in a pretty deserted locale. There are not that many people around. No pigeons are flying overhead and noises from the street are muffled.

Special Agent Cuomo is ready to brief his fellow goons on what's going on.
An hour later...
The sun begins its drama-less descent in the sky. The clouds up above are few and far between, and the city's skyline is slowly transforming from the deep blue that it was a few minutes ago, into a deep and dark indigo.

This is gonna be 1 hell of a talk!

Agent Heartley is still feeling a bit wary around this creepy old dude who runs an organization that kills people (and kids) for large sums of money. The way Mr. Strickland affectionately strokes and pets his cat is (also) unsettling, to say the least.

I do what I do because I believe it's my duty as a citizen of this great nation of ours, and that is the extent of my involvement."

Agent Heather incredulously asks, "That easy, huh? What's your angle here? What's the catch?"

Special Agent Cuomo gets a bit annoyed, and he squares his jaw, "Your file said you were MACV-SOG."

Agent Heather fiddles with her shirt collar, "Yep. That's...us. Fighting the enemy within, the treasonous, the traitors, the terrorists."

Special Agent Harold perches an eyebrow, "'We'?"

Agent Heather sniffs and crosses her legs, "The '3 things' being...?"

Agent Heather clears her throat and wordlessly shuffles in her seat.

Mr. Strickland blinks and takes a deep breath, "So you say. In truth, I've never heard anything about this. If there were bioterrorists plotting something here in Flimont City for that long, then I would've known about them. It's my job to know these things, you see--"
Agent Heather interrupts, "These...bioterrorists are some sneaky sons of bitches. They stop at nothing to blend in and fly under the radar. Just admit that some things do actually happen right under your nose."
Mr. Strickland's eyes widen for a split second, and he retorts, "I assure you, Miss Heartley, that I am acutely aware of what goes on in this city. Then again, I'm sure you both have your reasons for...withholding intel from me. Regardless, I do look forward to working together."
The blue-eyed Ragdoll cat yawns and stretches out. It purrs softly and licks Mr. Strickland's fingers.
He gently pets the cat's head and smiles, "It would be a shame, however, if we weren't to get along. Ah, well. I will make sure that any assistance I can offer is of the highest quality. We only wish to see Americans remain safe. That's our common goal, yes?"
Special Agent Harold looks around the cramped room, "Yeah, freedom and security. We'll do our jobs, and if we need help, we'll come to you."
He glares at the guy petting his cat and firmly commands, "Don't interfere with our op and don't get in our way. Are we clear on this?"
Mr. Strickland's face becomes devoid of emotion as he looks at Special Agent Cuomo, "Crystal. I am, after all, quite an order-follower. Now, I give 'em out, but I know when to defer to those with a differing clearance level. Don't worry, Special Agent Cuomo. We'll stay out of your way."
He continues with a request, "All I humbly ask is that you and your people refrain from harming any animals, if you would be so kind. People are fair game, of course. But the rest of these critters are precious to me."
Mr. Strickland picks up his cat, stands up, and leaves the room. He ends the talk on his own terms, it would seem. He stands by the rusty door and holds it open for the FBI-SAD duo.

Agent Heartley turns to Special Agent Cuomo, "Whoa. What the hell was that? I know this guy's ours, but HOW? Is he on the payroll, did someone flip him, did he turn state's evidence, did he--"
Special Agent Cuomo wipes his face and mutters, "Fuck me, this is a crazy mess, Heather. This shit's above both our paygrades combined. I think...I think we're gonna have to be play nice with him."

Agent Heather shrugs and picks up the pace back to the SUV, "Fair enough. He just gives me the, I dunno, heebie-jeebies, ya know? Some people just make your skin crawl the more you look at them and sit down to talk to them."
"Hmph. Good instincts. Yeah, we'll have to keep a close eye on this guy. It's a bit too late to kick him to the curb, so we work with him and get what useful intel we can get outta him."
Special Agent Harold climbs into the SUV. Agent Heather follows suit. He taps the back of the driver's seat and commands, "Drive."
"Sir." The SUV roars to life, and it starts speeding back down the highway.
Special Agent Cuomo looks uneasy and he spends a few minutes, deep in silent and grim thought.
Agent Heartley glances at her boss and notices his furrowed brows and the tightness of his jaw. She leans closer and whispers, "He's a bit of a weird guy, huh?"
"Mm-hmm. Between me and you? I don't trust that son of a bitch 1 bit."
"Oh."

Agent Heather's eyes widen, "What?? He--he's intelligence, sir! You really wanna go after 1 of our own?"
Special Agent Cuomo doubles down on his suspicions regarding Mr. Strickland, "Agent Heartley, when I give you an order, I except you to follow it without question, without second-guessing me, without--"
Agent Heather sharply interrupts, "But, sir, it's against all kinds of protocols! HE'S INTELLIGENCE! He's practically untouchable from where we're standing!"

Special Agent Harold lowers his voice and continues, "You're right, Heather. He's 1 of us. If we're gonna be working together, then we gotta play nice with each other. I'll do that dance, for now. But the second we're done with the blank bodies, we go after him."
His tone leaves no inch for arguing.
Agent Heartley sighs softly, "Yes, sir. Just don't say that I didn't warn you. If anyone finds out that we're--"

"Well...if the higher-ups find out..."

"Hm. Yeah. Sun's down. That usually means those creepy fucks are coming out to play, huh?"

"Yeah, I'd hate to think what my 2 kids would do i--if mom doesn't make it home alive."
Special Agent Cuomo lazily pats her, "Don't worry, Heather, you'll get to be there for all their moments- prom, recital, graduation, whatever. You'll get to be there for all of it." He smiles at her, but it's not entirely reassuring.
"Thanks, sir. That--that means a lot. And um...about Mr. Strickland?"
"Mm-hmm. We'll watch him, and when the time is right, we'll get him. For now, I'm laser-focused on the blank body 'bioterrorist' threat in this city. That's our primary focus."
"Yes, sir."
The FBI's Special Affairs Division is now officially in Flimont City. The SAD is officially a part of the Second Inquisition's Coalition. The Coalition itself has "branches" all over the world.
The Coalition itself is an illicit and covert multinational conspiracy within many intelligence services and the Vatican (yep) dedicated to hunting vampires and other entities that go bump at night.
From the FBI's SAD (amongst others) in the US of A to the UK's Branch 16 (again, among others) to Israel's notorious Unit 8211 to Brazil's BOES, this shit is international!
And those are just the Coalition Orgs aligned with various oppressive governments and repressive alphabet agencies! There are also private (corpo), academic, vigilante, religious, and unaffiliated Orgs out there, too.
But those are for another time!
In Flimont City, the FBI (along with the SAD) are here to "officially" investigate a possible bioterrorist threat and put down the same. Unofficially, however, they're here to ram stakes in vamps, capture a few (if possible), blow shit up, burn places down, and more.
The sun has fully set now. The world outside is darkening. Streetlights lazily flicker on, cars clog the streets as evening traffic builds up to an agonizing peak, and the city's bustling (Un)nightlife is in full swing.
Clarice, the Malkavian Primogen, was suspended in the pulls of her day-sleep by an hour. As she's coming to, her eyes flutter open and she blinks.
She looks around her, and she doesn't recognize anything. Everything around her is so trippy- colors not on the standard visible light spectrum dance around, and shapes that are almost beyond her comprehension flit in and out of view.
Clarice is on some sort of a high, and she's having a bad trip. A real bad one. Well, that's what tends to happen when one ingests LSD prior to one's Embrace.
It was back in the 1980s and she's not sure what she was thinking when she took it, but it was a not the greatest of decisions, in retrospect. It's all a blur, really. She remembers her Sire "convincing" her to take it since she'd be dead (and reborn) in no time.
Then, she'd (presumably) forget all the bad stuff, and she'd just be happy, or something like that.
Her Sire had a wicked smile on his face, and there was a disturbingly crazy glint in his heterochromatic eyes.
As soon as the Lysergic acid diethylamide dissolved on her tongue and hit her brain, everything became a weird-ass blur as she felt her Sire's fangs sinking deep into her neck.
And the rest is history. Needless to say, Clarice's Embrace was a very bad trip.
Back to the now...
The Malk finds herself in...that place. The one that exists solely in the minds of ALL of Malkav's past and present Children- the Malkavian Madness Network.
Clarice is immediately hit by a barrage of voices from all directions.
"You don't stare at the sun!"
Someone else abruptly screams out, "THIS IS THE MARKET!"
"The tongs pull open the door."
Clarice pushes through the sea of voices, feeling that someone in the midst of this trippy madness is trying to reach out to her. The Malk Primogen hears the distant roar of the ocean waves, and she walks towards the source.
She can taste the salty, ocean breeze, and she can feel the warm sand between her toes.
Somebody calls out to her, specifically, "Clarice! Teacher! Schoolteacher! I--I saw something! I--"
Whoever that was is cut off by some steely-voiced gal calling out, "You can't hide, you sure can't hide, from th--the x-ray eyes! Hehehehehehe!"
Clarice pushes all those voices aside as best she can and trudges closer to what she believes is the source of the voice that called out to her by name.
She spots a very familiar-looking young man, dressed in a green, wool sweater. He's sitting cross-legged on the sand. He looks quite young, and his complexion is unhealthily pale.
Clarice's lips move, "Dallas? Is that you, darling? What's bothering you?"
Dallas gasps and looks up at his fellow Seer, "T--Teacher? Y--you're here, too?" he has a wild look in his eyes, and his pupils are blown wide. He looks like he's about to have a breakdown.
Clarice gently answers, "Of course I am. You dragged me all the way...out here. You said you saw something. Care to elaborate?"
Dallas starts mumbling, "Momo and Feather. Momo and Feather are here. SAD. Ess-Ayy-Dee. So SAD, so BAD, so FED, and it's not good! Oh no, oh no, oh no! Not good, NOT GOOD AT ALL! Bad, bad, bad, bad, bad! Oh no, oh no, oh no!"
Clarice gently commands him, "Calm yourself, Dallas. Use your words. Arrange them in a more coherent fashion. I'll hear you out, and we can discuss this. Come, come. Tell me."
Dallas's hands start shaking and he rocks back and forth. He whispers, "Momo and Feather...names. Faces, all blurry. Ess-Ayy-Dee. I'm so SAD! They--they're here, Clarice, here...for us."
The Malkavian Primogen, being a former schoolteacher, is accustomed to dealing with such antics and eccentricities.
She takes a deep breath and prods, "That's interesting, isn't it? But why are you so upset about this? Who are these Momo and Feather people? And what is this...Ess-Ayy-Dee that they represent?"
Dallas's eyes widen even more, and he looks like he's about to cry, "S--so much FIRE! Oh, god! FIRE! SCARY! SCARY! BURNS! IT RAGES on--on the 3rd f--f--floor! Oh, god! SAVE HER, someone, fucking save her! NOOOOOO! SAVE HER!!"
"Calm down, Dallas. You're going to fall into a Frenzy if you keep this up. Calm. Down. This isn't good for your mind," Clarice calmly chides.
"You--you don't understand, Clarice. It's already begun and--and there's nothing we can do to stop it!"
Clarice clicks her tongue and dismissively says, "Poppycock, Dallas. Poppycock. Nothing is set in stone. Whatever horrible things you're seeing can still be averted, but you have to work with me. Tell me what you've seen? I'm sure the Prince would appreciate it, too."
Dallas looks like he's about to go nuts. His eyes are darting around like crazy, "Momo and Feather, th--those are the names I saw in my--my vision. No--no good description of how they look, but they ha--have ill intent towards our kind, towards Kindred."
"Towards Kindred, hmm?" Clarice perks up, "Tell me more about this Ess-Ayy-Dee, and then tell me how these Momo and Feather individuals fit into the SAD."
Dallas takes a few moments to gather his scattered composure and then continues, "Ess-Ayy-Dee. SAD. Ah, yes, it--it makes sense. Uh--uh--FBI, I saw FBI clothing and FBI badges. I saw the lettering. Saw. The. Letters. S-A-D. It's not good. It's not good at all. Not good, not good, not good, not gooooooood."
"OK, interesting. Now, tell me, in your own words, how do these Momo and Feather people fit in all this?" Clarice's gaze is intense. She wants some damn answers. And some proper ones at that.
"I saw FIRE and a woman burning alive. I didn't see the woman's face, but--but her screams and her pain, and oh, god, there were steely claws and--and tentacles and machines and wires ta--taking her away as she--she was burning."
"Dallas..."
"Ma--machines. A big, bad, machine was claiming this chick and taking her away, and it--it was so, SO, so painful, but I think she was already g--gone by then. The machine, it, it was taking her apart and putting her back together. Rebuilding her and changing her."
Clarice sighs softly, "Forget about the machine and this burning woman for a moment. Tell me more about Momo and Feather and their connection to the SAD?"
Dallas starts mumbling under his breath. He looks like he's about to have another vampire equivalent of a panic attack.
Then, his head snaps up, and he's wide-eyed, "Feather and Momo...n--not their actual names, but it rhymes close enough. They--they are SAD. I sense them. They're here, Clarice, and I'm afraid. So very afraid."
The Malk Primogen asks, "They're here? In this Domain, right now?"
"Yes. Right now, yes, right now, right now, they are. They are. Momo and Feather. Feather and Momo. I'm scared, teacher. Will--will you protect us Lunatics from them? You're our Primogen, you HAVE TO, right?"
Clarice sharply exhales, "I will do my best, Dallas. Try, Dallas, dig deeper and see if you can give me just a bit more to go on. Names, locations, what they're wearing, how they look, et cetera."
Dallas's hands are shaking, "I, uh--uh, I don't think there's anything else tangible, Ms. Clarice. I'm so sorry, teacher. I was so overwhelmed by what I saw, and I knew that I needed to warn...YOU about it because you're the one who gets shit done on our behalf, y'know?"
Clarice nods, "Yes, you were right in summoning me here, Dallas. The visions can be overwhelming for us Seers. You haven't been with us for that long, so your grasp of your powers and abilities are a bit weak. No worries. You did good, kiddo."
The Malk Primogen's lips curve into a small, reassuring smile, "You did well, Dallas."
Dallas's eyes widen in surprise, "I did well? I did well!"
"Yes--"
"Holy shit! She said I did well, guys! Did you hear that! Guys? Gals? Where are you? C'mon, it's so silent here. Talk to me...someone, anyone? Hello?"
Clarice interjects, "Dallas, trust me when I say that it's not worth it. The voices, the shapes, the sounds, the colors, they will overwhelm a Fledgling like you. Your young Malkavian mind is trying to make sense of things that are beyond rudimentary understanding."
Dallas's lips quiver, "What do I do, then? I can't ignore this shit, Clarice! I get so lonely in here sometimes! The others, they just...they're not responding, and it's making me sad, and then I'm just alone in here with nothing but my thoughts, and it's not fun at all!"
Clarice sighs and responds, "Reach out to a few of them, but be VERY cautious when doing so. You're still a Fledgling, so your mind has yet to adjust to the intricacies of the Madness Network. Be patient and take your time. Don't try forcing it."
"But the voices are so loud! And everything in here is so...weird."
Clarice faintly chuckles, "You'll learn to block it out. We all did. We all have to. Not doing so could very well end with you falling into a Frenzy from whence there is no return."
Dallas mumbles, "The Wassail. I--I'd be turned into a senseless Wight, and you'd have to put me down like--like a mad dog."
"Mmm, yes, I hope that it does not come to that. You have so much potential in our Clan, Dallas."
"I--I know. I just feel so tight in my chest sometimes. It's all the stress, and the visions, and the voices, and, and--and...everything else in this damn city!"
Clarice calmly reminds him, "Don't fret, just remember my advice."
Dallas slowly nods and replies, "OK, OK, OK, I'll do that. I'll do just that. Oh, by the way, how's Arnold?"
Clarice warmly smiles, "My Ghoul fares well. I'll be sure to tell him you said 'hi'. Goodbye, Dallas. I've already overslept by an hour. I'll go to the Prince with your vision and see what he has to say."
"Buh-bye, Ms. Clarice! May the night be kind to you!"
"Likewise."
Soon after, Clarice feels herself waking up, and she's returning to her body. The next thing she sees is a ceiling and a fan lazily spinning around. The sky outside is dark. Her room is carpeted, the wallpaper is a mild shade of green, and a lone window is closed shut.
She slowly gets up from her bed and walks to the bathroom. Her reflection in the mirror is always a sight to behold- corpse-pale and almost ghastly-looking.
The Malkavian Primogen's Haven is a duplex house in a quiet suburban neighborhood. She shares this Haven with her Ghoul, Arnold. She's not bothered too much and mostly keeps to herself, and away from any HOA (Home Owner Association) drama and busybody neighbors.
Clarice looks around the bathroom and sees a toothbrush, toothpaste, a bottle of shampoo, a hairbrush, and other essential toiletries. There are no windows here.
After a quick bath, the Seer dresses up in something comfortable for the evening ahead- a grey wool sweater and a pair of black sweatpants.
The Malk makes her way down the stairs and walks through the hallway. She turns on the light in the kitchen, and the room is illuminated.
Her front door creaks open and her Ghoul enters. He's wearing a simple white t-shirt, a pair of blue jeans, and brown boots.
He beams at his Domitor, "Teacher! You--you're awake! You...um...'overslept' by an hour, so um...I didn't wanna disturb you, y'know in case you woke up and bit me. That sucks when that happens."
Arnold looks to be in his early-20s. His brown hair is short and cropped. His skin is fair and freckly, and he's got a fairly average build.
Clarice fondly pats her Ghoul's shoulder, "That's alright, Arnold. Thank you for respecting my day-rest. As it were, I was contacted by a fellow Seer right before my awakening."
Arnold sits on the sofa and joins his hands together, "Oh, cool. Who was it? Someone I know?"
"Yes, it was Dallas--"
Arnold grins, "Dallas! December 31st, 1999, 12:59 AM. He--he was made into 1 of us at--at that exact time, right?"
Clarice nods approvingly, "Very good. Yes, you're right. He was, quite literally, Embraced at the turn of the millennium!"
Arnold asks, "Millennium is 100, right?"
"No, it's 1000, Arnold."
Arnold suffers from certain developmental difficulties. Even when Clarice was a schoolteacher, the then-young Arnold had a LOT of trouble adjusting to and learning in a standard public-school environment.
He also had a lot of trouble fitting in and interacting with others.
Clarice was 1 of his teachers, and she did what she could, but Arnold clearly had special needs that the school was simply not equipped to handle. What does one expect in Ronald fucking Reagan's America of austerity and war, though?
The 1980s sucked.
Even back then, she felt a deep and genuine connection to her pupil, and she felt that she was destined to help him in whatever way she could. She helped him learn the basics and some more advanced stuff.
But that wasn't enough, nor was it the kind of specialized help he truly needed.
As Arnold grew older, he'd eventually cross paths with his former teacher. She took pity on him and made him her Ghoul. After 3 sips of Blood from her wrist, Arnold was essentially bound to a life of (more or less) eternal servitude to Clarice.
Arnold's a good guy who just got dealt a really shitty hand, and Clarice, for her part, is very protective of her Ghoul.
She cares for him as much as he cares for her. Arnold, from time to time, still calls his Domitor "Teacher" or "Miss Clarice" and it's kinda sweet.
The Malk Primogen and her Ghoul spend some time talking about things. Clarice gives him the basic details of the vision she had.
"I'll go to Prince Antonio with this, and we'll work something out from there."
Arnold asks, "Do you want me to come along?"
Clarice shakes her head and places her cold hand on her Ghoul's shoulder, "No. Prince Antonio is not the kindest or most...cultured of men. Were he to find out about your...differences, he'd surely tease you and be very mean to you."
"How would he be mean to me, Ms. Clarice?"
Clarice weakly smiles, "It's not wise to dwell on that, Arnold. Just...please, stay here. Lock the door and only open it if you see me. You don't want to draw any unwanted attention to yourself, yes?"
"Yes, Miss Clarice," Arnold dutifully repeats, just as if he were back at school.
The Malkavian cracks a tiny smile, but there's pain and sadness behind it as well. She gently pats her Ghoul's shoulder and tells him, "You've done good, Arnold. By the way, how was the toothpaste I bought for you? Was it the right brand?"
Arnold gives a double thumbs-up, "It was perfect! You know me too well, teacher."
Clarice nods approvingly, "I certainly do. We are, after all, bound by Blood. Did the police harass you this time?"
"No. I minded my own business, didn't go too far out, and didn't talk to anybody. They're still out there, with their guns, and they look so mean. I'm kinda scared. Can't you just bite them all and kill them? I--I don't like the police in this city, Ms. Clarice."
Clarice shakes her head, "I'm afraid that would go beyond a breach of the Masquerade. Now, I need to go see Prince Antonio. I'll be back later tonight, and I'll make you your favorite- Pop-Tarts!"
Arnold claps his hands and cheerfully replies, "Pop-Tarts! I love those! Yippeeee!"
"Of course. Lock the door behind me, and don't answer it for anyone BUT me. Yes?"
"OK, OK, OK, I'll do that!"
"Good."
Arnold locks the door and stands by the living-room window. His Domitor puts on a plain scarf and heads off to go and pay the Prince a visit and report on what she's seen and heard.
Which only begs the question, who are Momo and Feather?
Momo = Cuomo and Feather = Heather. Dallas's visions are usually scrambled and vague, but he gets the gist of what he sees (and hears) most of the time.
As Clarice is walking down the footpath, she feels a sharp pain in her head. Dallas, somehow, managed to reach out to her and contact her.
"Hey, yo, Clarice. I--I ordered some pizza. I'm not really too keen on going out tonight, so I figured why not bring the warm body to me, eh? Uh, yeah, bye."
Clarice feels her own Hunger rise. She sighs and looks around for a warm neck to sink her sharp and pointy fangs into.
Her neighborhood has quite a tree cover. The streetlights have already flickered on, and there are some people out and about.
A young man is walking his sausage dog. The poor creature is on a leash and looks absolutely miserable.
Clarice spots a young woman jogging by. She has headphones on and is looking straight ahead. The jogger is dressed in tight yoga pants, a tank top, and an open track jacket.
Her heart is beating loudly and strongly, and her blood is pumping vigorously. The Malk can feel the blood from where she's standing.
Clarice's fangs extend and she quietly follows the young woman. The jogger's neck is slender and bare, ready for the biting.
The jogger stops for a breather, the sounds leaking out from her headphones are quite loud.
Clarice silently sneaks up behind the mortal and quickly grabs her. Her sharp fangs sink into the soft, warm flesh of the young woman's throat.
Blood, lifeforce itself, flows out of the poor lass and into the ravenous mouth of a hungry Seer.
The Malkavian Primogen only takes what she needs. After a few more euphorically sanguine seconds, she releases the poor woman from her tight grip.
The mortal is barely able to stand and crumples to the ground. She's got a blank, vacant stare on her face. Clarice licks the wound shut and goes on her merry way.
Her Beast has been quieted...for tonight, at least.
The jogger chick might or might not remember this, but what's done is done. She eventually staggers onto her feet and runs back to her apartment, never to jog down this street again.
Elsewhere...
Before skipping town, Burt dropped by Diego's and Marisol's Haven and left a note for his Childe.
Markham is in the living room, fully dressed, showered, and ready for the night ahead. He is sitting on a sofa and reading through his Sire's note. The handwriting is quite something, alright.
It very much feels like 1 of them old letters from the Civil War era, where the handwriting is like something one would see in a museum of some sort.
After squinting and struggling to decipher his Sire's scrawling, Markham manages to read and comprehend what is written.
The Baali rockstar gives the usual advice: keep your Humanity high and your Beast in check, stay out of trouble, don't get involved with the politicking nonsense of the Ivory Tower, and don't break the Masquerade.
The letter ends: "Be good to those 2 Ferals who've given you a place to stay. And remember, kiddo: survival's the game we all play. But don't get complacent. Stay on your toes and don't lose sight of what truly matters on nights like these. It was good catching up with you again."
Markham puts the note aside and rests his head in his hands.
Marisol pecks Diego on his lips and heads off to work. She's used to finding fresh blood on the way. Diego sees his girlfriend off and closes the front door.
Diego and Markham have some time to chat.
The Gangrel throws himself on the sofa with a grunt and looks at his Baali friend, "So, hermano, what'd that letter say? That handwriting, whoa, it's like doctor's handwriting."
Markham chuckles and folds the note, "Burt says to 'be good' and 'stay out of trouble'. Oh, and not to get involved with the politicking bullshit of the Camarilla; can't say I disagree with him."
The Feral rubs his hands together, "So, what's tonight's plan?"
Markham adjusts the collar of his plain dress shirt, "I thought I'd catch up with...someone."
"Oh? So, you and that Rhonda chica got along quite well last night, eh?"
"Mm-hmm. She's a decent woman, Diego. I feel reminded of someone when I'm around her. Reminded of a person I can't forget. A person I will NEVER forget."
Diego slowly nods and dusts his cargo pants, "Well, you just tell me where it is you wanna go and I'll drop you off there."
"You know, Diego, I can always rent a car or flag down a taxi--"
"Nuh-uh. Nope. As long you're under our roof, I'm taking good care of you. Remember, a vato in distress is a vato we gotta help. You're no exception, homes."
Markham smirks a bit, "Well, that's kind of you, Diego, thank you. Really, I mean it. I need to make a few phone calls before we head out for tonight."
Diego stares off into the distance and ruminates out loud, "Man, I can't believe that your Sire's gone now. I'm gonna miss that Iggy Pop looking Gringo, haha! He was a real one, y'know? Seen a lotta shit. He knew what was up, that's for sure."
"Yeah, he sure did. Hm. I'll be a few minutes. I'm thinking about calling a couple of people and asking around."
Diego nods, "Sure, hermano, no problem. Take your time."
Markham takes a few moments to reflect. He can't help but wonder just how much longer he'll stay in this city. After being stonewalled by LDJ last night, he's not entirely sure how much longer this investigation will drag on for.
He also can't shake the feeling that something terrible is about to happen.
His Beast stirs within him, as does something darker and more sinister. It's a familiar(ish) sensation to the Baali Neonate.
Markham shakes his head and makes a few calls. He calls up his boss at the SEC, briefs him on the situation so far, and asks for any further advice on how to proceed.
Clifford responds with the same advice: just get it done.
After that, Markham calls up his Touchstone, Jamie. It goes straight to her voicemail, "You've reached the cellphone number of Jamie Pollux, the one and only, haha! Please leave a message AFTER the beeping beep bop boop and I'll get back to ya!"
Markham waits for the beeping bop boop and speaks, "Hey, uh, Jamie. It's me. Markham. Just checking up on you and seeing how you're doing. Hope everything's alright. Call me back whenever you get this and...stay safe out there, OK? Bye."
The Baali blows a raspberry and pulls out the card that Diana had given him last night. Her number is hastily scrawled on the back of the card. Markham dials the number and waits for a response.
Diana's voice answers, tired and weary, "Hello, this is Diana Moskowitz. Who's this?"
Markham smiles a bit, "Uh--hi, Diana, this is...uh...Markham. Reed. We bumped into each other last night. I hope I'm not, y'know, bothering you, or anything."
Diana loudly yawns, "No, no, it's alright. I was just...napping in my van after a cleanup job. So, what's up, Markham? You wanna um...grab a coffee or something? I could REALLY use a large, LARGE cup of wake-me-the-fuck-up-and-keep-me-awake juice right about now."
"Uh, sure, that sounds good. Do you mind if I ask a few questions?"
Diana sighs, "I've been fielding questions from creeps all day, and I'm not exactly in the mood to talk shop, so...ah, what is it?"
"You...still remember me?"
Diana sourly chuckles, "'Course I do! It's like you haven't changed since the day my dad had you watch over me, y'know? Or maybe I really need an eye checkup, heh. Anyway, you're one of the better ones. You're not an asshole, at least. I hope so."
"Oh, yeah, thanks, Diana. So, how is your dad doing?"
Diana bitterly groans, "Uch. He refuses to accept that I'm a woman now. Every time I try to call him up to say 'hi' or whatever, he curses me out and yells about how I'll 'never be a REAL woman' and how he 'can't believe he raised such a disgrace to the Moskowitz family name' and--and it--"
Her voice cracks and she pauses for a moment before continuing, "--And blah blah blah. It's all a bunch of bullshit, Markham. It's just a bunch of bullshit. My family's full of assholes. I'm sick of their shit, anyway."
"I'm sorry, truly, to hear that."
"Yeah, well, seeing you after all these years has kinda brought back a lot of memories, y'know. Not ALL bad ones, thankfully. We should catch up for some coffee, as--as long as you're paying. If that's OK with you?"
Markham plainly replies, "Sure. You know any good places around here?"
"Yeah, there's this Jersey Mike's knockoff on 10th Avenue called 'Uncle Steve's!'"
"Uh...OK? I'll meet you over there in a few. I have to take care of something, first."
"Sounds good. See ya then. Don't keep a lady waiting, yeah?"
Markham puts his Motorola flip phone away and joins Diego, who is still staring off into the distance, lost in his own thoughts.
Diego inquires, "Who was that?"
Markham dryly answers, "Someone from my past. I need to make sure that she doesn't get mixed up in any of this. The last thing I need is more complications."
Diego shakes his head and rises to his feet, "Yeah, less complications is the last thing any of us need right now. Let's go, hermano. I know a spot we can score some blood. Remember, no killing nobody. We don't need that shit on our consciences, right?"
The Demon nods in agreement, "Of course, always." He puts on his black trenchcoat and climbs into the Gangrel's pickup truck.
The night is young, and the hours stretch out ahead. Traffic is quite dense, and things move at a snail's pace. Diego idly hums and waits for a gap in the traffic.
Markham, meanwhile, thinks of the past few nights since his arrival in Flimont City. A lot has happened, and that's putting it mildly!
The Baali pulls out his flip phone and dials LDJ's phone number. It rings and rings until eventually, someone answers.
"Luciano speaking. Who's this?"
"Mr. Donovan, it's me. Markham Reed. I'm with the SEC and I was wondering if we could talk. I won't take up much of your time."
The phone is on speaker, and Gordon Pym is standing right next to LDJ. The former silently motions for the latter to keep talking.
Luciano clears his throat, "SEC, huh? OK, OK. What do you want?"
Markham remains as polite as ever, even after all the BS he's been put through, "I wanted to ask you a few questions, Mr. Donovan. There are some discrepancies in your financials that I'd like to speak to you and your associate about. Could we meet up sometime soon?"
Gordon silently gestures to LDJ, who rolls his eyes and grumbles, "Fine. Yeah, sure, why not? Tomorrow night, at 11:30. There's a parking lot a few...miles away from my joint. I'll um...have someone pick you up and bring you to me. We'll have ourselves a good, honest talk. That sound OK?"
Markham frowns a little, but he accepts, "Sure. That's great. Thanks, Mr. Donovan."
"Yeah, no problem. You know Hugo Street? Yeah, the parking lot's just right off the corner of Hugo and 7th. I'll have someone waiting for you over there."
"I'll keep an eye out. Thank you for your cooperation. I look forward to our discussion. And thank you for not abruptly hanging up on me this time."
Luciano stifles a scoff, "Heh, yeah. No problem. See ya."
Markham hangs up and turns to Diego, who is still driving.
The Feral snickers, "Man, you really gotta be wearing them kid gloves when dealing with those spoilt rich folk, huh? So, what did that cabrn (ES: bastard) say? Did he play the fool again or is he finally down for a talk?"
"We're meeting up tomorrow night. We'll have a nice, honest talk. All of this is going to come to an end, and I'll have a better idea on how to proceed with my investigation."
"Hah! It's about damn time. Man, you've only been here for a few nights, and you've already seen the worst of it, huh?"
"Mm-hmm. Maybe you and Marisol should really consider that move to Santa Fe or New Jersey or...anywhere but here, Diego. Anyway, it's not my place to tell you what to do. Just...there's something better out there, Diego. For the both of you."
Diego shakes his head and lets out a deep sigh, "I know, homes, I know. But we still got a lotta ties here, y'know? It's not just the house, it's the other Gangrel here. They're like mi familia. I'm not gonna just drop 'em and zoom off into the night."
He stops at a red light and wiggles around in his seat, "Besides, my girlfriend has her job going on, and I can't just tell her to...drop that, y'know? It sucks, but it's stable and enough for most of our immediate needs."
Markham's brow furrows and he nods, "Yeah. The stability is something you both need. Starting over in a different place wouldn't be easy, especially for us Kindred. The paperwork alone would raise so many red flags. Not to mention all the moving expenses."
"Oh, don't get me started on the moving, haha! You got that right, ese. Shit's not easy. We're Gangrel, not Ravnos. We can't just up and move on a moment's notice!"
"I've done this before. Moving's hard enough when you're just a mortal, but now..." the Baali trails off and stares at the numerous cars and trucks on the road.
Diego turns up the rap music blaring from his radio, "We gotta do what we gotta do to survive, y'know?" he drums his fingers on the steering wheel and drives on.
After a few moments of slowly wading through the traffic, the Outlander asks, "So, what's on your mind, homes?"

Gordon has placed a phone call to Mr. Strickland. The latter answers, "Yes?"

Heh.
It isn't long before Markham and Diego are at a fairly busy street. A few cars and trucks are parked on either side of the road. There are a few people walking along the sidewalk.
The air is thick with the smell of gasoline, car exhaust, and cigarette smoke. A few people are smoking outside of a bar.
Diego parks his pickup and points in a direction, "10th Avenue's that way. That's where that joint of yours is." He pats his clothes and locks the doors. Markham follows him.
The 2 Kindred stroll down the street, keeping their heads down and avoiding eye contact.
Both vampires go through the usual rigmarole of stalking, biting, feeding (no draining!), licking, and walking away. It's all very routine for both of them by now.
Diego casually stretches and wipes his mouth, "Ahh, man, that hit the spot. So, you OK here by yourself?"
Markham can feel his inner Beast has been satisfied for now, "Yeah, I'll be fine. Thanks, Diego. I'll see you later tonight." He pulls out his flip phone and checks the time.
The Baali looks around and sees scores of people going about their existences, moving to and fro, oblivious to the fact that they share the world with what are essentially bloodsucking creatures of the dark night.
He wonders if these people have any idea of the world of darkness bubbling right under them. Tomorrow, if the existence of vampires were proven, would they even care?
They'd be more worried about the things that actually matter, like paying the bills, school fees, rent, mortgages, taxes, and so on. Those are the things that many a mortal concern themselves with.
The mundane, ordinarily, everyday concerns of those that draw breath. Even if vamps, werewolves, and other such supernatural entities were proven to exist, they'd be considered "meh, whatever" compared to the more pressing matters of life.
And Unlife.
Even the undead have jobs to work at, bills to pay, and groceries to buy. The same old, same old. Markham can't help but wonder how long this city can go on like this?
He spots a few cops making arrests. He even observes a few others taking bribes from men in fancy suits.
The Baali's thoughts drift back to his investigation. It's been slow-going, but he's getting somewhere. Hopefully. Maybe. He hopes so. This is his chance to make sure that people in this city play fair and by the same set of rules as everybody else.
A tall order in the city of greed and lucre, but he's got to try.
Uncle Steve's! looks like it always has, albeit shinier. The parking lot is packed with vehicles. There are a few pedestrians milling about nearby.
Diana's van is parked out front and Markham slowly walks towards it. The Baali spots Diana counting some coins, meticulously checking each piece, and hoping that she has enough.

"Oh, sorry about that, Diana. So, coffee, right? I already...ate."

"You think he's up to something no good? What?"
Diana's coffee arrives and she thanks the server. The coffee cup is tall and steam rises from it. She douses some creamer and sugar into it and stirs.
"Something's fishy, alright. That fuckin' guy has always given me the creeps. You know that he recently bought and imported a nasty-looking Dalmatian."

Diana stirs her coffee some more and shrugs, "Ah, just going with the motions, Markham. Being a professional cleaner is my whole 'thing' now. Everything else just fades in the distance. I've got the whole, 'trying-to-keep-a-roof-over-my-head' thing to deal with, y'know?"

"Yeah. I'm behind on my rent and my landlord, like my 'lovely' boss, is a slimy greaseball. He's just, ugh..." the woman's face contorts into a tight grimace and she spits out, "I hate his fucking guts SO MUCH. And he's such a pervy creep! You wouldn't believe what he asked me to do."

The self-serving politicians, the brutish cops, the pliant media, the greedy speculators, the drug dealers, the sex workers, the homeless, the hungry, the poor, the desperate, the addicted, the hopeless, the lost, the forgotten, the disenfranchised, the angry, the violent, the victims, the survivors, and...
The Kindred, who might be in 1 (or more) of those categories.
Everyone is playing their part. Everyone is doing their thang. Everyone is surviving, cuz survival is the game we all play. Some have it on cruise, and many are barely hanging on.

The wheels are turning, the gears are grinding, the cogs are spinning, and the clock is ticking.

Some of these immortal blood-leeches have nothing to lose, some have everything to lose, and some have even found something (or someone) worth "living" for.
