His eyes are semi-bloodshot, his expression is contorted into an angry scowl. The old man is trembling, sweating, and breathing heavily. He's on the verge of having a full-blown heart attack, and he's clearly aware of this.
Jeremy's eyebrows shoot up, and he wrings his hands together. He calmly speaks, "Regardless of the reason for his disappearance, we have to keep in mind that the business could be at risk, even without him."
He slightly grimaces, "It's bad enough that we're on very thin ice with our recent clients, and it would be prudent for us to complete this project before things get any worse or--or out of hand."
A few board members nod.
Jeremy looks around the table, and motions for Sharla to take over.
She professionally smiles at him and nods, "Thank you." She continues, "We've gone over this at great length, Mr. Clarence. We have yet to agree on who shall lead the company in your son's absence. But this is not...well, the final step."
Clarence asks, "What do you mean by that? Just pick somebody as interim CEO and get it over with."
Sharla shakily laughs and replies, "Oh, if only it were as simple as that, sir. Your son had a plan of sorts. Were he to unexpectedly die or go missing, he wished for 1 of his 3 sons- Quincy, Tequan, or Marcus- to be appointed the new CEO."
Sharla continues, "As you can imagine, Mr. Clarence, we are in desperate need of your expertise in this matter."
Larry takes over, "Quincy is out of the question, of course. He has been, I was told, appointed as the CFO of Gen4 Security. Is this correct, Mr. Clarence?"
Clarence nods, "That is correct."
Larry proceeds, "Well, Tequan. I err...don't know whether a uhm...chiropractor would be suitable for us, haha."
Jerome chimes in, "He's also a homosexual. An openly gay CEO ain't something we can exactly roll with, especially now."
Some of the other board members nod in full agreement.
Larry clears his throat, "Yes, I see your point. So, that leaves...Marcus. His background as a stockbroker does show some promise."
Clarence shakes his head from side to side, "Nuh-uh. That ain't gon' happen. Ever."
Jeremy asks, "Might I ask why? Putting my friendship with your grandson aside, what is the reason behind your...strong feelings on the matter, Mr. Clarence?"
Clarence firmly replies, "Boy, you're young and you still have a lot to learn. Don't ask questions that you don't really wanna hear the answer to. It ain't gon' be Marcus. I'd sooner blow this whole fuckin' place sky high than hand it over to that goddamn failure."
The Lancaster patriarch has a bitter and foul look on his face. His eyes are blazing with hate and contempt at the very mention of Marcus's name.
Jerome blinks and shakes his head, "I--I see. Well, that don't leave us with many other choices, err...does it?"
Mumbles and grumbles echo through the room. No one wants to step in and take on the role of Lancaster-SYS CEO. Or maybe they do, and they're just playing coy, biding their time.
Jeremy sighs and sheepishly asks, "Forgive me if I am crossing a line here, Mr. Clarence. But what about your other grandchildren? Do you feel that there's anyone among them who'd be suitable for the role?"
Before the old guy can respond, Sharla cuts in and boldly queries, "Mr. Clarence, have YOU considered yourself for the role? It would certainly be good for the company, in more ways than 1."
Clarence slowly raises his chin and swallows hard. He looks at the other board members, and they look back at him, expecting an answer. Coherent, preferably.
After a long and tense minute of mulling over the possibilities, he finally manages to say, "Now that you've mentioned it, I'll be thinkin' about it."
Clarence shakes his head and grumbles, "Goddamn Marcus and the rest of those boys. I shoulda called them 'mistake' and then I shoulda called the damn orphanage soon after. Hrrrmhph."
Um...OK?
After that, the old bugger slowly, deliberately rises to his feet. His hands are trembling, and he's clearly in the midst of an arduous battle with his own body, but he pushes through, "I'll say it once: pick whoever you wanna pick...but make sure they ain't dumb and stupid."
Jeremy bows his head, "Of course, sir."
Clarence bitterly adds, "Oh, and 1 last thing. Don't even try to saddle me with this responsibility ever again. I'm an old man, and I need to be home in my damn bed. Now, get me the fuck outta here."
Larry's eyebrows go up and he smiles tightly. He shoots a knowing look at Sharla, who's sitting a few seats away from him.
"Yes, sir," Jerome answers with some relief. He promptly ushers Mr. Lancaster out of the boardroom. He even goes down with the old guy, making small talk and asking how his adult grandchildren are doing.
The door closes behind them, leaving behind the remaining board members, who sigh with relief, "Well, that's over with."
Jeremy exhales sharply, "Whew. It's eggshells on a minefield with that guy. I swear to God, I thought he was about to have a goddamn heart attack right here and now. Thank heavens that didn't happen. It would've been bad for our already-dwindling share prices, haha!"
A few people nod in agreement. Some even chuckle along.
Clarence is driven back home, and the remainder of the sweltering afternoon chugs along. It's hot and sweaty outside, but the board members are content knowing that a large and heavy weight has been lifted off their shoulders.
The board's "productive" discussions do eventually lead to the appointment of a temporary CEO for Lancaster-SYS. Until then, they'll be on the lookout for someone more suitable.
They all agree that Mr. Clarence Lancaster, the ex-CEO's father, is well, he's Clarence. But his experience, connections, and vast wealth are assets that they simply cannot afford to overlook.
There's a shimmering haze covering the city of Flimont. It's still very hot and muggy. The Lancaster-SYS building stands tall and ominous amongst the rest of the skyscrapers, which are nowhere near as grand as the dark obsidian structure.
From certain angles, it's quite photogenic. As a matter of fact, a photographer for a magazine once took a picture of the Lancaster-SYS building on a similar summer day.
The photograph in question was aptly titled: "OMINOUS".
Needless to say, Laurence didn't like that 1 bit when he got wind of it. He went ALL OUT to have the photographer fired and the magazine yanked from the shelves.
It got so bad that the poor photographer eventually took his own life. It wasn't until neighbors complained about a stench coming from his bathroom that he was discovered.
He was 20-something and he had his full life ahead of him, but the ego of a greedy and fragile CEO (same applies for the board members and shareholders, too) ruined everything.
When Laurence Lancaster goes all out in destroying or ruining someone, you better believe that he goes all-fucking-out. He had a reputation as being ruthless, determined, like an immovable object yet to meet an unstoppable force.
(That wasn't even the 1st time something like that has happened, either.)
Typical behavior of a large company's CEO- narcissistic, petty, vindictive, and egomaniacal to a fault.
(The system itself rewards, fosters, and incentivizes such foul traits, which in turn help to uphold and sustain the system.)
So, the fact that Laurence is AWOL right now is both good and bad for the den of coiling snakes at Lancaster-SYS. On the 1 hand, it's good because, well, there's an opening.
(The perks of being CEO are nuts! It's criminal!)
It's bad because of that very important, very secretive project that was supposed to be completed by now. It was due to be a big success for Lancaster-SYS.
If the plan fails, the whole company could be in trouble. And these are clients that you don't wanna piss off- ever! They're scary, shrouded in secrecy, and have the resources to end you on the spot.
But, again, there's an opening...and there are lot of folk in the board who are clamoring for that top spot. They all want to be the next CEO of Lancaster-SYS.
There's no rush, though. They know the value of the long game. They got time, connections, money, and power. It's just a matter of time, really. Those fancy shoes do be needing some filling!
So, what even happened to Laurence Lancaster in Magnolia City?
Ah, it involves the Kindred in that particular Domain. More need not be said...for now.
Anyhoo...
As the evening comes, the sky begins to glow with a dull orange hue. The air is warm and thick, but the residents of the city have been forced to become inured to this.
(It's called climate change, and it's not gonna get any better unless something's done about it).
The city is lit up with the brightest light pollution in the region, as the night begins anew. The Kindred are slowly roused from their day-slumber by the time the sun makes its full retreat.
It's another night for the city, another night of bustling with business, cars honking, people going here, going there, and so forth.
Dr. Collins twitches on his sturdy (and heavy) double bed, which is made of oakwood. This bed was a nightmare to bring to his bedroom. Even the strongest Brujah (using Potence) would have trouble carrying it.
But this bed is special to the good doctor. Why?
It helps him stay Grounded. That's the Tzimisce Clan Bane. It basically means that the Tzimisce MUST spend their day-sleep in VERY close proximity to the object (or objects) that Grounds them.
This can anything...or anyone. Thankfully, it's just the big ol' bed for the good doctor. Other Stokers have to day-sleep whilst surrounding themselves with the soil from the ground of their homelands.
Others probably have to day-sleep in the tattered clothes in which they were Embraced. It varies from Fiend to Fiend, really.
But what is the significance of this bed? WHY does it Ground him?
It was also, as it turns out, the very same bed he was Embraced on. It was back in the 1960s. Moving this thing around hasn't been easy these past 40 years, but the good doctor has managed just fine.
Ljudmila was the name of the woman who Embraced Dr. Collins. She hailed from what would eventually come to be known as USSR, but after Stalin and his bureaucratic cronies betrayed the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, she fled the country for the United States.
Ljudmila, for her part, was initially optimistic and excited about the changes that were to come. It was even said that there were some Tzimisce who enthusiastically took part in the 1917 Revolution, as did many other Clans and Bloodlines.
She had lived for so long, seen so much, and witnessed too much suffering prior to the October Revolution.
But...she was forced to bear witness to the gains of the Revolution being undone and usurped by a bureaucratic caste of those unfit to lead the working masses forward.
She did her best to hold out and fight back, but it was of no use sadly. Stalin and his goons usurped power, and the remaining good people were either purged (violently) or fled (to lands faraway).
After a series of gruesome purges and mass executions, the Soviet Union was a hollow husk of what it could have been. Whole generations of revolutionists, intellectuals, fighters, poets, artists, scientists, and more were tragically lost.
(Kindred were said to be amongst the numerous victims, but the overwhelming majority were mortals).
Ljudmila's Childer were among those who were destroyed during the Great Purge (or Great Terror) of 1936-1938. She was among the fortunate ones to have fled before the long knives were being sharpened.
Ljudmila lost all of her Childer to some crazy Stalin-aligned Brujah and Tremere who came ready and left absolutely no survivors by the time their carnage had concluded.
The rampage was terrible, and it was said that the traitorous Kindred were at it for nights, feeding and feeding and feeding, to the point where their veins were blackened with Diablerie.
(They were high on the Blood of their fellow Cainites. How terrible. Even Banu Haqim have their limits.)
After the bloodletting was done, those same Humanity-deprived Kindred had moved onto the villages and small towns nearby.
Ljudmila herself caught wind of the approaching horde of Diablerists. So, she made arrangements to be smuggled out of a small region in Georgia, and she went westward from there.
Ljudmila was able to successfully escape and flee the USSR. She spent some time in the Carpathian Mountains before arriving in the US of A.
It wasn't long before she would meet the then-mortal Dr. Collins. She took an interest in him. Even back then, he was diligent, professional, stolid, and knowledgeable. He was the perfect candidate for Ljudmila's fangs.
He was also a man who had no problem accepting the existence of the supernatural. Ljudmila did her best to rationally explain (and justify) the existence of vampires to the man.
Dr. Collins and the woman who'd go on to become his Sire had many an interesting conversation. She initially visited his small clinic to pick up some medicines for her Ghouls.
It was snowing outside, and the sky above was starless and dark.
Their talks were level-headed, amicable, and rather intellectually stimulating. They discussed their different beliefs and philosophies, and it was said that Ljudmila was greatly impressed by Dr. Collins's knowledge, experience, and understanding.
At that time, she had largely moved on. She still held out hope that the USSR could be saved. However, the assassination of Leon Trotsky in 1940 killed any semblance of optimism in her.
Of course, WW2 and the horrors that followed was the straw that broke the camel's back, so to speak. The Siege of Leningrad in 1941 broke her shriveled heart beyond repair.
800+ days of unspeakable horrors. And the Red Army had already been severely weakened by then.
The pain was apparent in Ljudmila's baggy eyes. Dr. Collins noticed this throughout their many talks. He prodded, but by the 1960s she had essentially given up on...hope itself.
The Stoker had, many times, contemplated walking out into the sun and ending it all. She spent most of the 1950s locked in her 1-bedroom Haven. She used her Ghouls to help fetch her blood, carry out some work on her behalf, and do what Ghouls usually do for their Domitors.
Her will was still strong back then, but her resolve was slowly breaking apart at the seams.
By the 1960s, she was a shell of her former self. A walking husk barely clinging on to the notion of Humanity itself. While she refrained from monstrous deeds, a part of her had become...numb. Numb to it all, really.
Dr. Collins perceptively picked up on her emotional state. He was initially given the choice of becoming her Ghoul, but HE urged her to Embrace him instead.
Ljudmila asked if this was what he wanted.
An equable "Yes" came out of his mouth, followed by a slight shrug of his shoulders. His last meal was a simple medium-rare steak.
In no uncertain terms did Ljudmila warn her future Childe about the MANY downsides of Unlife during the doctor's last dinner, but Dr. Collins simply wiped his mouth, washed his hands, and made his choice.
After washing his plate and throwing out the remains, Dr. Collins was led by the hand to the bed he would later die his First Death in.
He rationally explained to her that he, as an established physician, would be VERY interested in the possibilities of Kindred Unlife. To him, it was (and will always be) a matter of logic and reason, really.
Ljudmila was quite reluctant to take his soul. Him being easy with it took her aback as well. She knew that it was a 1-way ticket to an "afterlife" that was often quite horrific.
The remainder of the 1960s rekindled a small spark of hope in Ljudmila. Following the Embrace of Dr. Collins, she took interest in the happenings of that particular epoch- the Civil Rights Movement, the anti-war movement(s), and so forth.
She and her Childe would have many a(n) (Un)lively debate on the merits of these movements and the various social, political, and economic forces that drove them.
However, most of the middle-class protest radicalism was already fading away by the 1970s, and by the 1980s, a mutated form of reaction had set in.
Add to that the malignant and corrosive effects of the Stalinist (and Stalinist-adjacent) orgs, and it isn't too hard to see why Ljudmila had lost hope.
There were, at best, a few stragglers who held on to their old ideals, but others would either fade away or go on to make their peace with the new order (tm). Some would hold out.
And, of course, the Reagan/Bush Administration's policies only fueled the flames of greed itself. Joseph Raymond McCarthy merely planted the seeds.
An entire generation was left disoriented, defanged, and without any semblance of leadership and perspective. Sad.
Ljudmila withdrew herself from the outside world by the late 1980s. Her Ghouls did literally everything for her. She'd occasionally write to her Childe, and he'd reply in kind (or when he found the time to).
Her last ever letter came on the day the USSR collapsed- 26th December 1991. It was a painful letter. She had not expected it to end in such a...bitter manner.
It remained in the possession of the good doctor for many, many years. He'd occasionally take it out and read through it, mulling over the harsh words written therein, and the...strange object that she had sent along with it.
It's a solid and sharp fragment of the spaceship of the Tzimisce Antediluvian, which crash-landed to planet Earth many eons ago. That particular fragment was found in the Ural Mountains by a group of mortal explorers and scientists.
It's heavy and sharp around the edges. It doesn't match any known element on the Periodic Table.
Ljudmila explained its significance: "This fragment of a star-faring flying vessel was found in the Ural Mountains. I can feel the power of The Eldest coursing through it. Preserve it. Study it if you please, my Childe. I entrust you with something that my own Sire entrusted to me many years ago."
Dr. Collins was initially skeptical about the validity of the object (and its connection to The Ancient), but the private (and under-wraps tests) he had conducted on this shard only raised more questions.
(The fragment was so unlike anything found on this planet. Its energy was, appropriately, alien and unsettling. It emanated a low, rhythmic thrumming sound that was simultaneously calming and unsettling at the same time.)
The letter and the very important artifact are still...somewhere in the Haven of Dr. Collins. Needless to say, that piece of spaceship was unlike nothing the good doctor had ever seen, read about, or heard about.
And he's a pretty well-read man!
Ever since the fall of the USSR (and the horrors that followed), Dr. Collins has not received any more word from his Sire. No letters, no attempts to reach out, no trinkets, no subtle messages, no nothing.
Did Ljudmila walk out into the sun and end it all? Did she fall into a Torpor from which she will never likely emerge? Did she relocate? Did she become the victim of the machinations of the Eternal Struggle?
It is unknown. This not knowing does bring some pain to Dr. Collins, but not so much that he is unable to function on a night-to-night basis.
He still has his Ghoul, Brock. He has his work as a GP in his clinic. And more recently, he has his duties as Primogen for his Clan.
The Stoker spent the last few nights looking to his patients. He had a small surgery that he had to perform for a child. It was a fairly straightforward procedure, and dead hands tend to be the steadiest of them all.
His eyes are always sharp, and his memory is a steel trap. His senses are honed, and he his medical knowledge is contemporary and bang-up to date.
The surgery was a success, and the child is in a stable condition. The child's younger sibling made a drawing (with crayons) for Dr. Collins.
The Fiend was pleased by the gesture. Even though he has literal alien Blood coursing through their veins, Dr. Collins remains a humble and unassuming doctor who will go out of his way to help all of his patients and do his best to keep them healthy and happy.
The good doctor bathes and dresses. For tonight, he has to see to some of his Primogen-related duties (albeit reluctantly).
There weren't that many patients scheduled for tonight, so Dr. Collins had Wesley move their appointments to another time. There was a small handful of regulars who Dr. Collins almost always sees first-thing, but they're either away or far too busy.
Dr. Collins is dressed in a pair of dark pleated pants, a white shirt with vertical blue stripes, and a thin tie. His shoes are black and polished.
He looks like a dapper fella. His hair is fine, and his eyes are (as always) keen and observant.
The Dragon sits on his armchair and helps himself to a bag of blood from his (recently replenished) stash. These...particular bags of blood have been rerouted from a children's hospital.
Yikes.
Dr. Collins is not a perfect man. He knows where his blood comes from, but how he rationalizes his "eating habits" is by sorta...not thinking about it too much, which for a man of reason and logic is so, so very unlike him.
He cracks open the stopper and chugs the sanguine contents of the blood bag down.
The red fluid is cold yet refreshing. It's always satisfying, and the Beast within hums contentedly as this sweet sanguine liquid makes its way down the throat of the Dragon.
He tosses the empty bag in the trash and gets himself together. He spends a few minutes reading through today's newspaper.
After that, Dr. Collins looks himself over in the mirror, adjusts his tie, and leaves his Haven.
He's off to meet a fellow Tzimisce named Mr. Lance, to discuss the redrawing of some boundaries for Tzimisce feeding and hunting grounds. It intersects with Ventrue territory, so there's a lot of...maneuvering that needs to be done.
These nights, the Tzimisce have a steady and stable presence in Flimont City. The former Primogen, Galeb, saw to it that the Tzimisce never expanded, multiplied, or became a threat (in any way, shape, or form) to the other Clans, especially the Ventrue.
(He had his own reasons for doing so).
Galeb was begrudgingly accepted as Primogen over his Clan. As an Elder, he had a certain sway over his fellow Stokers. Regardless, the Tzimisce in this Domain are still given a wide berth to do their own thang or whatever.
Provided it isn't in violation of the Camarilla's Traditions. The Tzimisce in this city are all Old Clan Tzimisce (including Dr. Collins). Old Clan Tzimisce did NOT join the Sabbat (or the Anarchs, for that matter).
They have remained steadfastly faithful to the Camarilla (many, not all; some have no use for Sects and whatnot). Others within Old Clan Tzimisce even refuse to engage in Flesh-Crafting/Vicissitude.
They believe it is far too barbaric and uncivilized. Of course, not all Tzimisce can shy away from this. There's a good reason why the Tzimisce are also known as "Flesh-Shapers".
After all, Dr. Collins himself Covets after having 2 extra arms. He just has to find the...right "donor" who can "supply" the limbs.
For now, the good doctor phones his Ghoul, Brock.
Brock answers, sounding very awake and alert, "Yeah?"
Dr. Collins begins, "It's me. How are things going on your end?"
"Oh, hey, doc! Yeah, I'm just studying here. Y'know, gotta be...sharp if I wanna make it as a plastic surgeon, right? Haha! So, what's up, doc?"
Dr. Collins nods and replies, "I'm proud of you, kid. Did you do what I asked?"
Brock nods, "Oh, yeah, yeah. Totally. I spoke to the err...others. They're doing OK. They keep asking about...you-know-who, and I keep telling them what you told me to tell 'em. Yeah, they uhm...they're worried, but some of them are relieved, too."
Dr. Collins is somewhat satisfied by this, "Hmm. Good. I'll need you to take care of a few things for me tomorrow morning. I'll drop by your place to tell you more. Anything else I should be made aware of?"
"Nah. Same old, same old. You read the paper, right? Frontpage?"
The Stoker groans, "Hmph. Yes. Like I said: everything I've learned about the Donovans has been against my will. He got lucky, that's it." There's a hint of anger in his voice.
Brock's eyebrows go up, "I see. Yeah, fair enough. Everyone at the university's talking about it, too."
"Hm. Stay safe out there, kid. I'll drop by your place after I'm done with some other things. And don't worry, I'll knock- and wait- in case you have...company over."
Brock faintly snickers, "Nah, I'm like totally focusing on my studies now, doc. Oh, by the way, I went to see Dr. Sarah."
"Ah, you did. How is she?"
Brock turns over a page in his textbook, "She's good, yeah. I had my teeth checked over. Nothing too major, thankfully. It's all good, neat, and clean."
"Good. Good. Did she say anything else?"
"Mm-hmm. She wants to talk to you. She told me to tell you to drop by her dental practice anytime you're not too busy."
Dr. Collins cracks a small smile, "I think I'll see her tonight."
"You don't have any patients to see at the clinic??"
"Nope. Most of them are either out of town or busy. I had Wes reschedule a few other appointments to another time, but that's only because it's nothing urgent."
Brock blinks and scratches his head, "Oh, wow. Really?? So, you've got a lotta free time tonight, doc!"
"Yeah. Not as 'free' as I'd like it to be, but hey, I can always find some good and productive use for it. Alright, I'll drop by later, Brock. Be there, wait for me. We'll talk then."
"Roger that, doc. Bye!"
Click, and the line goes dead. Dr. Collins grabs his car keys and leaves the Haven. He gets in his green Honda Insight, puts on his seatbelt, and drives off to Mr. Lance's Haven.
Traffic is heavy during this time of the night. Dr. Collins heaves a sigh of mild annoyance and has his hands on the steering wheel. He's not the type to lose his patience so easily, but Flimont City's traffic can test even the most patient of saints!
Near the downtown area, Dr. Collins is stopped at a random police checkpoint. A cop has his assault rifle out. There's a large, armored van with blinking sirens near the checkpoint.
Dr. Collins maintains his composure and pulls over quietly. He calmly asks, "Good evening, officer. What seems to be the problem here?"
The cop gruffly responds, "License and registration."
Dr. Collins makes sure that his 2 hands are visible at all times. He slowly reaches into the glove compartment to give this pig what he demands, "Here you go. This is my license, and this is my registration. Everything is in order, as you can see, officer."
The cop glowers at the doctor and goes off to crosscheck the documents with the computer inside of his cruiser. He's back with the doctor's stuff a few seconds later.
Dr. Collins places them back in their place. His expression is calm. He has that same deadpan, non-judgmental, placid look on his pale face.
The cop meanly asks, "You're that doctor for that hobo clinic, right? The one where all the deadbeat bums and washed-up single moms go to, right?"
Dr. Collins does not dignify such a comment with an answer, "Might I inquire as to why you stopped me, officer?"
The cop responds, "Because I can. I asked you a fucking question."
Dr. Collins tightens his grip on the steering wheel, a tight look of mild displeasure flashes across his face.
The cop raps his knuckles on the windshield and grits his teeth, "HEY! Talk to me, man! Are you or are you not the guy who runs that loser clinic?"
"Officer, with all due respect, I do believe that this unwarranted harassment is crossing a certain line here."
The cop barks, "The hell you talking about? What 'harassment'? All I'm doing is asking you a fucking question. Have you ever rendered medical aid to a criminal before?"
Dr. Collins plainly answers, "As a doctor, it is not my place to pass moral judgment on the nature or origin of my patients' ailments. I am a doctor, and it is my solemn duty to treat patients regardless of their social standing, economic condition, age, race, gender--"
The cop rudely cuts the vampire off, "Shut up! Out of the car, now!"
"Wha--"
The police officer raises his assault rifle and points it at Dr. Collins. The Stoker is in complete shock. What in the hell is going on here?!
His hands tremble slightly. The Beast within growls and rages and yearns for blood. He could easily take this guy on, pounce on him, rip him to shreds, and drain him of every last drop of blood.
It would be over in mere seconds, and Dr. Collins knows the human body pretty damn well. He knows the pressure points, all the vulnerable spots, all the weak points.
Not tonight, however. The Masquerade is of prime importance.
Dr. Collins could even leave the cop half-alive, with most of his extremities intact. The Beast within yearns for that. The Beast desires to see the fear, the terror, in this pig's eyes.
No. Not tonight.
The good doctor slowly exits his vehicle, making sure not to make any sudden moves or give the cop a reason to pull the trigger.
The cop keeps his distance. The other nearby cops join him; their assault rifles are drawn and pointed at the Stoker as well. They are very alert and wary, on edge.
The officer growls at the Fiend, "He refused to answer my simple goddamn question. I asked this fucking guy if he ever treated criminals and he--he didn't even deny it!"
A female cop shakes her head at this. She asks the doctor, "Did you treat criminals recently?"
Dr. Collins does not take his eyes off of the cops. He firmly replies, "I did not. No."
Another male cop chuckles, "Fucking liar! He's that hobo clinic guy, right?"
"Yeah!"
"Cuff him!"
As a cop is about to slap handcuffs around his wrists, a bulky SUV stops near the checkpoint, and a man steps out of it. He's dressed in a white shirt and black pants.
He's quite tall and heavyset. His face is clean-shaven, and his eyes are a deep shade of blue. He looks to be in his 40s, give or take a year. He has an easy smile on his face.
A police officer turns to the newcomer and angrily says, "Hey, get back! This guy is a potential suspect--"
The heavyset guy smirks and softly says something to the cop. Dr. Collins remains perfectly still and his eyes dart here and there. He's still on edge.
The cop immediately lowers his weapon and backs off, a blank stare on his face. The newcomer then moves to the female cop, who also lowers her rifle. He whispers something to her as well. She nods at him and walks off.
Dr. Collins recognizes him as none other than Mr. Lance.
(It appears that Mr. Lance over here is using the Dominate Discipline to help out his fellow Dragon.)
The Tzimisce turns to the remaining cop, who's still got his AR pointed at the doc. Mr. Lance shakes his head, smiles, and makes a come-hither motion with his fingers.
The cop cannot resist, so he trudges over and cocks his head. Mister Lance whispers something in his ear, and he, too, backs off and meanders off to another place.
That same cop calls out, "Eh...false alarm, people! Nothing to see here! Move! MOVE ON! GO!"
Dr. Collins sighs and shakes his head, "I was this close to filing an official complaint, you know."
Mr. Lance softly chuckles, "We can't have that now, can we?" His accent is American, flat and neutral.
Mr. Lance then cracks his neck and stretches his arms, "Ah, the cops, well, you know how it is, doctor. C'mon, follow me back to my place."
After some more wading through traffic...
Mr. Lance's Haven is just another standard gray residential building in Flimont City. The area around it is bustling with life. Cars roar down the highway at incredible speeds. The streetlamps appear to be in working order, and the pavement is well-maintained.
Mr. Lance's Haven is on the ground floor. His apartment has a rather Art Deco look to it, with some impressive pieces of art hanging around. The dcor is classy, with some pictures of a beautiful older lady and Mr. Lance next to her.
In 1 black-and-white picture, the older lady is seated, while Mr. Lance is standing, chest puffed out. There's a small inscription in the lower right corner that reads: "A mother's son. A mother's pride. A mother's delight."
Mr. Lance adjusts the golden frame and states, "She passed away 3 years, 7 months, and 2 nights after my Embrace."
The Tzimisce smiles sadly, "I was fortunate enough to have had her in my life, you know. I wish you could have known my mother, doctor. I feel that you both would have had much in common."
Mr. Lance himself was Embraced during the interwar years (the 1930s). He worked as muscle for a speakeasy that catered to certain...interested parties.
It was an exclusive joint, where the working girls, gangsters, and various unsavory types all drank, ate, gambled, and partied away. The mother knew of her son's job. She understood why he did it.
And she loved him anyway.
The mother herself worked as a clerk for a factory that manufactured heavy equipment. She had a stern look on her wrinkly face. Her hair was cut short. Her eyes were sharp and alert.
During the Great Depression, she lost her job and fell on some really hard times. There were times when she went to bed, hungry and cold and miserable.
Her son was the only source of income they had. The speakeasy was their only source of income, that's why she didn't say anything about his "career choice". She loved him because he was willing to roll up his sleeves for her.
Mr. Lance's father had died in the slaughterhouse of WW1, as did his 3 brothers. All of them were 19-20 years of age. He was the only one of his siblings who didn't go to war.
However, Mr. Lance drafted the dodge by working for some mobster. During the Great Depression, that same mobster got shot to death in his own office. A gangland hit, a message, whatever.
Mr. Lance soon found himself in the employ of whoever was running that speakeasy. He had the muscle to make sure that business ran smoothly and that the authorities either got their cut or remained none-the-wiser.
Mr. Lance's Sire first approached his mother. However, she turned down the opportunity of immortality, instead asking that he Embrace her son instead.
She wanted her boy to see the future, to live forever, and to have all the time in the world. Mr. Lance's Sire graciously obliged, but only after the mother made her son swear an oath- he would never use his immortality for his own gains and he was disallowed from ever joining the Sabbat.
Oh, and he was also prohibited from engaging in any kind of Flesh-Crafting/Vicissitude. And no Blood-Bonding with other vamps, too. Lastly, if he were to take a Ghoul, it would have to be a woman in her 30s.
Uh, yeah, sure. Fine, cool, whatever. Mr. Lance and his mom agreed to these (fairly) reasonable terms and conditions.
And many decades later, here he is, still kicking about the gaffe. He's had a good run, so far. He's kept his head low, stayed clear of trouble, and remained a steadfast and loyal Tzimisce.
(He's yet to find a Ghoul who meets his Sire's requirements, and wonders whether the hassle is worth the trouble of finding one.)
Dr. Collins sits on a plush black sofa as Mr. Lance sits right opposite him. The big guy clasps his hands together and begins, "So, how are things, doctor?"
Dr. Collins responds, "Going great. By the way, what you did back there..."
"Think nothing of it. You should consider yourself lucky. I was just coming back from buying new lightbulbs, and I saw that green car of yours near the police checkpoint. I knew it was you."
Dr. Collins frowns and adds, "Thank you, really. I--I didn't know what I would've done were it not for your timely intervention. What did you say to those cops, anyway?"
Mr. Lance shifts in his seat a little, "Just a pinch of Mesmerism on their scattered minds. I try not to push too hard."
("Mesmerism" is a Nickname for the Dominate Discipline).
Dr. Collins nods, "Ah, and once again...thank you. What the hell is going on with the police around here, huh?"
Mr. Lance replies, "Ever since those 2 cops got wasted, the others have been on high alert. They're nervous and angry, like cornered animals and such. They're just looking for someone to beat on, I guess."
The good doctor rubs his temples, "Yeah, that seems to be the case."
Mr. Lance muses, "Even in my time, Dr. Collins, the sound of the approaching paddy wagons was never a pleasant one..."
He smirks and adds, "But a little...sourdough, some quick thinking, and charm was all that was all that was needed to keep the 'law' at bay. The old-fashioned way. You know what I mean, right?"
Dr. Collins heaves a sigh and asks, "I guess. Sourdough??"
"Money, counterfeit. By the time the cops got wise to it, it was too late to do anything about it, heh heh."
Dr. Collins nods, "Ah. Hmph. You weren't actually gonna bribe them, were you?"
The other Tzimisce pauses for a moment, "It was a last-resort option. Bribes and the FCPD go well together, like peanut butter and jelly, hahahahaha!"
He's right. If you see a cop in Flimont City who won't take a bribe (in kind or in cash), you catch 'em and put 'em in a zoo with the national animal of Scotland.
Dr. Collins, having lived in Flimont City for quite some time now is well aware of this fact.
Mr. Lance inquires, "You never did get around to learning any of our Clan's Disciplines, right?"
Dr. Collins admits, "Truth be told, I've had no need for it. None whatsoever. If anything, it would hold me back as a physician, and I can't really have that."
Mr. Lance replies, "Hmm, you'd be surprised. It's not as bad as you think, though. We've got a lot to choose from, y'know. Animalism, Auspex, Vicissitude, Dominate, and Protean."
Dr. Collins scratches his nose, "Vicissitude is less of a Discipline and more of a--I don't know what to call it, really. Categorizing it is a pain, honestly. There's the good, and there's the bad in that...just like all other Disciplines and powers that are in our Blood."
"Fascinating stuff, huh? My Sire already forbade me from all the Flesh-Shaping stuff, but the other Disciplines were fair game, so I chose Dominate and did my best to master it throughout the years. I was told that it'd be pretty useful. It is, haha!"
Mr. Lance gestures to the doc and smiles proudly, "Just look at tonight, right?"
Dr. Collins acknowledges the point, "Hm. That was pretty useful, yes, but I've made my decisions already- no Disciplines for me. Ever. I have better use for my Blood...and my time. No offense."
Mr. Lance clicks his tongue and lazily waves, "Tch, please. None taken. I can imagine, being a doctor, curing all manner of ailments, studying those fancy writings, seeing to every ill and injury, and fixing broken hearts and shattered minds. Yeah, I understand that. I really do, doc."
Mr. Lance then leans forward, "Does it ever get too much for you? After all, you've been doing this a lot longer than your peers. I can't even imagine the stress that's weighing on you, the responsibilities, and such."
Dr. Collins is silent. He never really talks about the bad stuff. He does take pride in his work as a GP, but how long can it go on for? How long before someone catches on to the GP who never ages? How long before things start to crack?
Mr. Lance nods, "Yeah, I thought so. You're our Primogen now. I hope I don't speak out of place, but you really ought to consider your options down the line."
Dr. Collins dryly asks, "What do you mean by that?" There's a mildly defensive edge to his voice.
Mr. Lance respectfully proceeds, "All this modern technology, all this talk of terrorists, spies, and whatever. We're living in times of great change, Dr. Collins. I never would've imagined that THIS is the way things would've turned out in this new century, though."
"Hm. Yeah. My paperwork's in order. My knowledge is contemporary. My office is clean and well-stocked with the necessary equipment. The Primogen thing is...something I didn't ask for."
The doctor stares off into the distance and adds, "I have and will always be a doctor. It's the only thing I'm good at, it's what I've given most of my life- and Unlife- for. I have a Ghoul to take care of as well. I've got a lot on my plate, as you can see."
Mr. Lance chuckles, "Yeah. The Primogen thing, it's just 1 of those things you have to find a way of dealing with. You can't really refuse or say no to your...additional duties, y'know?"
"Hmm."
Mr. Lance senses the uneasiness in his fellow Stoker, and he can't really blame him for it.
So, he changes the subject by querying, "So...any news on Galeb yet?"
Ah, great. That annoying question. Again.
Dr. Collins holds back a groan and blandly answers, "No. Nothing. Not a peep. Or a squeak for that matter. Why? Have you heard something?"
Mr. Lance picks up on his guest's...discomfort and casually replies, "No. Nothing. Sorry, I just thought that you might've had something on him, that's all." He then adds, "He's been gone for quite some time now."
Dr. Collins sighs and remarks, "Hm. He has."
Mr. Lance opines, "Between me and you, I found Galeb to be quite a disagreeable man. In the weeks prior to his disappearance, he seemed strange to me."
Dr. Collins twitches a little, "Oh?"
"Mm-hmm. He was silent, contemplative, constantly staring at the ground, fingers steepled together...menacingly, like he was planning something...or maybe it was the toll of being an Elder..." Mr. Lance chuckles and adds, "Either way, it didn't sit right with me."
"I see. No one ever really spoke about it, but yeah, even I...err...noticed his strange behavior was as of late."
The doctor muses, "Maybe he was Beckoned away."
Mr. Lance looks clueless, "I have no idea what that means, doctor. Hm, yes. Either way, you're our Primogen now. We're hoping for great things from you, Dr. Collins."
The good doctor nods a bit and forces a smile, "Hm. I'll do my best to deliver. I guess it's worth saying that I'm not my predecessor, nor do I aim to ever be him."
Mr. Lance shrugs, "Ah, fair enough. Other than that, I haven't heard squat about Galeb."
"Hm. Right. Let's just focus on...more important matters for our Clan, like the redrawing of those boundaries. What else have you been up to as of late, Mr. Lance?"
"Aahh. Me, huh? We're just bumping gums here, right?"
"I believe that's what we're doing, yes. Why, is there some kind of trouble I ought to be aware of?" Dr. Collins leans forward a bit. The look on his face is calm, but his tone is level.
Mr. Lance shuffles on his seat and states, "Nothing that would count as a Masquerade breach. It's more of a concerned citizen...err...matter. Nothing at all." He flashes a toothy smile.
"A concerned citizen matter? Is that all?" The Stoker doesn't take his eyes off of his host.
Mr. Lance winces and budges, "I have blood delivered to me- discreetly, of course. The young dame who delivers my packages seems...quite off. I'm not sure of the appropriate words to be throwing around."
"Oh?"
"Y--Yes. I believe her name is Yumi. Never did get a last name, and I didn't feel right pressing her for it. Disturbingly thin, messy clothing, a sort of unhinged expression, and she was quite impolite with me."
Mr. Lance explains, "She's been making her deliveries, and I give her the dough and send her on her way."
Dr. Collins nods and comments, "OK. Sounds like you've got it under control. What seems to be the problem with this...Yumi?"
Mr. Lance clasps his hands together and exhales sharply, "She looked so...weak, so tired. She didn't have that...life...in her, that sparkle, if you catch my drift."
The Stoker then adds, "She seemed more like a Ghoul that was off her fix. But I asked around and nobody I know has a Ghoul named Yumi. I gave her a sawbuck..." he trails off.
(Sawbuck is 1930s slang for a $10 bill).
Mr. Lance pauses. He's got something else on his mind. Dr. Collins notices the shift in his fellow Stoker's demeanor.
Mr. Lance shakes his head and chuckles to himself, "She--she--her eyes lit up. She thanked me profusely and went on her way. I felt so sorry for her."
Dr. Collins has met Yumi before- she was the one desperately demanding OxyContin from the good doctor. He didn't get her name all those nights ago. She was practically begging for a prescription of that stuff, poor lass.
Regardless, he strokes his chin and thinks out loud, "Hm. Maybe she's just going through a rough patch right now." He pauses for a second, then continues, "Could you send her my way the next time you see her, Mr. Lance?"
Mr. Lance bows his head slightly, "Of course, doctor. It would be my pleasure. You have a real knack for helping these kinds of people out, eh?"
Dr. Collins stolidly responds, "Someone's gotta do it, and I have the time...and the experience."
Mr. Lance gets up from his seat with a slight groan. He pulls a map of Flimont City from his bookshelf and lays it out on the large table in his dining room.
He rolls out the city map and pulls up his marker- a chunky red thing, one of those fine permanent markers. Dr. Collins stands across the table as his fellow Fiend begins to mark this already marked map with a series of crosses and other marks.
He's currently marking out what counts as Tzimisce feeding grounds- this is territory where they can freely hunt in.
"As you can clearly see, we have a good and fair chunk of the city right now. The question is, will that change in the next few nights?" he asks while marking.
Dr. Collins dryly notes, "Things change at a moment's notice around here, Mr. Lance."
"Yes. Take a look here..." Mr. Lance directs his guest's attention to a rather large area labelled "Beaumont Boulevard". There's a massive question mark scrawled in red ink over this part.
The big guy sighs and asks, "This part right here has been contested for quite some time now. Beaumont Boulevard is Baali country. As a result, we've stayed well clear of those...Demon Worshippers. And it's French, too. Haha!"
Dr. Collins faintly chuckles at that and asks, "So, what seems to be the issue over here?"
"The Ventrue have had their eyes on it, too. As do we. Only the Gangrel and the Malkavians are uninterested. As you can see here..." Mr. Lance's finger traces a line at the edge of Beaumont Boulevard, where it sort of intersects with Ventrue territory.
He points to a block on the western end, "There's a block here that's just full of banks, law firms, and other Ventrue-affiliated businesses. Now those Blue Bloods want more of the pie for themselves."
He taps his marker on Beaumont Boulevard and explains, "This is a big apple, Dr. Collins, but it's not big enough for all of us. The Baali are deeply entrenched in Beaumont Boulevard, and that's even where their Coven is located, or so I've been told."
Dr. Collins rubs his chin. He's silent and deep in thought, "So, what's our interest in Beaumont Boulevard, then? Are the Baali willing to deal?"
"They most certainly are," Mr. Lance confidently answers.
"And what exactly is the deal we're looking at here?"
"The Unholy will permit us to feed in and around Beaumont Boulevard, provided we allow them to make a few small expansions here and here," Mr. Lance answers while circling 2 spots that are firmly Dragon territory.
The other Tzimisce squints, "Expansions for what purpose, Mr. Lance?" He's not liking what he's hearing at the moment.
Mr. Lance shrugs, "Territorial, I suppose? Maybe it's something to do with those...rituals they conduct down in their Coven. Hey, you're the Primogen, shouldn't you be more aware of this?"
Dr. Collins crosses his arms and comments, "It's my 1st time hearing all of this. There's no Baali Primogen on the Council, but I think there are talks about maybe having one. Does the name 'Pierre Despard' ring any bells?"
Mr. Lance smiles, "Yes, it certainly does, Dr. Collins. I believe that he is in charge of the Baali's Coven right below Beaumont Boulevard. Strange fish, that one. French, haha!"
"Hmm. What's the status of our other territories within the Domain? How's it holding up? I've been meaning to go and take a look myself, but I've been busy with work. I've sent Brock to check in on a few people, and they seem fine."
Mr. Lance replies, "It's holding up well. The Gangrel are mostly concentrated on 5th Street. The Malkavians are, well, all over the place. The rest is firmly Ventrue."
Dr. Collins points out, "There's Brujah, too. Former Anarchs. They want in, but Prince Antonio's put an impossible asking price for a seat at the table."
"Ah. I see. Well, that's gonna be...interesting. Galeb had a knack for making sure that our territory remained ours, if only because the Ventrue tend to destroy anyone who dares to feed in their places, or on their people."
Dr. Collins responds, "Mm-hmm. And Prince Antonio is pretty much looking to make sure that that never changes."
Mr. Lance smiles, "Not to worry, if we can come to an arrangement with the Baali over the next few nights, then I'm confident that everything will turn out great in the long run. Everyone around here wants a slice of the pie for themselves, doc."
Dr. Collins mildly chuckles, "That they certainly do. It's just a matter of...equally divvying up the slices, right?"
"'Ventrue' and 'equally' don't usually find themselves in the same sentence, Dr. Collins. Oddly enough, the same could be said of the Brujah."
Dr. Collins clears his throat and takes a good and long look at the heavily marked map of the city before him. He's now got some light insight into the internal workings of his own Clan.
The territorial politics alone were quite a surprise, though. The Tzimisce don't really have much when it comes to hunting grounds. Their feeding opportunities appear scant, that's why they're interested in expanding.
There are quite a lot of Tzimisce here, but there isn't enough space or resources for all of them, especially when one considers the Ventrue's habit of exterminating anyone who is in the wrong place at the wrong time.
(Sheriff Velma has no issue destroying any non-Ventrue caught messing around in Ventrue territory, of which there's a lot, some of which bleeds into Malkavian territory).
The Gangrel are mostly concentrated in (and around) 5th Street and other poorer or deprived neighborhoods around F-City.
Dr. Collins thinks to himself, "Wow. I really didn't know that this wall all that we had. Hm. Something's gotta give; it can't go on like this. It just...can't. Our Clan's growing, and we need the space to sustain that growth."
He narrows his eyes and continues in his silent contemplation, " I mean, look at this: the Ventrue's got more room than anyone else...they're even right on top of Malk territory, how do they even tolerate that? Do they even know that they're on top of each other? Hmm..."
The doctor finally turns his gaze away from the map and faces the big dude who's been patiently waiting for him to finish looking it over.
"A penny for your thoughts?"
"Things need to change around here."
"You and me both, buddy. You and me both."
Mr. Lance proceeds to roll up the city map and puts it back from where he retrieved it. The good doctor thanks him and promises that he'll give these issues a more thorough review before his next Primogen Council meeting.
The conversation then drifts to them talking about their families (mostly Mr. Lance), their hobbies, current happenings, and whatnot.
For a guy who was muscle at a speakeasy (he still talks like one sometimes), Mr. Lance has adapted remarkably well to the current year's mannerisms, ways of speaking, and such.
He's a learned man, one who's picked up all manner of skills throughout his long years. Mr. Lance currently works as a payroll processor for a family-run trucking company- quite the far cry from hired muscle at a speakeasy!
It's a very manual, paper-heavy, and system-restricted kinda job. There's a whole lotta clicking, typing, checking, and printing involved. Sometimes Mr. Lance has to physically handle check runs and such.
"I've been at it for about 6 years now. A lot of my co-workers are...on the lam, if you catch my drift."
Dr. Collins leans forward, "Oh?"
"Mm-hmm. Good people who simply fell on some hard times and made a few mistakes- some more severe than others, mind you. I can relate to their experiences."
Mr. Lance gestures to a picture of his mother when she was younger, "Y'know, doctor, she...gave me this chance. She could've easily taken the gift of Unlife for herself, but she wanted..."
His voice breaks a little. It's obvious that Mr. Lance's mum means a great deal to him, even after all this time. He recovers with a sigh and continues, "She wanted me to be happy, y'see? She wanted her last and remaining son to...live forever."
He's now smiling fondly and rubbing the side of his face as he gazes at the photograph of his mother as a young lady, "Losing her husband and her 3 boys- my brothers- to that pointless goddamn fucking war...excuse the language. It--it really affected her, y'know?"
Dr. Collins nods along and affirms, "Mm-hmm. Yes, yes, I do. War is...it's not a fun movie, it's not a damn game, it's...cruel and grueling and--and...well, I--I was there--" he stares at the ground, a clear look of anguish in his dead eyes.
The then-mortal Dr. Collins himself was in France during WW2, so he speaks from experience.
Mr. Lance can see the trauma, the suffering, in his fellow Dragon's eyes, but he doesn't prod any further.
Instead, he continues talking, "Momma said that I was all she had left, y'know? She said she was gonna be damned before she let anything take me away from her as well. War, disease, whatever. She couldn't lose another boy to the horrors, doc. She just couldn't."
"So, she let you get Embraced in her stead."
Mr. Lance solemnly nods, "She's my mom and she will always be. Giving up a chance at--at immortality and--and power so that I can...so that I could have another chance, another shot at things...it just goes to show...y'know?"
"Sounds like quite a woman, indeed, Mr. Lance. Selfless to a fault."
Mr. Lance fully agrees with a nod of the head, "Hmm, yeah. She'd seen a lot, y'know? Been through a lot, too. She married young, real young...too young by modern standards, but times were very different back then."
"They sure were."
The talk between these 2 vampires goes on for a few more minutes.
"My job's pretty different from the speako, lemme tell ya that much! Same goes for my previous jobs, haha! Most of the time I spend involves me being glued to a damn spinning chair, hahahahaha!"
After a fairly pleasant chat, Dr. Collins stands up, exchanges a firm and tight handshake with his fellow Tzimisce, and takes his leave. He's gonna go and see Dr. Sarah now.
Dr. Collins promises Mr. Lance that he'll talk about expanding Tzimisce territory at the next Primogen Council meeting, whenever that's scheduled for.
"I'll do my best, Mr. Lance. And please, send this Yumi woman my way the next time she pops around. I usually have time to spare. And who knows? Maybe she DOES need a bit of help, a friendly ear and a helping hand. It never hurts to reach out and see what can be done."
Mr. Lance walks with his guest to the front door, "Indeed! She certainly has the look of someone in desperate need of some aid. She looks so...directionless, purposeless, and weak. It worries me a little."
Dr. Collins stops in his tracks, "Hm? Truth be told, that describes more than half this city on nights like these."
Mr. Lance cocks an eyebrow, "Oh?"
Dr. Collins bitterly says, "Mm-hmm. You live in Flimont City for so long, you start to forget what decency even looks like. Money seems to be the only thing that certain people around here give a damn about, and it's disconcerting...to say the least."
Mr. Lance chimes in, "Disheartening, too. This new century was supposed to be full of promise, full of hope. Yet I've only seen disappointment, dreams and wishes dashed to a 1000 tiny little pieces."
Dr. Collins gives him a sympathetic look. Mr. Lance pensively lowers his head and faintly smiles at his fellow Tzimisce, so as not to end this on a bad and sour note.
(Mr. Lance, like literally anybody else, is not immune from the overarching social, economic, historical, and political processes of the times. He, too, has his limitations. We all do.)
The good doctor pats Mr. Lance's shoulder, "Please, stay in touch. And come by the clinic whenever you're not too busy. Make an appointment first."
Mr. Lance plainly nods and ushers his guest out of his Haven with a wide farewell smile, "Thanks for dropping by, doc. Take care on those roads, y'hear?"
He lifts his finger and pointedly adds, "I won't be there the next time, to bail you out of a sticky situation with the law."
Dr. Collins slightly winces at that. His memory of having that AR pointed at him was most unpleasant, to say the very least. He really has to find a way around these maniacal, trigger-happy cops who are just looking for a reason to pop you, cuff you, and/or have you fitted out for a Chicago overcoat.
Dr. Collins says his final goodbye to his fellow vampire, "You have yourself a good rest of the evening, Mr. Lance. We'll speak again soon. I'm sure of it."
Mr. Lance waves, smiles, and bids the good doctor farewell as he gets into his vehicle. It's the good doctor's time to depart, to be on his way to see the dentist at her place of work.
As the good doctor drives off, Mr. Lance goes to his bedside table and pulls out a small antique silver box. He gently opens it and pokes his stubby finger at the contents within.
Inside the box are a few locks of hair- Mr. Lance's mother's hair, to be precise. Those locks of hair are what helps this Tzimisce stay Grounded. As long as he day-sleeps with it close by, Mr. Lance can keep his head on straight.
If he ever loses those precious locks of hair, then he'll wake up a VERY grumpy bloodsucker, paining all over. And nobody wants that, so Mr. Lance keeps his mum's hair close to him at all times. It's the least he can do for her.
She gave him this chance, after all. He tells himself that he owes her everything. Everything.
Dr. Collins is now back on the dark roads. He drives slowly (even slower than usual, so as to not arouse any more unwanted attention). He takes longer and more traffic-ridden routes just to avoid another run in with the oink, oink.
The streets are bare, desolate, and not as lively as the doc was expecting. His car cruises along the uneven pavement as he watches the streetlamps on his right flicker. As do the streetlamps on the left.
"Looks like it's time to get the city council to look into this issue. Heh."
The Stoker drives slowly, almost too slow, like he's afraid he's gonna get pulled over again and have a crazy cop point their gun at him and start hurling accusations at him. The doc drives well under the speed limit.
His eyes are firmly fixed on the road, and he pays close attention to what's around him. He's on edge. Very, very on edge. He tightly grips the steering wheel and keeps driving to Dr. Sarah's dental practice.
While on the road, he spots a silhouette of a...woman (?) walking down the sidewalk. The trees overhead provide a bit of cover, so he can't really make out her features.
She appears to be barefoot, carrying her cheap-looking high heels in 1 hand. Dr. Collins slows down and spots...none other than Roxanne, the Brujah sex worker.
Roxy's dressed in a white shirt with the topmost buttons undone. Her capri pants look worn out, and her hair's a bit messy.
The lady of the night has a neutral expression on her face, looking like she just came out of a very bland session of vanilla sex. She's standing there, breathing a little heavy, her bare feet planted on the dirty pavement.
She walks with a sense of urgency, her head tilted forward, staring at the pavement beneath her.
Dr. Collins pulls up beside her and calls out, "Roxanne?"
The Punk almost jumps, but she catches herself and smiles at the doc. Her face lights up a little, and her body relaxes as she leans over the window.
She opens her mouth and speaks in a warm and friendly tone, "Oh, good evening, Doctor Collins. What are you doing here on this 'lovely' night, hmm? Same as me? Seeing to your clients, hm?"
Dr. Collins shakes his head and faintly chuckles, "They're my patients, Roxanne. It's a different line of work. Get in, I'll give you a ride to wherever it is that you're headed."
She's silent for a few seconds, and then asks, "Are you sure? You look busy. I wouldn't want to impose on you. And I need the walk, that last customer...was, ugh, awful."
The doctor sighs and asks (out of concern), "You do practice some form of safe sex, don't you?"
"'Course, sugar. Always." Roxy takes the good doc up on his offer and gets in his car. He asks about why she's walking barefoot, and she tells him that she had to ditch her heels, because they were killing her dead feet.
Dr. Collins drives again, still slow as a turtle. The sex worker, on the other hand, is all smiles as she reclines in the passenger seat. The wind blows gently into her pale face.
Roxanne smirks, "You do know that you can make this baby go a lot faster, right? There are barely any cars out, which is a...surprise to be honest. It's not every night that these streets are this empty."
"I've seen better nights," the doctor plainly responds. His voice is steady, calm, and cold. His eyes are focused on the road.
Roxanne stretches her arm out of the window and lets out a soft and gentle sigh as the wind blows through her twirling fingers. This part of the city is so silent.
Dr. Collins tells her, "I'll have to check in on your sister tomorrow night. Any changes in her condition? Any problems?" He gives the prostitute a quick glance but then returns his gaze to the road ahead.
Roxanne hums wistfully and shrugs, "Nope. Penny's still...the way she is. I don't know if that's a good thing or a bad thing, though."
"Hmm. Is there something wrong with her?" the doctor asks with genuine concern.
Roxy gulps, "Nah. Do you think that there's a chance she might, y'know, wake up from her coma anytime soon??" Her baggy eyes are laden with desperation, with a dash of fear, and a smidgen of hope.
Dr. Collins is silent. He's silent for a few moments as he thinks about it. He finally exhales softly and tells her, "It's hard to say, Roxanne. I might be a Presbyterian, but I remain skeptical about...miracles or other supernatural phenomena."
The Brujah snickers and points out, "We're vampires, honey. Damned from the very moment those fangs sunk deep into our necks. All we've probably got is a...small bit of hope, the slightest sliver of assurance that maybe we're not, you know, totally damned after all."

The dental clinic is a medium-large, modest brick building that sits at the middle of the block. The outside walls are painted a light shade of gray, and the sign above the door simply reads: "Smiles By Sarah".
The windows are covered with blinds, so peeps can't peep inside. There's a small parking lot in the back, and the clinic has its fair share of regular customers.
