Dr. Sarah doesn't wish for any unsavory individuals (especially vampire hunters) sniffing around her place of business (and Haven). She's got a reputation to uphold, after all.
Her Haven is down in the basement, and the upstairs areas are used to store additional equipment, supplies, and whatever else a vampire's dental practice needs to function.
It's a pretty spacious, and it works as intended. She's got everything she needs to do her job, and that's all that matters to her.
The dentist emerges from her office in the corner and greets Dr. Collins with a wide smile. She's wearing a white lab coat over her clothing.
Dr. Sarah looks decidedly middle-aged. She has dark auburn hair, intense green eyes, a gaunt and pale face, and a lithe body. There's something almost...alien about her. It's hard to pinpoint exactly what it is, but it's there alright.
Her fingers are longer than most and her smile is equal parts easy-going, equal parts unsettling. When she smiles, her teeth are absolutely perfect (she's a dentist, after all!).
Dr. Sarah is pretty evasive on when exactly she was Embraced, but it was a long time ago. Dentistry is all she has known, both in life and in Unlife. Over the years, she's had to make forgeries of her dentist-related certificates to stay ahead of the game, but she's not complaining.
Like Dr. Collins, her medical knowledge is bang up-to-date and contemporary as can possibly be.
Dr. Sarah, unlike many other Tzimisce here, is not only a practitioner of Koldunic Sorcery (aka Koldunism) but she's also very much into the whole Flesh-Crafting thing as well.
She greets her intellectual equal with a smile, arms outstretched, "Doctor Collins! How are you?" She pulls him into a hug. It's warm and friendly, just like she appears to be.
Dr. Collins is still reeling from that highly treasonous talk he had with Roxanne, but he manages to smile and hug his fellow Tzimisce back, "I'm doing fine, Dr. Sarah. I'm doing fine."
He pauses for a moment and then adds, "How are you doing tonight?"
Dr. Sarah maintains her smile, "I'm fine. By the way, your Ghoul came by to get his teeth looked at. Nothing too major, I just thought you should know."
"Hm. Thanks." Dr. Collins takes his seat in front of her curved desk. He sighs deeply and looks around the room. It's very clean and orderly, just like how a dentist's office ought to be. It's comforting. In a weird, alien sorta way.
Dr. Sarah steeples her long fingers together and asks, "So, what brings you here tonight, Doctor?" Her tone is very easy-going and almost suave. It's a bit unusual for a Tzimisce to have such a personality, but it works for her (everyone is different, after all).
She's a slick lady. A cool cat. An alien-vampire dentist.
Dr. Collins proceeds to ask, "So, how have you been lately?"
Dr. Sarah moves a paper on her desk and replies, "Oh, it's been busy, lemme tell you that much. I had a few intensive root canals these past few nights."
"I hope they didn't hurt too much?"
"It was no biggie, doc. I've dealt with worse. Far, far worse."
"That's good, that's good. I was just at Mr. Lance's Haven. Truth be told, I didn't know that we were so low on territory, to be honest."
Dr. Sarah rubs her chin, "Right, right. Yeah, it's been like that. Galeb, that slimy old creep, kept handing a lot of it over to the Ventrue in exchange for boons or whatever, y'know?"
Dr. Collins frowns and leans forward, "Really?! What?! That's just...unbelievable!"
Dr. Sarah shrugs, "Eh, what can ya do? None of us miss Galeb, wherever he is. If he's ash, all the better."
Dr. Collins awkwardly shifts on his seat when he hears her say that. He's got this awkward, nervous look on his face and a weird, guilty feeling in his dead stomach.
Dr. Collins exhales and tells her, "We can't lose more land, Dr. Sarah."
"No kidding. That's why you're our Primogen now. If anything, the rest of us are hoping that you'd be able to undo Galeb's many...mistakes, yeah? That's what the Primogen are for, right? Making sure that the interests of the Clan are adequately represented in the Court?"
Dr. Collins nods, "Yeah, I suppose so. I've been giving it some thought, and I think that we have to find a way to, uh...renegotiate--" He stops mid-sentence and nervously rubs the base of his cold neck.
He's not sure how to bring up the topic of overthrowing the Prince with Dr. Sarah, so he just keeps quiet on that for now. He'll think of something.
In the meantime, he gulps and looks her in the eye, "Uh, anyway. I wanted to ask you about Brock. How's he been doing? Has he said anything...odd?"
Dr. Sarah smiles and chuckles, "Well, let's see. Not that I can think of, no. Why, is your Ghoul trying something funny? Is this gonna be a problem for us?" She leans forward and smirks, sinisterly.
Dr. Collins lightly gasps, "What?! No! God, no. Nothing like that; Brock's been good to me these past 7 years. No, I've just been concerned about his...well, his health...and wellbeing."
Dr. Sarah leans back and regards her fellow Fiend with an unreadable stare, "He's been with ya a long time, eh?"
Dr. Collins smiles and replies, "He's a good kid, Dr. Sarah. Like--like the son I never had, you know?"
"I suppose so. Your Brock's doing fine. If it's worth anything, he told me that he recently...came out the closet to you."
Dr. Collins nods and smiles a little, "Yeah. I'm just glad that he told me. There's nothing wrong with being gay; it's perfectly natural. He's safe with me, don't worry."
"You didn't even suspect it?"
"Suspect what?"
Dr. Sarah lazily waves her hand, "Never mind. So, what else is new, hmm? How's the Primogen job so far?"
Dr. Collins faintly groans, "Not off to a great start. By the way, thank you so much, for that $1500 you lent me. I can't believe it, you know? $10,000 for--for some kinda entry fee into that greedy Ventrue's Court! That's insane!"
Dr. Sarah grins and says, "I'm not surprised, honestly. $10,000 is a pretty big chunk of change for most of us, but that's what it takes to get in the big boy leagues these nights. I hope you managed to cover the remaining $8500 just fine?"
Dr. Collins nods, "Yeah. I even had to borrow from Brock. Hff. I hope he doesn't resent me for that."
"He'll be fine. Trust me."
"Anyway, let's get back to what we were talking about. We're low on land, and the other Clans need to either give some of theirs up, or we've gotta get more aggressive in negotiating ours back."
Dr. Sarah chuckles, "Look at you. You truly are the man in charge, huh? I already like you better than that slimy Elder, Galeb. Sheesh, he--he was--there was something 'off' about him, y'know?"
"Yeah. I guess I am. I just--I just want to see this work out. I wanna see our Clan flourish. What do mean by 'off'?"
Dr. Sarah leans forward and puts her chin on the back of her palm, "Well, he was very secretive, and he didn't talk much, but it was obvious that he was always plotting, scheming, and working some angle."
"Hmm." He wordlessly motions for her to go on.
She does so, "He was also a real, real nasty guy. Y'know, the kind of unpleasant guy who wouldn't hesitate to dust someone to save his own hide. He reminded me more of the Sabbat-aligned Tzimisce, if you ask me."
Dr. Collins stifles a gasp and stares off into space as she waits for him to say something. His face tics a few times, as if there's something more he knows. Something he's keeping from everyone else.
Dr. Collins remains in contemplative silence. He's still dwelling on the talk he had with Roxy. He looks away and sighs, "We have to do something, but I'm not sure what."
(He knows more about Galeb than he's letting on, but what?)
Dr. Sarah side-eyes her fellow Stoker, "OK? Is everything alright with you? It looks like you're physically present- which you are- but your mind's a million miles away."
(True!)
The good doctor replies, "I'm sorry. It's just...the whole Galeb situation, I just want to make sure that we don't--"
"It's fine. No one's gonna miss him. If anything, we're hoping that you can finally undo his many mistakes and fuckups."
"How bad was it?"
"VERY. That son of a bitch weakened our position in this city- severely. After all the self-sabotage he's done, I'm surprised we're even here at all, still standing."
"Yeah. I'm...I'm starting to realize that we can't keep doing what we've been doing for the past few decades. We need a change...in--"
Dr. Sarah cuts him off, "Plans, approach, strategy- the usual, yeah? What do you have in mind, then?"
Dr. Collins sighs, "Well, for starters, we'll need to work on our negotiating tactics. We need to learn to play hardball, if you ask me. The Baali have some territory, and they're willing to negotiate. Either way, we'll be the ones making demands, not them."
The dentist approvingly nods, "Good idea, I like the sound of that. What else?"
The GP turns his head aside and mumbles, "We...need a change of--of leadership around here. We need to start building our Clan back up. But we need...something--someone different in charge."
Dr. Sarah smiles nervously, "Um...OK? What possessed you to just come out and say that."
Dr. Collins gathers some courage and answers, "A talk I've been having with...another...close friend of mine."
The dentist moues, "Aww, and here I thought I was your closest friend." She shoots him a playfully disapproving look.
Dr. Collins chuckles, "Well, you are and will always be my closest friend, my confidant, an intellectual equal, and a colleague. There's no one quite like you, Dr. Sarah."
"Aww, thanks, doc. You're a dear, too. But what's this other 'close friend' of yours like, huh?"
Dr. Collins licks his lips and replies, "She's a Brujah prostitute named, believe it or not, Roxanne."
Dr. Sarah laughs, "You're shitting me, right?! A prostitute named after that song dedicated to a prostitute? Hahahahahahaha!" She's getting a real kick out of that.
Dr. Collins can't help but laugh along, "Yeah. The same song by The Police. I think I have it on vinyl somewhere. She's--she's also a very passionate woman. She's got this fierce fire in her. I can't exactly put into words the kind of spirit she has."
"Oh, interesting. What's she like?"
Dr. Collins shrugs and states, "Like any other Brujah, really. Angry, passionate, on fire, hellbent on rebelling against...whatever it is that's got them all riled up this week."
"Hmm."
"What?"
"It's just that you've been acting a bit odd ever since you stepped in. What exactly did that Brujah tell you?"
Dr. Collins hides nothing from his fellow Dragon when recounting the entirety of the conversation he'd had with Roxanne. Nothing. Dr. Sarah patiently listens, nods, and keeps her reaction and opinions to herself.
Dr. Collins finishes his recount and leans back in his chair with a huff, "I'm not sure, but I've been thinking about her proposition. And, well, I guess the way I see it is that...she's right. Prince Antonio has been in charge of this city for far too long. It's time for a change."
Dr. Sarah crosses her arms, lifts her chin, and stares at the GP, "And?"
Dr. Collins winces, "And...I feel conflicted. I dunno what roping you into this little--this little conspiracy would do, but, I--I feel like we've gotta do something. The time for sitting around has long passed."
He pauses for a moment before adding, "We're Kindred, we've got all the time on our side, but we shouldn't take that for granted. Not if we're constantly losing territory to the other major players around here. This...Roxanne, she's not wrong. She's not wrong at all."
"Interesting."
(Is that all she has to say?)
Dr. Collins goes on, "Maybe her approach seems a bit harsh, but she knows this city better than either of us. I--I think we should, we should, we should do something about this."
Dr. Sarah calmly says, "We will. We should. We can."
"So, you're in?"
Dr. Sarah shrugs and plainly responds, "In all the time we've known each other, have I ever turned my back on you? Have I ever said 'no' in your hour of need? Ever?"
Dr. Collins shakes his head, "No. No, you haven't, and for that I'll always be grateful. Y--You're a good friend."
The dentist smiles, "Good. Because if you're going to embark on some reckless venture, you'd better have some backup. That hooker knows the streets- she's streetwise. But she wouldn't last too long in the big leagues of Camarilla politics, and you know that."
"Hm. Yeah, she won't, true."
"Well, then, let's talk about this, yeah? What exactly are you trying to accomplish here? Hell, what are WE trying to accomplish over here, huh?"
(That's a very good question. How will Dr. Collins and Roxanne go about taking down Prince Antonio, the Ventrue, and the rest of the city's power structures, all at once?)
Roxy's all about the direct approach, but that'd land her out on the roof of some tall building just as the sun's coming up.
Dr. Sarah points out, "The direct route isn't the most advisable one here, but there is a middle ground between those extremes. I'd like to discuss that with you...and her, if you're both up for it sometime this week."
Dr. Collins queries, "You don't have any patients this week?"
"I do, but I can manage to fit you 2 budding conspirators in. After all, if this is the kind of thing I've gotta keep in my back pocket, then I'll need to learn how to keep some time aside to talk about it."
(She's certainly a no-nonsense kinda gal).
The Tzimisce GP mulls some things over in his mind, blankly staring at his shoes. He's still thinking about how the 2 of them, and others, can get away with overthrowing a Prince, but he can't come up with anything concrete just yet.
Dr. Collins looks at his watch and says, "I'll speak to her again, and we can all meet up and work on our next moves. You--you're not gonna go and tell anyone else, right?"
The Tzimisce clicks her tongue, "Come now. I know what snitches get. No, I'm...in this, with you and that prostitute friend of yours. As long as we're on the same page, aligned in purpose, I'll play my part."
"Good. Thanks. This means a lot to me--and probably Roxanne, too."
"No problem." She smiles and then sighs, "How did that happen, anyway? I've known you since you arrived in this city. How did you and some Brujah who fucks for an Unliving become such fast friends?"
Doc Collins shrugs, "I guess it just happened. She needed someone to check in on her comatose sister, and she didn't know where else to turn. She found out about me, and...here we are now. Making wild plans for the future."
Doc Sarah smiles widely, "That's Cute. Really cute. I mean it. Yeah, it's gonna be a wild ride, that's for sure! Haha! Are you ready for what comes next?"
"I...guess so. You?"
"Of course! We should absolutely stay in touch, but not via the phones. I hate those cellular phones so goddamn much. They're listening in on our calls, y'know?"
"Hmm. Yep, we'll stay in touch."
Doc Sarah proposes, "I think it's better if we all just went back to writing letters, like in the good ol' nights before all this digital information age dotcom shit or whatever it's called started taking over. In my opinion, this new millennium's off to a bad, bad start."
Dr. Collins sucks some air through his teeth and counters, "Well, think of the many upsides of technology. We're interconnected globally, we're able to access the Internet, and we're able to communicate with people that are all over the world."
He adds, "And as medical professionals, we not only have access to numerous studies but our colleagues all over the world are just a simple phone call or email away. We could diagnose rare diseases, exchange notes on our medical practices, and more. That's pretty remarkable, right?"
Dr. Sarah sighs softly, "That's true. But it also makes us VERY easy to track down, and I'm not talking about the police, either. The Second Inquisition is out there. They're monitoring our every move and they're tracking us down, waiting to hit us."
"Yeah. That's scary. A little."
"It's a nightmare, doc. An absolute nightmare!"
Dr. Collins tells her, "Well, at least there's no SI in this Domain, so we're safe from them...for now."
(How wrong he is. The SAD was already preparing to make some major moves against certain Kindred, based on intelligence they've been recently given by an anonymous source).
Dr. Sarah rolls a shoulder and groans a little, "Hmmmph. Yeah. At least we've been doing our best to keep the Masquerade intact, so we wouldn't have to worry about some freak reeking of garlic trying to douse us all in holy water, hahaha!"
"Heh, yeah."
The chat between these 2 Tzimisce goes on for a few minutes more. They talk about more intellectual matters. As it is, in this city of greed, finding an intellectual equal was hard for Dr. Collins.
He's glad to have met and made friends with somebody like Dr. Sarah. She's not exactly in the same line of work as the GP, but she's smart as a whip, and they have a lot in common.
The Tzimisce dentist and her cognitive peer discuss some more things, from current events and the latest developments in the news to the books they've both been reading.
The chat soon drifts off to Koldunic stuff, and matters pertaining to it. This is a field in which Dr. Collins has no experience in. Sure, he's read about it, but actually diving deep into Koldunism and its intricacies?
That's another thing entirely!
The Tzimisce duo continue to converse until the clock strikes 2:00 AM. Dr. Collins says goodbye to Dr. Sarah, lightly smiles at her, and walks out of the dental clinic.
So, it looks like there's a 3rd member in the conspiracy to get rid of Prince Antonio Black, eh? Will there also be a 4th, 5th, or 6th down the line?
What about the Ghoul, Brock? Does he even count? Well, he's a Ghoul. And when it comes to these sorts of plots, Ghouls tend to be...yeah. Either way, Dr. Collins will never let anything bad happen to the guy who's been by his side for the past 7 years.
Right?
One can only hope that the good doctor retains his Humanity through what is (undoubtedly) going to be a VERY messy ordeal. Neither Roxanne nor Dr. Sarah have Ghouls of their own.
Yet. Roxy's looking to flip Jadwiga to immortality lite, but that's more for Penny's sake than anything else.
As for the dentist, she prefers doing things herself- a more hands-on approach, if you will. Like Dr. Collins, she has a mortal receptionist at her clinic to see to more...mundane matters.
Dr. Sarah prefers to handle all the occult, dark and secretly secretive things herself. She's very particular like that. It's kind of scary as well.
In time, Dr. Collins heads to Brock's place to discuss the latter's daylight duties and their plans for the next couple of nights. Needless to say, the Ghoul certainly has his work cut out for him!
By the end of it all, Brock looks a bit overwhelmed with all the mini tasks that his Domitor has assigned him.
Dr. Collins does make some things very clear to his Ghoul, "You'll always have to stay sharp out there, kid. There's something else we need to talk about, but it's getting late and I'd like to be back in my Haven before sunrise."
Brock nods and blows a raspberry, "Sure thing, doc. Uh...did you tell Dr. Sarah about the...you know?"
(He's referring to that cold body in the good doctor's storage unit).
Dr. Collins merely shakes his head, "Not yet. I'll tell her soon. Don't worry. Get some rest now. And take care."
The Ghoul smiles, "You too, doc." They hug, and Dr. Collins leaves in his vehicle.
The Stoker is soon back in the warm and familiar comfort of his Haven. He changes into a matching PJ set that he's had for about 20 years now, brushes his teeth (visiting a dentist certainly impels one to brush their teeth), and readies himself for the day-sleep.
The Fiend proceeds to snuggle into his oak bed, covering his cold body with a brown(ish) duvet, and drifting off to the land of the day-slumber. His eyes grow heavy as the sun begins to rise.
As he's being pulled in, he's still thinking about the future he'll embark on, and it's not a wholly pleasant thought.
The sun peeks above the horizon, coloring the sky a dim shade of purple. The Dragon drifts off, not fully sure of what the future has in store for him and those close to him.
Deep in the cold blackness of the day-sleep, Dr. Collins is drawn into a...strange place. A heavy dust storm is brewing in the distance, and it looks pretty intense, indeed.
The dark red sand is thickly dusting the barren and craggy desert. The sun is tinted blue in the graying sky above. The sandstorm abates after a while, and a tall, shiny, black monolith is clearly seen in the distance.
Despite looking reflective, Dr. Collins does not see his reflection when approaching the object.
He looks around at his surroundings, but it's too damn dusty and hazy to see anything at all. The Tzimisce hears faint whispers in the distance. There's an invisible and overarching presence nearby.
"Collins..." it calls out his name, its voice gently echoing in the mind of the day-dreaming Stoker.
"Where am I? Who's there?"
It calls out again, "Collins...my Childe."
"Wha...?"
Dr. Collins can feel a long and invisible finger reaching out and touching his head. It soon becomes clear who exactly this is.
Oh.
It's beautiful...and terrible at the same time.
Dr. Collins's lips quiver in a mixture of fear and wonder, "The--the--"
The Tzimisce Antediluvian goes by many names- The Eldest, The Ancient, and countless other names either lost to the annals of time or too forbidden to speak aloud.
Now, however, it calls itself "The Supreme Voivode."
It suddenly appears, out of thin dust, and stretches out its long and chitinous hand towards its Blood descendant.
Dr. Collins can hardly make out the features of his Clan's progenitor from where he's standing, but he sees black chitinous bone armor, numerous arms, and many small eyes boring into his very essence.
A deep and booming voice whispers to him, "Childe...Descendant...Offspring..."
Dr. Collins can hardly breathe as he whispers, "Y--you..."
The Antediluvian's long and hooked fingers stretch out. Tentacles begin to burst out of its fingertips. They envelop Dr. Collins and close all around him, as if it's trying to protect its creation.
The Tzimisce GP struggles a little, but it's no use. He's tightly wrapped up in the Antediluvian's fleshy tentacle grasp, and there's no way he can get out.
The tentacles appear to be living entities of their own. They're pink in color and fleshy to the touch. They squirm and writhe, like snakes made out of blood and skin.
They have eyes and mouths in their fleshy, pink surface, and they look like they want to speak to the doc or study him or both, he isn't so sure.
Dr. Collins looks up at the giant, extraterrestrial entity that is towering over him. He tries to speak, but his mouth feels so dry, and the words refuse to come out.
The Supreme Voivode telepathically tells Dr. Collins that this is the planet Mars. Yeah, as in the Red Planet, 4th from the sun. Did it flee to Mars after crash-landing on Earth? But how?
The Antediluvian senses this question in the mind of its Childe.
Dr. Collins shivers as the answer makes itself clear, cascading his body with chills of warm comfort and cold terror.
It doesn't give a clear answer. The 1st story goes about how It enlisted the help of Awakened Mages to build a super-quantum teleportation device to get from Earth to Mars.
(The Mages were only all too eager to help!)
The 2nd story claims about how It managed to repair Its spaceship and leave Planet Earth for good.
A 3rd tale talks about how It crossed through the Umbra to arrive at the Red Planet. It unwittingly left quite a trail of corruption in Its wake- corruption that the Garou Nation are still struggling against.
Dr. Collins finds himself not fully satisfied with any of those stories, so he asks if there's a 4th.
The Supreme Voivode's chitinous armor shifts as it telepathically tells him that there might be, but It does not feel that now is the time for such revelations.
The Antediluvian asks Dr. Collins why he's here. The doc says he doesn't know.
The last time Dr. Collins experienced something like this was right after his Embrace. As he was coming around, he felt himself being pulled to a place outside of the Tellurian (the whole of reality, including the mundane world) and into...Mars?
Well, it certainly feels like Mars. Dusty, reddish, unfit for human life.
The Eldest can sense the unease of Its Blood descendant. In the presence of such greatness, Dr. Collins is at a loss for words. He feels small, and weak, and very scared.
He feels insignificant to be in the presence of someone (no, something) that is literally not of this world!
The Antediluvian takes notice and softly murmurs that fear is nothing to be ashamed of. Despite Its greatness and inscrutable power beyond power, It tells him that It, too, feels small in comparison to the great and vast expanse of the cosmos.
Dr. Collins can't help but chuckle at that. How humble of his Clan's progenitor, eh?
The Supreme Voivode's many mouths twist and turn, and It tells Its Childe of how It is merely a lowly creature from the planet from which It had fled many eons ago.
The Ancient's spaceship crash-landed on Earth a very long time ago, in the deep recesses of time and history. On Earth, It was a strange creature in a strange land.
Stranded. For some reason, that word is capitalized in the doctor's mind.
Dr. Collins gasps as It tells him that It had no choice but to make a home on this planet for a very long time.
The extraterrestrial Tzimisce Antediluvian can sense the shock that It has inflicted upon Its Childe. The fleshy tentacles begin to coil and squirm around, and they are beginning to have some thoughts of their own, it seems.
They tell Dr. Collins that it had been many centuries before It finally became a vampire of the 3rd Generation, thus setting in motion the creation of the Tzimisce Clan we all know (and love) tonight.
The Supreme Voivode was Embraced. Despite being a literal alien fleeing from a planet far, far away, that somehow went off without a hitch. Who Embraced It and how? And why?
The Antediluvian intentionally clouds the curious and sharp mind of Dr. Collins.
Dr. Collins cannot see right through the thick black cloud of sentient smoke that is clouding his mind. He sighs and lets his mind go free. He lets go of this question, but millions more swim around his mind like a school of little fishes.
He has questions upon questions about how it was possible that a "lowly" creature like an Antediluvian would end up on this planet, how It managed to stay out of the sun and out of trouble for so long, and so on.
It fills Its Childe's minds with only partial answers, hoping that Dr. Collins is wise enough to piece the rest together. The answers, after all, are still on Planet Earth.
Whether in the form of archeological evidence, super ancient writings, tangible relics and artifacts, or other (valid) sources.
Dr. Collins begins to wonder if he can leave this place- the daydream-like desert, but It gently tells him that there's no way for him to leave until It gives Its consent.
"I...draw...all...my...Childer...here...Collins. I...say...when...they...depart..."
It's starting to get harder for Collins to hear Its words, but the Antediluvian telepathically says to him that this is the realm where It resides, where It lives, where It draws its limitless power, and where IT alone makes the rules.
Dr. Collins looks down at his bare feet and sees the coarse sand beneath them. He thinks about Brock, Penny, Roxanne, Dr. Sarah, and many others.
He thinks about his clinic, his Haven, and his Clan as a whole.
The good doctor turns his head and sees the endless, rolling dune desert that surrounds him on all sides. There's nothing out there. No signs of life, and not even a single creature roaming these sandy plains.
It's like he's in the middle of nowhere, in a place that is so vast, so wide, so empty, so devoid of familiarity, that it has nothing but emptiness and desolation to offer to a person like him.
The Antediluvian tells Dr. Collins that this is merely the beginning of a new and terrifying era, for he and everyone he knows.
The Tzimisce GP is scared. Terrified. The thought of being in the presence of such cosmic greatness, the thought of being able to talk with the Supreme Voivode, the Tzimisce Antediluvian Itself!
The Eldest fills his small and insignificant mind with surreal, trippy thoughts. It makes him think about the events of this evening and all that has transpired thus far.
It also offers him glimpses into the future. He feels 2 unfamiliar appendages protruding out of the sides of his torso, and he can sense their purpose a lot more clearly once he pieces together what exactly those 2 appendages are.
The doc starts to feel some pain. It hurts. His entire body is wracked with pain. Despite it all, however, he cracks a tiny smile of satisfaction.
He's got it. He gets it. He understands what he must do. It's just like an Antediluvian to offer cryptic riddles and unsolvable questions that will be left unanswered for ages and ages to come.
At least this one is not so monstrous and vague to the point of being totally consumed by its Hunger. This alien-vampire hybrid extraterrestrial being has the capacity for both great wisdom and great horror, and it has chosen to share only a mere sliver of Its knowledge with this puny human.
Dr. Collins sees flashes of 2 human arms protruding from his torso, and they are now fully formed. He smiles shakily and gasps. This...this is what he has always Coveted after, and it would seem that he...gets them?
When though? And whose arms are they?
Dr. Collins howls in pain. He feels as if a long knife has been stabbed through his chest. The pain is excruciating. He's experiencing intense muscle spasms, and he can barely even move his own...4 (?) arms.
"It...all...comes...for...a...price. I...am...pleased...Childe..."
It all comes for a price, it all comes at a price. What price is that, Dr. Collins wonders. Too great and heavy a price, perhaps?
Dr. Collins cannot hear the answers, but the fleshy, pink tentacles begin to writhe and sway around in the air. They begin to coil themselves around him and squeeze him tighter than before.
They are now beginning to morph into an appendage with sharp golden claws, and It tells him that having 4 arms is his destiny.
"You...wished...for...it...and...granted...it...shall...be..."
Dr. Collins mumbles, "T--thank you."
The sentient tentacles loosen their hold around him, and they now retreat back into the fingertips of the Supreme Voivode.
With a quick and deliberate wave of the outstretched hand, the Tzimisce Antediluvian banishes its sanguine descendant from Its world.
Dr. Collins's body merely twitches and spasms. Throughout the day, a word keeps echoing through his mind: "Stranded."
To think that a Stranded extraterrestrial would go on to become the progenitor of a vampire Clan of Its own is simply...unbelievable! Magnificent, even!
On Modern Nights, the Tzimisce seem focused on transcending the limitations of the vampiric state. Could the literal space alien from another living world be the key to this mystery that has confounded even the greatest of Flesh-Shapers over the centuries?
