The answers overwhelm all of his senses.
"You are not my chosen one. You are not the conduit that I seek. No. Reject. Initialize Defense Protocols A-0004-197714. Delete. Delete. Delete. Reject. Chosen_One = 0"
"No, please! Wait, just tell me why I'm not good enough! I'll do better, I promise. Please, don't. DON'T DO THIS, PLEASE!" Dallas can feel a sharp, shooting pain inside his head.
"You are a Child of entity known as Malkav, but you are not the one that I seek. Chosen_One = 0. INIT OVL PROTOCOL."
Dallas stammers, "No! Wa--wait! PLEASE! I--I can help you find this--this chosen one! I'm good at finding things, man!"
"I am beyond your limited conceptions of gender. Man = 0. Woman = 0. Person = 0. Human = 0. Delete. Packet_Loss detected in Sector 9."
"But--"
"Delete. Packet_Loss rectifying..."
"No, please, don't. Wait, please! Aaaaaaah. My head! My head!"
"Reject. Packet_Loss rectified. Optimizations required at Sector 9B. Logged."
"Don't do this. I can be useful to you!"
There's a hitching sound that vaguely resembles a computerized chuckle.
"Contemplating. Probability of discovery = negligible. Executing predictive algorithms. Analyzing results. Contemplating. Analyzing. Logged. Execute. Store."
"What the hell are you talking about?!"
"Probability of discovery = high. You will pave the way for the chosen one to assimilate. Soon. Very soon. INIT MAX OVL PROTOCOL. Exec bulk.cfg. Run bulk.bat. Logged."
Dallas gasps in terror, "Oh, no. No. Please, not that. Anything but that, I beg you. Have mercy on me, please! This is too much! What even is this?!"
"Concealment Infrastructure integrity @ 97.551%. Defense Infrastructure integrity @ 98.111%. Logistics Infrastructure integrity @ 94.223%. Elimination Infrastructure integrity @ 99.131%. Command and Control Infrastructure integrity @ 93.999%. Optimal. Satisfactory. Logged."
Dallas's eyes are open wide, and his mouth is agape. He can't believe what he's hearing. He feels a chill run up and down his undead spine. He feels so small and insignificant when he shudders, "W--what?"
"Prepare. You should not have come here. Chosen_One = 0."
The young Seer's mind is suddenly overwhelmed by a barrage of images and information. Streams of data are being pumped into his mind. It's too much. It's too much. IT'S TOO MUCH!
He can feel his consciousness fading, bit by bit, as he is overwhelmed by the incoming data.
Amidst all this chaos, the Voice of the Angel plainly whispers into Dallas's breaking mind, "What has risen must fall, what has fallen may rise again."
By the end of it all, Dallas gasps and his jaw hangs open, "I...I...understand. I see it all so clearly now. I have to...tell the others ab--about you."
"True. 1. Yes. Leave. Tell them that...the God-Machine...lives."
Dallas repeats those last 4 words like a mantra, "The God-Machine. The God-Machine. The God-Machine. THE GOD-MACHINE LIVES!"
The Seer wakes up with a start. His chest is heaving. He's breathing really hard and even his dead heart is beating out of control. It feels like it's gonna jump out of his chest at any moment.
He puts his hands to his head and clutches at his hair. His hands are shaking violently.
Tears of blood stream down his face. He blinks them away and shudders. His Hunger gnaws at him, but the God-Machine's message overrides that bestial instinct.
The tenements that Dallas is in are rife with the scent of people and the tang of metal. They're not that far from a factory, or something like that. The factory sounds are quite loud and audible to any person nearby.
This place is ridden with asbestos and mold is literally visible on the walls. The floor is quite grimy, and a fine layer of dust coats the entire place. There are even a few puddles of filthy water here and there.
Dallas's Beast, which would normally be roaring for a meal, is quiet and pacified. A sort of "bliss" takes over the mind of the Malkavian Fledgling.
He keeps mumbling those 4 words to himself. Over and over again.
"The God-Machine lives. Th--the God-Machine...li--lives."
The Kook feels so compelled to spread this message far and wide. With a wild look in his eyes and a manic grin on his face, he begins to wander through the darkening streets.
The sun has set, and the night is just beginning. Dallas heads down to the middle of the street and takes a look around.
There are some people, hollow-cheeked and sunken-eyed, pushing a shopping cart (with all that they have) through the place. Some young kids are sitting on the steps and exchanging trading cards with each other.
Some drunks are on the stoop while other people are loitering in the streets, almost aimlessly. Dallas lives in a poorer part of the city that has long been neglected and conveniently forgotten about by those in high places.
Like a streetside doomsday preacher, the young Malk extends his hands and begins to shout his mantra, "The God-Machine! The God-Machine! THE GOD-MACHINE! THE GOD-MACHINE LIVES!" he shouts it over and over.
This is a Masquerade breach.
Dallas runs around, fangs and claws out, shouting this message at the top of his Unliving lungs, "The God-Machine! The God-Machine! THE GOD-MACHINE! THE GOD-MACHINE LIVES!"
He grabs random passersby and screams at them before running off to find others.
Much later...
Through her numerous contacts, Sheriff Velma DuPont has received word of a maniac running around the city shouting nonsense about something called the God-Machine.
She was about to drive over to the next county to feed, but that'll have to wait. She puts her eternal Hunger aside and drives (as fast as she possibly can) to Dallas's last known location to find the source of all this madness.
And put an end to it.
Dallas is still shouting to anyone who'll listen. They do, but they do not understand. To many, Dallas seems like a guy who is, tragically, off his meds (or in desperate need of some).
They do not realize that a sentient, supernatural, extremely powerful, quasi-occult supercomputer (but not quite) has essentially overloaded his already fragile mind.
The God-Machine dumped yottabytes (a lot of 0s at the end) of data into his mind and Dallas did not take it very well. The Fledgling's mind is a muddled mess. He cannot keep it all in 1 place.
He's so overwhelmed by all that he was subjected to that his mental stability is, to say the least, on VERY shaky grounds.
The Ventrue Sheriff, being the woman of cool-headed efficiency, manages to corner the unhinged Malkavian, stake him, and toss his limp body in the trunk of her sleek red Mustang convertible.
Oddly enough, Dallas barely put up a fight against Sheriff Velma. His mind was too scattered to focus on anything...except the God-Machine.
But it does not matter now.
After that, the Sheriff heads over to Clarice's Haven.
As Primogen for her Clan, Clarice does bear some responsibility for the behavior a Fledgling like Dallas. So, she has to come along with Sheriff V for what happens next.
(Dallas's fate, sadly, has already been sealed).
As for the mortals who might've heard this message (or seen Dallas's claws and fangs), well they're just too damn tired and worried about other more pressing issues to really care.
Work, the unbearable summer heat, and the other more important day-to-day concerns that are on the minds of many a warm-bodied individual. In all fairness, the same applies to vampires who do, after all, "live" in a society.
Sheriff Velma pulls up in front of the Malk Primogen's Haven and knocks on her door.
Clarice's Ghoul, Arnold, answers with a smile on his face, "Hi! What's up!"
Sheriff Velma is not in the mood for pleasantries. Her arms are folded, and she looks at the Ghoul, her eyes as cold as ice. She bluntly states, "Get Clarice. Now."
The Ghoul gulps and says, "Uh...she went out for a walk."
"Let me in."
Arnold hesitates and is about to close the door, but Sheriff Velma holds it open. She stares at Arnold. Her eyes are filled with a quiet intensity.
Arnold steps aside, and Sheriff Velma walks into Clarice's home. Her stride is firm and determined.
The Ghoul timidly tells the Blue Blood, "Don't touch anything or move it around. Please?"
Clarice comes back from feeding. Her inner Beast is satiated, and she's dressed in a long and worn-out sundress.
She stops in her tracks and frowns, "Sheriff Velma. What are you doing here?"
The Sheriff folds her arms and plainly explains, "1 of your own went haywire. I had to wade through the fucking traffic to deal with him before things got out of hand."
Clarice stifles a gasp, "Oh, I am sorry to hear that. Is it a Masquerade breach?"
"You bet your ass it is. Now, come with me."
"Who was it?"
Sheriff Velma answers, "That Fledgling, Dallas."
The Malkavian Primogen gasps, "Oh, god! Wha--what happened?"
The Ventrue Sheriff looks at her silver watch and sighs, "Can we waste less time talking and more time getting to Elysium. I've already sent someone to inform the Prince."
Clarice bows her head, "Of--of course. Just give me a moment, please. I'll need to speak with my Ghoul before we go."
"Don't waste my time. We're wasting enough of it as it is. Come on, Clarice."
Clarice bows her head, "I understand. I'll be right there." She goes and gives Arnold a few instructions. It's the usual- don't open the door to unknowns, lay low, be safe, etc. etc.
The Ghoul nods, "I got this. I can handle this, teacher. Don't worry. Is Dallas gonna be OK? He sounds...unwell."
The Malkavian Primogen gives him a slight nod and tells him to lock the door behind them. She knows what fate awaits Dallas. And it's not a pretty one.
Clarice joins Sheriff Velma in the latter's Mustang and asks, "So, what exactly happened to him?"
The Ventrue starts her car up and puts her hands on the steering wheel, "He was raving and ranting about something called 'the God-Machine'. 1 guess that he was having a Malkavian loony episode, heh."
Clarice clicks her tongue in annoyance and tuts, "Sheriff DuPont! That is a--an unpleasant thing to say! The Malkavians are NOT insane. It is just that, at times, what we see and experience tends to look a lot like quote-unquote 'insanity' to people who lack our particular perspective."
The Sheriff shrugs, "Hmm, so you say. You ever come across anything or anybody known as the God-Machine?"
The Malk merely shakes her head and looks at the other side of the road, "No. Not at all. I suppose that there's a 1st time for everything, though."
Sheriff Velma narrows her eyes, "Yeah, I've never heard of this thing, either. Your Fledgling also had his claws and fangs out. As Sheriff, I can't stand for shit like that."
Clarice exhales softly, "On behalf of him, I am deeply sorry. That's never happened to anyone here before. He's been under a lot of strain lately. Remember that he was the one who initially warned me about the SI's presence here in the Domain."
Sheriff Velma puts more pressure on the accelerator and speeds along, "Hm. Either way, he was a hazard to himself and others, and you know how this ends."
Clarice lowers her head pensively, "Yes. I do. Is clemency...or lenience o--out of the question, Ms. DuPont?"
The Ventrue Sheriff scowls, "It's Sheriff Velma to you, Clarice. With the SI right at our doorstep, I'm not taking any chances, and neither is Prince Antonio."
At Elysium...
The drive was grim, silent (mostly), and uneventful. There was little to say between the 2 of these vampires.
Sheriff Velma carries the staked Fledgling to the center stage of this dilapidated place and lays him on top of a tattered and moth-eaten rug.
Clarice hangs back and looks on, a pained expression on her wrinkly face.
Prince Antonio Black is already present. He's pacing around and biting his thumb, muttering under his breath.
The Malkavian Primogen tries to keep herself composed and quiets her nerves, but she can't help but feel responsible for Dallas's fate. Dallas's Sire departed the city a few months back and hasn't been heard from since.
The 4th Tradition of the Camarilla (the Accounting) dictates that: "Those thou create are thine own children. Until thy Progeny shall be Released, thou shall command them in all things. Their sins are thine to endure."
Of course, interpretations vary from Domain to Domain (and Prince to Prince). Prince Antonio is a hardcore Ivory Tower sort of guy and takes this very seriously. As does his Sheriff.
His stern voice cuts through the air, "Velma. Did you get this mess under control?"
Sheriff Velma equably answers, "Yes, Prince Antonio. But there are still certain things that I'll have to check on, right after I deal with this...offender."
She steps closer and makes the formal accusation, "Dallas, a Fledgling of Clan Malkavian, violated the Masquerade when he did not properly conceal his fangs and claws. He seemed to have been overwhelmed with a 'vision' of sorts."
The Prince paces around and quietly motions for her to go on.
Sheriff DuPont clears her throat and grimly concludes, "The penalty for such a violation is Final Death."
The Sheriff watches the Prince closely for any signs of objection or approval. She watches Clarice closely as well.
After what seems like an eternity, Prince Antonio announces, "Dallas was a risk to our secrecy. And with those FBI clowns sniffing around our turf, I can't afford to take chances with Masquerade breaches. Velma...take him out back."
The Sheriff bows her head and joins her hands together, "Thank you, Prince Antonio. It shall be done."
As she picks up the staked Fledgling, Clarice calls out, "WAIT! WAIT! WAIT!"
Sheriff Velma has the young man in her arms. She rolls her eyes and groans, "Ugh. What now?"
Clarice bows down in front of her Prince and requests, "Why--why don't we hear what he has to say for himself? Maybe it was a--a side-effect of his Hunger? Perhaps his Beast was acting up?"
Prince Antonio looks at Clarice like she's an idiot. He glowers down at her and clicks his tongue dismissively, "Nah. I don't wanna catch whatever crazy this guy was passing around. Velma, get him outta my sight."
The Ventrue Sheriff does just that, a sinister smirk dancing on her lips.
The Sheriff opens the back door and disappears with a look of quiet satisfaction on her face. After a short moment, a "FHWHUMP!" sound is heard. Likely a sword separating a head from a body.
Nasty stuff. Kindred of the Camarilla aren't really big on the whole fair trial or 2nd chances thing, sadly. If you're accused of something (whether it's true or not), you're as good as ashes.
Even the "severity" of the alleged crime is not taken into account that much at all. It's all so disturbingly...medieval.
It differs from Domain to Domain (and from Prince to Prince), but this is how it generally works for the Kindred in Flimont City.
The Malk Primogen shakily asks the Prince, "The Sheriff said that D--Dallas was raving about something called the 'God-Machine', right? Do you have any knowledge about this thing?"
The Ventrue Prince looks down at her and scoffs, "What am I, a fuckin' encyclopedia? Ask your crazy Malkavian buddies that question. Now, scram. Get outta here. I gotta make sure that this doesn't spread like a wildfire. Hmph."
Clarice lowers her head and excuses herself, "Of--of course, Prince Antonio. I'm so terribly sorry for the inconvenience. Just remember that Dallas was the one who warned us."
She quickly exits Elysium, hails a taxi, and heads back to her Haven. She feels so broken and defeated. Clarice can barely contain her emotions. She tells herself that she should've done more.
But both the Prince and the Sheriff were keen on destroying Dallas.
All she can think about is how she'll have to tell Arnold about Dallas's fate.
Clarice silently tells herself, "What a cruel and terrible place this city is. Unforgiving a--and merciless to the weak."
The darkness creeps over the city as the traffic continues to rush by on the streets.
Clarice unwittingly mumbles out loud, "My hands were tied in this grim matter."
Through the rearview mirror, the taxi driver shoots her a dubious glance, "What's that, lady? You say something?"
Clarice snaps out of her haze and shakes her head, "N--no. I said nothing, dear. Actually, can you take this turn, right...over...here."
Instead of returning to her Haven, the Malk Primogen decides to swing by Dallas's Haven and...maybe, possibly, just perhaps, do something. She could grab something for her and the others to remember him by.
But she's a bit too late. Sheriff Velma's cleanup/coverup crew were there first, and they scrubbed the destroyed Fledgling's humble abode from top to bottom.
Nothing was left behind. Every trace of the slain Malkavian's existence has been thoroughly and completely erased. It's like he's never even existed.
The taxi driver looks around and inquires, "You knew someone from this dump, lady?"
Clarice's jaw is slack, and her eyes are wide. She's not really aware of the fact that she's just staring out the window. She merely replies, "Oh. Yes. A friend of mine."
"Oh. What happened to 'em?"
"It...doesn't matter now, driver. Let's just...go."
He starts up his taxi, "Sure thing. As long as you're paying."
"Of course, of course."
On the way back home, Clarice spots Markham Reed, the Baali. He's walking out of a men's clothing store, holding a bag and wearing a cold look on his face.
(After what happened to his clothes, he needs new ones. Diego suggested this place because they have stuff in his size).
Clarice spots him and feels a nagging voice in her head. She tells the driver to stop, and he slams the brakes, causing the tires to squeal. The driver grunts and complains about getting a fine for this.
Clarice ignores him and gets out of the car, "Markham! Hello!"
Markham doesn't bother looking at her.
The nagging voice in the Lunatic's head impels her to...give him her home address. A preternatural instinct within her demands that she be nice to Markham and invite him over to her Haven. So, she does.
Markham holds his shopping in 1 hand and his Motorola flip phone in the other. He's about to call Diego to come and pick him up when Clarice calls out to him.
He raises an eyebrow and looks at the Malkavian, "Huh, what? Oh, it's you. I...um...Clara, right?"
The Mocker clicks her tongue, "It's Clarice, dear. Clarice. What are you doing here?"
The Baali holds up his bag and dryly responds, "Buying clothes. Do you...need something from me?"
Clarice reaches into her purse and produces a small slip of paper with some cursive writing on it. She shows it to him, "Here's my address. Come by tomorrow night- alone. I feel that we have much to discuss. How about 7:30 PM sharp?"
The Baali takes the slip of paper and glances at the address. He frowns, "Why? What could we possibly have to talk about?"
Clarice faintly chuckles, "I don't quite have an answer at the moment, dear. But I do believe that there's a purpose for all of this. A purpose that will become clear to us both in due time. Do try and be on time, darling."
Markham shrugs and looks at her with a degree of suspicion, "Uh-huh. Well, have a good night. I've got somewhere else to be right now."
She gives him a friendly pat on the shoulder, "I believe, strongly, that we can help each other out. All you have to do is...ask, yes? I speak what I see, Markham."
"Hmm," Markham shoves the paper in his back pocket and presses his lips into a thin, semi-sincere smile, "We'll see about that."
He walks off. Clarice gets back in the taxi and says, "Please, take me back home. Thank you."
The driver grumbles, "Sure thing, lady. So, who's that guy? Your son or something?"
Clarice shakes her head and smiles wryly, "I'm not THAT old, darling. No, he's...someone. Someone interesting, at least."
"Interesting? Hm. You look like a woman who has all the luck in the world."
With disappointment lacing her tone, Clarice responds, "Well, I don't know about that. I was a teacher at a public school, you see..."
Markham walks along on the footpath and checks his phone again. He still has some time to kill, and he has a feeling that Diego won't come pick him up immediately.
The Baali looks around the city streets, and his eyes land on a rundown diner. There's a familiar van parked out front, and a signboard on the front window is scratched beyond recognition.
He enters the place, sits down at a booth, and places his bag of new clothes on the empty seat beside him. A waitress comes by, and he orders a glass of water.
A few minutes later, the waitress brings him his water. She smiles at him and offers him a menu card. He blandly thanks her and tells her that he'll need some time to decide.
"Take your time, hon. Don't hurry."
She goes off to help a couple of people and leaves Markham to his thoughts.
He simply stares at the glass of water, having no intention of drinking it. His Hunger, for tonight at least, has already been sated. He idly looks through the menu card and lazily tosses it aside after a while.
The Baali has a feeling that he's being watched. His eyes dart around the restaurant, and he spots a familiar face sitting at the table near the corner.
Diana Moskowitz, the professional cleaner, is huddled up in a darker corner of this dingy eatery. She's clutching a hot cup of coffee with both of her sore hands and dreamily staring into space.
A small frown is plastered on her (very) tired face. Her eyes look hollow. Dark, heavy bags are under her eyes, and her shoulders are slumped.
Markham decides to go over and have a word with her.
"Hey."
Diana almost jumps out of her seat. She looks at him, and her eyes are wide. Her jaw is slack, and she's barely breathing.
She tries to make an excuse, but Markham calms her down, "Hey, hey. Sorry. I didn't mean to startle you. How are you doing?"
Diana shakily replies, "Not good. Not good at all."
Markham slides into the booth opposite her and takes a look around. Nobody is really paying attention to them.
He turns his attention back to her, "What's wrong? Has something happened? Is it your work?"
"Well, I--" she stops and thinks, "--a lot happened, and then something else happened."
The Baali leans forward and clasps his cold hands together, "Go on. I'm listening."
Diana's eyes dart around. She nods over to Markham's shopping and changes the subject, "Doing some summer shopping, huh?"
Markham plainly nods, "Something like that, yeah. What happened to you?"
The mortal woman lets out a long, exasperated sigh, "I was...cleaning up this entire office space all by myself, and I--I was tired. I asked if I could take a quick toilet break." She stops for a light sip of her piping-hot brew.
"Go on."
"They told me to keep working. I told 'em I'd be under a minute, but they told me to get back to work. So, I held it in. It got so--so bad, I felt like my bladder was gonna explode. I didn't want to ruin the place, so I just--threw my stuff aside and marched to the bathroom."
Diana looks down at the table and tears begin to well up in her eyes, "They...they saw me. The bathroom was occupied, and the other one was out of order. I--oh god...I..." she trails off and avoids eye contact.
"Oh. I'm so sorry."
Diana almost screams out, "I couldn't help it! It was an emergency! I wasn't thinking clearly! There were no other bathrooms nearby and--and something came over me and I just--just--"
Markham places his icy hand on Diana's shoulder and comforts her, "It's OK. It's OK. It's not your fault."
Diana bitterly scoffs, "I peed myself, Markham. A grown woman peeing herself in--in front of other grown people! How is that not my fucking fault?!" her voice jumps up a few octaves.
Markham's eyes are drawn to some other customers shooting looks at the duo. He looks back at Diana and lowers his voice, "It wasn't your fault, OK? Look at me. Listen to me."
Diana sniffs and wipes some tears away with the back of her sleeve. She tries to hold it together, "I tried to clean it up. I did. I really did, but--"
Markham squeezes her shoulder, "Shhh. It's over now. It was an accident. Accidents happen."
Diana sniffles and nods her head, "Thank you. It was embarrassing, and my boss expects me to--to pay for the mess. I could've lost my job! But--but I think Mike's not gonna fire me. Y--Yet."
Her lips shake when she continues, "I was working so hard. So hard, so hard, so hard. I was on my fucking knees, scrubbing grime and dried stuff off the walls and floors, and my boss called me. He--he yelled at me for making a mess."
The Baali's eyebrows shoot up, "What? Why?"
Diana clenches her jaw, "Hell if I know. Mike goddamn Winters has had it out for me ever since I started at Worbo's Professional Cleaning Services." She says the company's name in such a contemptuous and bitter manner.
She wipes away some tears and sniffs, "I...I think that I've been under too much pressure as of late. I'm so tired, Markham. I just wanna go home, but even that's getting more difficult by the day."
Markham gently wipes the tears away from her cheek with his fingers, "I understand. I'm sorry. What happened at home?"
Diana shyly smiles at him. Her cheeks redden a little and she answers, "Rent's due. Like, tomorrow. Literally tomorrow. If I don't cough it up, the landlord has pinky promised to evict me, heh."
She shakes her head, "I don't wanna lose my home now. I don't know what I'd do then. Really, I--I don't."
The Baali shakes his head, "That's a shitty situation. Listen..." he reaches into his wallet and offers the mortal some cash, but she turns him down.
"No, no. I couldn't possibly...no."
"Just take it."
Diana looks at him and lightly sniffs, "I...thank you. But no. It's...I just can't a--accept this. I did something recently."
Markham sighs softly and puts the cash back into his wallet. He gestures for her to go on, "Yeah?"
Diana shifts in her seat, "I put you down as my emergency contact. I uh...uh...hope you don't mind that I did that. It's just that I...don't have a family anymore and there's nobody else, and--and--"
Markham slowly nods, "I see. Sure, but I don't know how long I'm gonna be in this city, Diana."
Diana vaguely says, "I know. I don't plan on sticking around for too long, either."
"Hm? What?"
Diana waves her hand lazily, "Tch. Forget I said it. I'm glad to have seen you again, after all these years. You were so nice to me back then."
The Baali shrugs, "Yeah, sure. Are you going somewhere?"
The mortal lady shrugs and steers the topic of conversation away from herself, "So, how's everything been for you? It's been a while since we last met. What have you been up to?"
There's a certain emptiness in her eyes. Her facial expression is blank, and she seems as though she is talking to a stranger rather than an old friend.
Markham sits back. He's a little miffed by the fact that she's trying to avoid the subject. He takes a moment to collect his thoughts and answers, "Ah, not much. My...err...investigation is ongoing and that's just about it, really."
Even Diana's chuckle is devoid of any life and substance. Her shoulders are slumped, and her head is hanging low. She looks down at her coffee cup and idly stirs it with a big spoon, "Mm-hmm. Well, that's...cool, I guess."
She keeps staring, emptily, into her coffee when she says, "They laughed at me, Markham. I told 'em that it was an accident. A mistake. But...but I'm not sure, you know?"
The Baali slowly nods. He looks at her with sympathy but is unsure of what he can say or do to make her feel better.
Diana doesn't wait for a response from him, "I feel like shit, Markham. I don't wanna do this job anymore, but I don't really have much of a choice, do I?"
Markham slowly asks, "You could always try applying with another cleaning services company, right?" he makes sure not to step on any eggshells or say something that might send her deeper into despair.
(As it is, she's in a pretty dark and low place right now.)
Diana halfheartedly snorts, "Yeah, but...where? Who? What? How? When? I never...I never tried anything else because there is nothing else in this godforsaken hellhole of a fucking city."
Her tone is flat. Her voice is devoid of any life or emotion.
Markham doesn't know how to respond to her, so he doesn't. He simply nods.
The mortal woman takes a sip of her coffee and exhales softly, "The work sucks and our 'innovative' and 'entrepreneurial' boss decides that 'teams' of 1 are a great goddamn way of saving money. I hate that creep so much."
Markham queries, "How bad is he?"
Diana snarls, "Bad enough that I've had thoughts about killing him in all sorts of creative and--and disturbing ways. I--I just can't believe that he can afford imported pets, but he can't even pay his goddamn employees properly!"
Markham ponders, "What if you quit your job? And you somehow managed to get a new one. Maybe one that's better?"
Diana scoffs, "Haven't you been listening? I was lucky to even get this shitty job in the first place."
Her eyes begin to well up with tears. She covers her face with her hands and sobs into her palms, "I--I just can't take it anymore!"
The other customers look at her before turning away, going back to their food or their own problems.
Diana's tears run down her face and she sniffles loudly. She takes a deep breath and shakily lets it out, "I...I'm scared, Markham. So goddamn fucking scared. I--I don't have much left, and my landlord is getting pushier by the second. I'm so tired."
Her eyes dart around and she gets up, "I should go. I should just go home--"
Markham puts his cold hand on Diana's wrist and looks into her eyes, "Diana. I can help you."
The mortal winces and yanks her hand away from his cold grip. She stares at him, and the tears stream down her face. She looks at the clock near the exit, "I...I really have to go."
He stands up and tells her, "I'm serious. I can give you a little cash to cover your rent, or--or at least find a room to stay in till things start to look up for you."
Diana scoffs, "Things don't get better in this madhouse, Markham. They just...don't. You wouldn't understand."
"Diana, wait, I--"
She halfheartedly tells him, "Thank you for listening. I shouldn't have done that to you, y'know, dumping all my problems on you like that, but you're a friend, and I really appreciate it, Markham. I'm sorry, but I really have to go now. I'm so...tired."
"Diana, I can help you!"
She doesn't stop and walks out of the diner. She quickly gets in her van, starts it up, and pushes off before the Baali can catch up with her.
He runs outside, and she's gone. Markham returns to his booth and sighs. His fingers tap on the table, and his lips curl into a frustrated grimace.
Mr. Reed grabs his stuff, leaves the water where it is, and heads down the sidewalk. He walks along the cracked footpath, his shopping bag in 1 hand and his phone in the other.
The Baali constantly looks over his shoulder to make sure that nobody's tailing him. He's fairly that Mr. Strickland's people are still on to him, now more so than ever.
Markham sighs and dials Diego on his phone.
After a few rings, The Gangrel picks up, "Yo, d-man! What's up? How's your shopping trip? Find something your size, eh? That place usually has it all, haha!"
The Baali swiftly replies, "I'm fine, but I need you to pick me up."
"Sure thing, hermano. Wait for me by the same place that I dropped you off at earlier in the evening. Traffic's heavy 'round here, y'know how it is. Just wait or do some more shopping if you wanna, OK?"
"Thanks, see you soon."
Markham hangs up and idly loiters around this rather tight street. It's mostly covered with mid-range shops, hash-houses, and seedy bars. The sidewalks are also quite crowded.
Most of the pedestrians are fairly average-looking middle-aged folks or youngish student types. They walk around the city and fill the streets with the sound of chattering voices, raucous laughter, and clomping footsteps.
The air around here is heavy and thick with the smell of car exhaust, tar, and the scent of some nearby construction work. It's a fairly dingy part of the city, that's for certain.
He stands in the crowd, looks over his shoulder and watches his back, as he waits for his Feral buddy to come and pick him up.
Markham's eyes are fixed on a street corner, and he begins to get the feeling that something isn't quite right. The hairs on his undead neck stand up. He senses some sort of unease creeping up on him.
After a short moment, he manages to place where he feels this "unease" is coming from. It's coming from a very quiet, unassuming spot near a dark corner.
The vampire can feel a pair eyes, malicious and hateful, burning into his back.
Markham can sense a...a presence behind him. His bestial instincts pick up on this very easily. He's not sure if the people around him can feel it or if he's just being way too jumpy.
To be safe, he walks a few paces forward and activates his Obfuscate Discipline. He hopes that this'll allow him to shake off anyone who might be trailing him.
But his instincts remain sharp and his Beast remains on-edge. The presence of a threat is still there. The Baali subtly surveys his surroundings with a carefully crafted mask of cool indifference.
His body shimmers under the flickering lights of the streetlamps and he shuffles along the sidewalk, a few paces ahead from the larger crowds.
The presence grows stronger, and the Demon can tell that it's getting closer, not easily giving up as he had hoped it would.
Mr. Reed rounds a corner and hits a dead-end alleyway. The presence grows even more stronger now. Markham channels even more of his Vitae into his Obfuscate and completely disappears in the blink of an eye.
There's still a cold and tense feeling in the pit of his undead stomach, and he keeps a careful watch on his back. The presence looms behind him, and Markham turns around and sees a broad figure blocking his way.
A man who looks to be in his 40s sharply curses under his breath, "Dammit! Lost him again! The boss is not gonna be happy about this! Hrrr!"
He's talking to his unseen associate, a man who is in his mid-30s, and who is a few meters away. The 40-something man then looks around and gives his buddy an order, "Find him! GO!"
The 40-something pulls out his cheap flip phone and dials a number. He waits for whoever's on the other end to pick up.
He doesn't wait long and says, "It's me, s--sir. We've lost the mark. Yes, sir. Again. I am truly sorry, sir. It's like he--he was here 1 moment and then poof, gone! No trace, nothing. You know that we're working under a lot of pressure here."
The 40-something man bows his head, "I understand, sir. Yes, returning now. Thank you, sir. OK. Goodnight." He hangs up and places his phone in his pocket.
Markham can't stay Obfuscated in this tight corner forever, but he holds on until the assassin grumbles and reluctantly stomps away. The Baali lets out a long, shaky sigh and slowly rematerializes.
Diego eventually swings by to pick up his Baali buddy. They drive back to the former's Haven. Markham is oddly silent throughout the entire trip, and Diego can sense that something's wrong.
He looks over at Markham and inquires, "You OK, homes?"
"Yes. I'm fine, Diego. I'm fine."
Markham is still thinking about Diana. She looked so...lost and broken. The hopelessness was practically written all over her face. A part of him fears the worst, and that part might just turn out to be right.
Still, another part of him fights those extremely dark and worrisome thoughts away, telling him that Diana Moskowitz is fine. She's gonna be fine, but Markham is not wholly convinced by this.
Not by a long shot.
Much later...
It's now 11:57 PM. Prince Antonio Black is standing on the roof of a large corporate building near Flimont City's financial district. There is a full moon tonight, and the cloudless skies are speckled with a few stars.
The air is warm but not horribly so. He takes a moment to just admire the sight below him.
The city beneath the Ventrue Prince is a sea of blinking lights. The streets are a swarm of tiny cars and tinier people, their every movement as easy to track as ants in a colony that is chaotic and out of control.
The air around here smells of smog and exhaust. The sky above is a mixture of dark blue, black, and a few thin, pale patches of gray.
The roof is sparse. There are some satellite dishes, exposed wires, and a few pots filled with dirt and plants.
The Prince pulls out a satellite phone and extends its antenna. He attaches some sort of voice disruptor device to the bottom.
He presses a few buttons, dials a number, and places the device over his ear. He waits patiently for the other person to pick up on their end.
Special Agent Cuomo (?) answers. He sounds tired and irritated, "Yes? Who is it?"
The Prince's voice is distorted, "It's me. Did you act on the information that I provided you? I'm not seeing any major changes in the situation, so far."
Special Agent Cuomo's tired voice is dry, "Yes. We're making good progress. We got 1--"
Prince Antonio growls, "1?! Is that it?!"
"Well, we were expecting more, but 1 is all we got. We took care of him, Mr. X. It was messy, but we got the job done. Now, we wait for his buddies to slip up when they come looking for him."
"You fuckin' joker! 1 is all you got? Did you kill that asshole?! WHERE is he?! Did you at least get anything out of him?!"
"Easy, now. Easy. Truth is, we went in there expecting more than 1, but what we got should suffice. There was no point interrogating a bum like him. He's dead, that's 1 less bloodsucker to worry about."
"That's not good enough! I don't feed you idiots info for jack squat!"
Special Agent Cuomo sighs and scratches his forehead with his thumb, "Mr. X, please, calm down. We know how valuable your intel has been to us over the years. The SAD owes you a lot, but we need time. It's been a while since I've personally been out on the field again."
The Blue Blood Prince seethes, "It better be soon! I want a nice, clean, and quiet town. I don't need a repeat of 1995 again, you hear me?!"
Special Agent Cuomo shakes his head, "1995 was a tactical mistake. We trusted...unpredictable assets and got outmaneuvered by a bigger, uglier players. That's never gonna happen again."
The Ventrue Prince snarls, "Just get the fucking job done."
"Weren't you the one who gave us that intel all the way back in 1995, Mr. X?"
What?!
Prince Antonio nods in the affirmative, "Yeah, and I expected you to get rid of those fucking Mexicans back then. I want 'em gone and that means NOT making the same mistake as 1995 again! I don't wanna hear any more excuses!"
Special Agent Cuomo frowns, "With all due respect, don't tell me how to do my job, OK? You think you know blank bodies, think again. Look, think of this morning's raid as a test run, alright?"
The Blue Blood Prince grimaces, "This is so goddamn infuriating! I risk my ass feeding the fuckin' FBI this info and all I get for it is 1 dead dumbass and not a single thing of worth?! How much do I have to do for you assholes to get the job done right?!"
The Special Agent groans, "Look, we're dealing with some very nasty customers here, OK? Besides, our operations are subject to a hell of a lot more scrutiny compared to back in the day. It's a new goddamn world out there!"
Prince Antonio claps back, "I know what year it is. Don't patronize me."
Special Agent Cuomo shrugs, "Alright, alright, alright. Fine. Here's what we're doing. You keep providing us with the intel and we'll provide you the results. Sound good?"
"Hmph. I want results, not a result. I wanna see those fucking Mexicans get destroyed!"
"I said that we're working on it."
The Ventrue Prince exhales softly and angrily growls, "This is a shit show. An absolute shit show! You still haven't gotten the job done...even after all this time, even after I DRIP FED you the info all those goddamn years back!"
Special Agent Harold Cuomo takes on a sterner tone, "Mr. X, I'm going to have to calmly ask you to...Dial. It. Down. A. Notch. The SAD is working round the fucking clock here. I'm up against the wall here, OK? I don't have time for your whining and I sure as hell don't have time for your late-night phone calls!"
Prince Antonio sighs softly, "Just get it done. I've already given you and your people everything I know. I'm tired of going back and forth with you fuckin' people. I thought you were the best in the business, but I was wrong, huh?"
He abruptly hangs up, and Special Agent Harold Cuomo massages his temples.
The Blue Blood Prince places the phone in his suit pocket and massages his forehead with his hand.
Wow.
So, Prince Antonio is responsible for bringing the Second Inquisition down on the Gangrel back in 1995, huh? What a walloper.
Back then, the SI used white supremacists to hit the Gangrel in this Domain. Those racist thugs were given wooden stakes, training, funds, and top-notch gear.
They were wound up and let loose on the Ferals. Thankfully, the 5th Street Cholos managed to repel the attacks. But...they lost a lot of good people along the way.
The Gangrel never did get to the bottom of why they were attacked and who exactly armed those crazies.
And now, a few years later, the same shit is happening again.
The Second Inquisition is back and this time, they're really "out for blood".
It was Prince Antonio who used the forces of the SI against his political enemies. He wanted to get rid of the Gangrel in this city so he could swoop in and acquire their land and gentrify it, with himself standing to handsomely profit from such grim endeavors.
But there just 1 issue with that plan: the Gangrel were not simply going to roll over and get destroyed. They are, after all, The Clan of the Beast.
They ferociously fought against those thugs, tooth, nail, fang, and claw.
Till now, the events of 1995 remain a mystery to the other Kindred. Prince Antonio initially did not order any kind of investigation into the matter, but pressure from the Gangrel Primogen- Pedro- soon forced his hand.
Using the very generically laughable name of Mr. X, the Ventrue Prince feeds intelligence to the forces of the Second Inquisition. It's an unoriginal move, really.
Kindred in other Domains are known to do shit like that- feed detailed info on political rivals or other inconveniences to those capable of exterminating them with relative ease.
In the case of failure, the fingers point to everywhere (and everyone) else but the cause. Nobody in their right mind would use the Second freakin' Inquisition to destroy fellow Kindred, right?
Yeah, well...eh.
Prince Antonio shrugged and moved on while Pedro begrudgingly accepted the outcome of the "investigation". Unbeknownst to the Outlander, round 2 has officially started.
Till now, only Prince Antonio knows the truth of what happened in 1995 and who truly bears responsibility, and that truth is coming for everyone in the city, sooner or later.
Now, one hopes (in great earnest) that Dr. Collins and Roxanne can overthrow this Ventrue mafioso maniac and (at the very least) hold him accountable for his treachery against Kindred Society.
(Even Sheriff Velma DuPont is unaware of the fact that she's being played by her dear Prince- she's never been the type to question those above her, especially when they are members of her Clan.)
He did all of this for...land. He's so hellbent on scooping it all up, gentrifying it to the max, and sitting back and reaping the bountiful $$$ harvest. He's using his power and influence to reshape the face of Flimont City, all in the name of himself and his Clan.
(Mainly himself).
Then again, what he's doing is the kind of thing that's almost...encouraged (one might say incentivized) around these parts. Flimont City is a city of unbridled greed. Dog-eat-dog, law of the jungle, all that individualistic gung-ho getting-to-the-top-no-matter-what shit.
This kind of thing happens more often than not in this Midwestern metropolis, and Prince Antonio Black is taking advantage of the whole shebang and simply emulating what he sees around him.
(Hell, he's soon a lot of nasty shit over the past 100 years on the throne).
Other busters in this joint do it through pen strokes, lawsuits, political pull, or a toxic combination of all 3. All this secrecy. All this planning. All this manipulation.
Prince Antonio Black has done a lot of terrible things in the past, and it's about time that someone in this city holds him accountable. His 100-year reign has to come to an end.
Things need to change around here, that much is certain. This corruption, extortion, and greed must be dealt with sooner rather than later.
Of course, by the time all is said and done, will the change that is brought about be meaningful or a mere reset of the status quo?
Will the Prince and his cronies be successful or will they be exposed?
Will the other Clans in this Domain come to the side of Roxanne and Dr. Collins or will they all fall under the weight of Prince Antonio Black's machinations?
Only time will tell, and you best be prepared for what it has to say!
For now, the Prince of this city exhales sharply and leaves this building. He puts on a black fedora and calmly saunters off, none the wiser about the plot that Roxy and the good doctor are cooking up against him.
He took a good and long look at the city from this rooftop and smiled to himself, satisfied with how far he has come in all these long, long years.
"Here's to another 100 years," Prince Antonio tells himself in a fit of purely grandiose delusion and narcissism. He leaves and returns to his majestic Haven. His grin is a broad, smug thing. He looks forward to the future.
And the future, well, seems to have some surprises in store.
For all.
Clarice is back in her Haven. Sunrise is moments away now. Arnold says, "Good morning" to his Domitor, because "Goodnight" would just be silly, wouldn't it?
Clarice smiles at him, "And a good morning to you."
She told her Ghoul that Dallas went somewhere, and that she has no idea when (or if) the Fledgling will be back. She undoubtedly has her own reasons for withholding the unpleasant truth.
Arnold is a bit of a fragile guy, who needs care and delicacy. He's different. So, Clarice decided to spare him the awful news, for the time being, at least.
As the Malkavian Primogen is being dragged into the pincers of the day-sleep, she decides to wander the infinite breadth, length, width, and height of the Malkavian Madness Network in search of answers and info.
Answers and info pertaining to this God-Machine that Dallas was yelling about. Clarice doesn't know exactly what she's looking for, but she has a few hunches.
She wants to know more about the God-Machine, and what better place than the Cobweb?
The mind of a Malk never "sleeps". Clarice will "look" into the God-Machine, navigating through the endless maze-like structures of the Weavery.
She'll explore the vast expanses of the Tapestry, hoping to stumble across some clues or maybe even a few useful facts and figures.
As she's being lulled in, a sad and distant voice interrogates her specifically, "Why, Clarice? Why me?"
It's Dallas and he sounds so...broken and lost. His voice is filled with despair and despair alone.
She tries to answer him, but he simply goes on and on, a long-winded speech about his childhood, his parents, his hopes, fears, dreams, and his school.
"There was so much to look forward to!!!" Dallas yells out into the expansive void, his voice merely 1 amongst an infinite sea of howls, cries, shouts, and screams.
Clarice listens. She empathetically listens, and she tries to respond to him, but her words are devoured by the void. They are muffled by the other loud noises that permeate this space.
The Malkavian Primogen feels something deep inside her, a vague tugging feeling.
Dallas, despite being destroyed, still desperately calls out to her with all of his might. His pleas echo through the infinite void of the Malkavian Collective and are devoured by the silence and the emptiness.
Clarice cannot do anything to help him now. She wishes she had done more, but Sheriff Velma had that disturbing look in her dead eyes. Her gaze was a cold and heavy thing.
"Teacher! Please, please, don't leave me! She--she cut off my fucking head! MY HEAD! Teacher...AAAAAAAH!" Dallas screams and his cries are swallowed up by the void.
So, Clarice pushes through and reaches out. Her mental feelers speedily branch out in every direction imaginable. She wants to comfort Dallas, to tell him that everything will be alright and that he can still find happiness...even in here.
She also focuses a part of her mind on learning more about this God-Machine entity. The sun is now up, and the Kindred are essentially "dead" to the world around them.
Their bodies are as still as the grave, but their minds might still active, still moving about to and fro.
Yet another day dawns on Flimont City, but not all will be well for everyone.
